PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite (from 480 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 124 citizens), Mr Macphee (from 44 citizens) and Mr Scholes (from 42 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully sheweth:
The irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 17 citizens), Mr Nehl (from 37 citizens) and Mr Scott (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Lilyfield Post Office Agency, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office agency at Lilyfield be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our requirements, or even to collect registered letters and parcels. Many of us are pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Offices are about 2.5-3kms away with no convenient public transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Lilyfield Post Office Agency and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Glaucoma
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that thousands of Australians are known to suffer from glaucoma
that some 200,000 Australians are potential sufferers of glaucoma
that glaucoma is the leading cause of preventable blindness
that most such blindness can be prevented through early detection and treatment
that initial detection of possible glaucoma is simple and inexpensive.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled initiate a national, voluntary campaign to screen for glaucoma particularly at workplaces and in institutions.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain electors of Australia shows:-

that the introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage the sick, elderly and disabled people as well as counselling and community services, particularly Lifeline.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament will reject the present proposal by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls as being an unfair cost burden on private individuals.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:-

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Time-charging for the business sector is also unfair and unreasonable as any charge increase to business will be borne by consumers in the end.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to;

Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent both Australian people and Australian business from being seriously disadvantaged by yet another ludicrous charge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
(1) That we oppose timed local calls by Telecom
(2) Timed calls should not be introduced in the absence of widespread community support

(3) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject plans by Telecom to time charge local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.

Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent the Australian people from being seriously affected by yet another ludicrous charge.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Cowper respectfully showeth that:

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent the Australian people from being seriously affected by yet another ludicrous charge.

PETITION.TITLE: National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australian Card'' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Humble Petitions of the Undersigned Citizens respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to time local telephone calls gravely concerns all people. Isolation and communication was the second biggest problems facing rural women according to the ``Survey of Rural Women'' questionnaire and any attempt at timing local calls will add to this problem, not decrease it.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that Telecom do not proceed with the timing of local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-
Any proposals by Telecom to charge local calls on a time basis would seriously disadvantage the elderly, the sick, the housebound and the underprivileged.
Any such proposals would involve enormous expense to callers ringing Government Departments, Telegrams, Doctors etc where they are required to hold on for long periods of time.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that the proposal to introduce timed local calls does not proceed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Treatment of Sun Damaged Skin and Warts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows that the petitioners are concerned that the Minister for Health proposes to delete from the Medical Benefits Schedule those item numbers covering the treatment of sun-damaged skin and warts by specialists. They fear that those patients suffering chronically from these problems cannot always be treated successfully by a general practitioner. They protest that they will be financially disadvantaged. They also realise that their problems require early detection and expert treatment, if the petitioners are not to be exposed to increased risk of skin and other cancers.
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and permit the abovementioned items in the medical schedule to be reinstated.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned by the threat to social morality and the welfare of children, posed by the unrestricted importation, distribution and sale of X-rated pornographic video material in and from the Australian Capital Territory.

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and reverse its amendments to ACT legislation and Customs regulations which have resulted in Australia wide distribution of material restricted under State censorship laws.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australian and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients and calls upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:

That the Government's decision to terminate an existing agreement with St. Luke's Medical &Hospital Benefit Association Limited for the provision of facilities for the receipt and limited processing of Medicare claims will:-
Deny ready access to cash reimbursements of Medicare claims.
Deprive citizens of a personalized reliable claims payment service.
Reduce job opportunities in the State.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reconsider their previous decision to discontinue Medicare agency arrangements.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We are opposed to the proposed restructuring of the A.B.C. We believe that the A.B.C. is one of the most important public services in Australia and a mainstay of democracy.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House of Representatives will take measures to ensure that the A.B.C. is permitted to continue to offer ``comprehensive'' broadcasting services under its present charter.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ban the sale of violent videos, books and toys of violence, in an effort to put an end to the increasing number of violent crimes committed in this country.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Fairlight Post Office Agency is to be closed.

It serves a Community Need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels, and would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to Serve the Public for the variety of services they offer.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of this Post Office Agency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mining of Mount Etna, Central Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. Mt Etna, Central Queensland, listed by both the Queensland National Trust and the Commonwealth Heritage Commission as essential to the National Trust, is currently being mined for limestone by the Central Queensland Cement Company and is to be totally destroyed.

2. Mt Etna has many unique faunal and cavernous attributes, in particular the cave Bat Cleft, is the largest by far of only five known breeding sites for the Little bent-winged bat, with 86% of the population breeding there.
3. Limestone surveys have shown that there are many non-cavernous lime-stone deposits in the Rockhampton area.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the members of the House of Representatives will call on the elected government of the State of Queensland to:
a. Halt the mining of Mt Etna, Central Queensland by the Central Queensland Cement Company.
b. Shift the Central Queensland Cement Company limestone mine from Mt Etna to another local area of non-cavernous limestone so as to maintain a local cement industry and the employment so generated.
c. Declare the hence vacated Mt Etna a national park so as to conserve for future generations its unique cavernous attributes in particular the Little bent-winged bat maternity site Bat Cleft.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: North Queensland Rainforests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposed nomination of Wet Tropical Rainforests of North Queensland to the World Heritage List. The listing as a World Heritage of such a vast area, including areas of State Forest scheduled for Timber Harvesting on a sustained yield basis, will have a detrimental effect on the Timber and Allied industries and on the citizens and economy of North Queensland.
The listing as a World Heritage of such a vast area will inhibit the future development of North Queensland on a broad economic base.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the listing of Wet Tropical Rainforests of North Queensland as a World Heritage.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows: We oppose the advertising of alcohol in any form.

Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism. Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness. Alcohol also causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio because of its persuasive effect on children and young people.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That we are strongly opposed to the proposal for metering of local telephone calls by Telecom since-
(i) higher phone bills would add more pressure to the family budget, and some would not be able to pay them;

We therefore request the House to give this matter a lot more thought before acting on the proposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Soya Milk
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that placing a 20% Sales Tax on the essential food item, Soya Milk, will present unnecessary financial difficulties to families.
Where many people in the community show a marked intolerance to dairy products, Soya Milk supplies a much need alternative.
We, the petitioners therefore request that the new sales tax on Soya Milk be rescinded.

DEBATE.TITLE: ECONOMIC POLICIES FOR THE G7 MAJOR INDUSTRIAL COUNTRIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in view of the severe constraints on global economic growth and on the development of lower income countries caused by severe trade imbalances, high real interest rates, massive debts of many countries, historically low commodity prices, and industrial and agricultural protection, this House urges the Group of Seven major Western industrial countries (the G7-the United States, Japan, Federal Republic of Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada) to-
(1) co-ordinate their national fiscal and monetary policies so as to reduce trade, exchange rate and interest rate imbalances and instability;
(2) strongly encourage current account surplus countries to adopt expansionary macroeconomic policies so as to increase their imports and stimulate world trade;

(3) reduce their wasteful military expenditure and urge Warsaw Pact countries to do the same so as to reduce fiscal imbalances, reduce interest rates and increase resources for economically and socially useful activities;
(4) establish facilities through the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank for phased, partial debt forgiveness and rescheduling;
(5) increase overseas aid for developing countries to the greatest extent possible with the ultimate goal of reaching the UN target of 0.07% of Gross National Product;
(6) support a new issue of Special Drawing Rights by the International Monetary Fund allocated to developing countries to allow relaxation of their balance of payments constraints; and
(7) convene a global conference on reform of the international monetary system.

This is an unusual motion in that it urges action by other governments. However, it is written in these terms because the Group of Seven major industrial countries-the United States of America (US), Japan, the Federal Republic of Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada-are the principal influences on the state of the global economy. Therefore, the Australian Government cannot avoid having attitudes and opinions about the policies of those governments and urging them to take appropriate actions. The global economy is increasingly interdependent. If the United States Government contracts domestic economic activity, that will reduce US imports and so reduce Australian exports. When, in the early 1980s, the United States Federal Reserve tightened monetary policy, forcing up interest rates, the effect was to force up interest rates in Australia also. So anyone concerned about the Australian economy must attempt to follow what is happening internationally.

The global economy is experiencing turbulent and uncertain times. The stock market crash in October is the clearest example. There has been some recovery of confidence since that crash, but the severity of the decline in share prices, which was greater in Australia than anywhere else, has left an atmosphere of insecurity. Part of that crash was desirable correction to overinflated prices, but the size of the decline in share prices causes uncertainty which has some real implications. For example, with much reduced share prices, companies are less readily able to raise capital through new issues on the stock exchange, and this may lead to reduced levels of corporate investment. There is also a decline in the value of wealth which will cause wealth holders to reduce both their investment and their consumption. However, it is too early to be sure of the extent of the consequences of the crash on Wall Street and other stock exchanges around the world.

More important as an indicator of the severity of the current crisis are the low and declining global economic rates of growth. In 1986 world output grew by about 3.2 per cent. The estimate for 1987 is that world output will grow by 2.8 per cent, a small decline. Estimates for this year are of a further decline in that rate of growth. With global population growing at over 1 1/2 per cent a year, this means that real per capita average growth rates are less than 1 1/2 per cent. There are wide differences between regions and countries. Industrial country growth rates tend on average to be slower than those of developing countries. But there is negligible or no growth in many parts of Africa and Latin America. In fact, many African countries are experiencing a decline in their economies, and have been experiencing a severe depression for much of the last five or six years, whilst in the newly industrialised countries of East Asia and China growth rates are particularly rapid-in the 6 to 8 per cent range each year.

Another obvious cause for concern is the size of the United States current account deficit-it was over $US50 billion in 1987-and the current account surpluses of Japan of about $US85 billion and Germany of about $US40 billion last year. Australia is experiencing a similar imbalance, our current account deficit being estimated at $11.5 billion in the current financial year.

Another symptom of turbulence is high interest rates. Late last year long term interest rates in major industrial countries were 5 per cent or more in real terms, which by historic standards is very high. The consequence of that is to retard investment, to increase the cost of servicing loans among borrowers and so to slow economic recovery and growth. High real interest rates are a particular problem for heavily indebted developing countries.

In 1987 African countries were, on average, having to pay 33 per cent of the value of the exports of their goods and services in interest payments on their debt. Countries in central and Latin America were having to pay more than 50 per cent of the value of their exports of goods and services in debt service. Heavily indebted countries have ratios of debt servicing to exports which are, of course, even higher. One reason that these debt service ratios are so high is that no matter how hard indebted countries try they are experiencing great difficulty in servicing or repaying their debts because during the last three or four years the prices they received for their commodity exports have collapsed, as they have for Australia; we can understand their circumstances well.

Non-oil primary commodity prices have declined on average by around 16 per cent during the last three years. In recent months there has been some recovery but not nearly enough to offset that decline, the consequence being that, while indebted countries have tried to increase the value of their exports by increasing the volume, that increase in volume has been offset by a deterioration in price so that the value has often stagnated. Australians are familiar with this problem because we have experienced it as well and the deterioration in our own terms of trade is the major factor behind our high current account deficit and growing overseas indebtedness.

Yet the major industrial countries are not taking action to offset these trends. In fact, during the 1980s trade has been made more difficult by growing protectionism in North America, Japan and Western Europe. It is not surprising that the rapid growth of imports to the United States of America should have led to calls for increased tariffs and protection, nor that the vociferous claims of farmers in the United States, Japan, France and Germany should have led to high levels of agricultural subsidy and protection in those countries. But it remains true that protection is contrary to the interests of both consumers in those countries and all producers and consumers in commodity exporting countries.

It is essential that there be a reduction in agricultural protection. Australia's initiative in establishing the Cairns group, so as to effectively advocate reduced agricultural protection during the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, should be vigorously pursued and vigorously supported. The heads of government of the seven major Western industrial countries meet annually to discuss principally economic policy. Therefore, it is relevant to urge them to take coordinated action. In any case, coordinated action is important because unilateral actions to correct some of the imbalances could intensify the problems. For example, the United States current account deficit must be reduced. That country has become the world's greatest debtor with international debts totalling more than $US400 billion.

The consequence of cutting United States imports is that the exports of the rest of the world to the United States will fall. This could have the effect of initiating another global recession unless world trade is stimulated by those countries that have the capacity to do so. So a cut in United States imports must be offset by an increase in imports by Japan and Germany, the major surplus countries, by the other small surplus European countries and by the surplus newly industrialising countries such as South Korea and Taiwan. A reduction in the United States fiscal deficit might also contribute to a reduction in United States interest rates through a relaxation of monetary policy. That would contribute to maintaining and encouraging investment in the rest of the world and so ease the debt servicing problem for indebted countries.

Greater stability is also required in exchange rates because instability inhibits trade. Stability of exchange rates requires coordinated intervention in foreign exchange markets by those countries with the capacity to do so. There has been much more intervention in recent months and a reduction in instability as a result. That has come about because of coordination between Washington, Tokyo and Bonn in particular. Much more is difficult to achieve because any coordination involves some reduction in national sovereignty. Yet the extent of global interdependence is such that coordination is essential. This suggests that the institutions for arranging coordination must be strengthened. For example, the powers and responsibilities of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank should be strengthened. The role of the Bank for International Settlement should also be enhanced. In fact, a global conference on reform of the international financial system is required in order to strengthen these international institutions and redirect their policies. It is good to see that the proposal for a global conference on international financial reform is receiving some more support internationally, notably from President Mitterrand in France, who has again nominated for that country's presidency.

Another reform of these international financial institutions which is required is to admit the Soviet Union and the eastern European countries, which are not at present members. It is an outdated anomaly that communist countries are not generally represented for they have a growing role in the global economy and their presence at debates concerning international financial and economic policy would enhance the effectiveness of these institutions. The US has recently indicated that it is considering supporting admitting these countries to membership. I hope that that proposal will be accepted and that the Australian Government will support it, too.

Japan and West Germany have adopted somewhat more expansionary macro-economic policies during the last couple of years. The West German Budget deficit is up to about 3 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product and some further tax reductions are planned. In Japan, public investment has increased. In both countries the volume of imports has increased and the extent of the current account surplus is starting to fall, principally because of the massive appreciation of their currencies. However, both countries' changes in macro-economic stance have been modest and more would certainly be warranted. Expansionary policies are also required in other surplus countries. There is a surprising waste in the size of the international reserves of Taiwan and South Korea, for example. Both countries could change their exchange rates and/or build up internal demand significantly, which would contribute to removing these imbalances. It is essential, too, that progress be made during the Uruguay Round of negotiations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade so as to reduce protection not only of manufactured goods but also of agricultural goods and services and to stimulate world trade in all those areas.

So far virtually everything I have said would be generally accepted. It is part of the conventional wisdom about the current state of the international economy. Other steps are also required though, and it is important that they not be neglected. One such step which is commonly neglected is to recognise the economic damage of the massive military expenditure in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and Warsaw Pact countries, and in the Third World, by the way, and the economic benefits which would accrue to all those countries from reducing military expenditure. During the 25 years from 1960 to 1985 military expenditures have gone up considerably faster than income per head. Gross national product (GNP) per capita globally rose by about 160 per cent between 1960 and 1985.

Military expenditure increased by about 250 per cent-that is, 160 per cent compared with 250 per cent. So there has been a particularly rapid increase in military expenditure during the last 25 years-much faster than the rate of economic growth. There was a particularly sharp increase in military expenditure in the first years of the 1980s, with much of that increase occurring in the United States, where for five years real military outlays increased by 7 or 8 per cent a year. Military expenditure was the major item of growth in outlays during that period and so was the major cause for the tightening of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve, which believed that outlays were growing too fast and had to be restrained. This forced up interest rates. Real interest rates soared to historically high levels, pushing up interest rates throughout the world. In a very real sense the growth in United States military expenditure under the Reagan Administration was one of the causes for the hike in interest rates in Australia in the first half of the 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good point.

—I thank the honourable member very much for that support. Home buyers, business investors and buyers of consumer durables in Australia paid a price for the growth in military expenditure in the United States. The central point, though, about military expenditure is that it is wasteful. It has what economists call a high opportunity cost, the cost of lost opportunities for using those funds for other important economic and social programs. Every dollar spent on military activity is a dollar which cannot be spent on upgrading roads, improving hospitals and improving the quality of the education system, let alone being spent on social security or aid to developing countries. That is the central reason why it is important that military expenditure be reduced not only in the United States but also in western Europe and, of course, in the Soviet Union and in eastern Europe because without negotiated, balanced reductions such decreases in military expenditure could not be politically sustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: The signing of the agreement between Gorbachev and Reagan on intermediate range nuclear missiles is a small but important first step. It is in the economic interests of all of us, as well as being important for our survival, that further agreements be negotiated reducing both nuclear and conventional armaments by both the superpowers and also by smaller countries.

Another factor undermining the global economy and contributing to the present decline is the extent of Third World debt. Both debtors and creditors must recognise that present attempts at alleviating the problem are inadequate. As the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) warned in its December Economic Outlook, the root problems of Third World debt have become less tractable since 1982. Multilateral solutions are essential. Many schemes have been devised, several of which have intellectual and political momentum. One which is being advocated by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid and which has momentum in the US Congress is the establishment of a debt management authority through the International Monetary Fund. This would require the establishment of a new fund to which contributions would have to be made and so there would be a small cost to governments. But, with an appropriate gearing ratio of, say, 10 : 1, such an authority could borrow hundreds of billions of dollars on the international financial markets over several years by selling bonds, mainly no doubt to current account surplus countries, which could then be used for buying up Third World debt at a discount. This would benefit developing countries by reducing the amount of their debt and their debt servicing obligations and also benefit creditor banks by enabling them to increase their liquidity, even though they would sustain a loss. But such a practice is already in place in the secondary market on Wall Street and it requires only extension of that principle to this proposed multilateral agency. The principle has also been accepted by the United States Administration in the new debt agreement with Mexico, so it could now be extended multilaterally with much less difficulty.

It is important that Australia seriously examine this possibility and that it be supported by our Executive Director of the IMF. As long as the Third World debt problem remains unresolved, Latin American, African and some Asian countries will not be able to make a significant contribution to global recovery. It remains as true now as it did 30 years ago that aid to developing countries is both an important humanitarian step towards reducing absolute poverty and in the interests of the industrialised countries, including Australia, because it enables the developing countries to expand, to increase their imports and so to stimulate world trade and production.

There has been a growth in real levels of aid from OECD countries during the 1980s. Some countries such as the Nordic countries and the Netherlands are remarkably generous, but other countries as well, such as Italy and France, have been increasing real aid flows. It is essential that all countries, including Australia, aim to build up their aid to the 0.7 per cent of GNP United Nations target. The undertaking by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to maintain the real level of Australian aid in the next Budget is an encouraging first step. Another step, which would ease the problems of deficit countries, would be to renew issues of special drawing rights (SDRs) by the International Monetary Fund. Most countries support this change. Only the Group of Seven major industrial countries, plus Australia, oppose this change. Their argument is that a new issue of special drawing rights would be inflationary but at a time when inflation is under control and when the contribution of a new issue of special drawing rights to global reserves would be tiny, and when there are severe current account deficit problems in many countries to the easing of which a new issue of special drawing rights would make a significant contribution, the arguments for not issuing SDRs are very weak indeed. The case for a new issue would be strengthened if it were made to developing countries. Ways of coping with the technical aspects of that have been suggested and are quite satisfactory.

Madam Speaker, these seven measures would all contribute to easing the current severe global economic problems. A short speech allows only superficial discussion but all the steps I have suggested would make an important contribution to resolving the problems. I hope that the Australian Government will advocate these policies in the global forums in which we are a member, and that this advocacy will be picked up by other middle-level countries so as to change the pattern of international opinion, which is a prerequisite to making the required changes in policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.
—Do you reserve your right to speak later?
—Yes, Madam Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, one can only support, and indeed approve, the general thrust of the motion moved by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), though it is somewhat difficult to escape an air of unreality and of wishful thinking in some of his remarks. I suspect that his speech fails to get down to real specifics. The basic thrust of the honourable member's remarks is to urge the countries of the Group of Seven to coordinate their national economic policies. That principle is certainly appropriate. But the reality, as perhaps came through in some of the honourable member's remarks, is that countries are very different. They are subject to varying domestic pressures; they have varying historical, cultural and other differences; they have different objectives. In these circumstances the matter becomes very complex.

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of the world situation of imbalance and instability, which is addressed by the motion before the House, is as follows. The balance of payments deficit in the United States of America is of the order of $US150 billion-truly massive, but less as a percentage of gross domestic product than for this country. The United States has a Budget deficit, not unrelated to the balance of payments deficit of the same magnitude. In the face of the trade imbalance, the United States dollar has fallen about 40 per cent, mainly occurring in the latter part of 1987, providing a natural correction. By contrast, Japan and Germany, the other main players on the world scene, are running large balance of payments surpluses. In addition, the newly-industrialising countries of East Asia are making their presence felt on the scene and they also are running very large export surpluses. It is a situation, particularly in the United States which cannot persist and which policy, co-ordinated or not, must address. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said of the United States situation:
You cannot build a lifestyle on a massive supplement of overseas savings.
He was referring to how the United States would finance the payments deficit. The Treasurer's comment was every bit as true of this country, under his own stewardship. I said in a recent speech:
Australians have to recognise the plain truth that their standards of living and real wages depend upon large-scale borrowing from foreigners.

Looking at the world economic scene, we see a Christmas Eve package in the United States hastily negotiated between the White House and Congress to reduce the Budget deficit, with little prospect of more decisive action until after the presidential election later this year-a completely inadequate response to the massive structural adaptation required, and one which will involve that country in an historically high level of new investment. Of course, the situation is no different in Australia-but there is more evidence in the United States of the essential new investment than in Australia's case, despite the Treasurer's recent rhetoric about the new equipment allegedly being installed.

Meanwhile, as the honourable member for Fraser said, Germany and Japan have introduced modest packages of increased spending and tax cuts. However, referring to the second proposition set out in the honourable member's motion, those moves have not been very expansionary, despite much world pleading. Referring to the newly-industrialising countries in the Far East-notably Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan and Korea-their currencies are tied to the US dollar, so that a depreciation in the value of the US dollar has little effect. How would one change that?

What I am saying is that the sentiment of this motion is in the right direction. But the reality is that there has already been much pleading for so-called coordinated action, and one soon reaches the limits of feasible coordination. But that is not to say that readjustment is not taking place. United States exports and German and Japanese imports have very much increased. Whilst the magnitude of the required adjustment is so vast that the danger of a slow-down-hopefully not a recession-in the world economy is considerable, currently world economic activity is holding up well, partly due to the relatively easy money conditions implemented since the stock exchange crash. For Australia that has meant a surge in commodity prices of the order of 11 per cent since last September, worth $3 billion on an annual basis in additional export receipts. It is of the utmost importance that the Hawke Government nevertheless presses ahead with the appropriate adjustment policies to take advantage of the breathing space so provided.

I turn to the other propositions in this motion. Proposition No. 5 is that there be increased aid to developing countries. Regularly in this House I enter the same plea, directed not only to the G7 group but to all development assistance donor countries. The outlook, unhappily, is bleak. There has been a worldwide declining trend in capital flows and development assistance to the developing countries over the past five years. One may well doubt whether Western governments will ever really recapture the generosity of past decades. There is, I submit, an urgent requirement to explore ways in which, say, the World Bank and other development institutions and governments can be much more active than they have been in the role of catalyst in promoting private lending and private initiative in development assistance activity. More of the right policies in developing countries-such as less regulation and control giving, freer markets, sound overall economic policy, outward oriented trade policy and a welcoming commercial environment for foreign investors-will encourage a significant enlargement of direct private investment in developing countries.

In recent years the net annual financial transfer from the rich to the developing countries has been a disaster picture. One estimate is that, whereas in the three years prior to the Mexican debt crisis in 1982 the 18 major developing countries received an annual net transfer in the order of $US40 billion, in the years since then there has been a net reverse flow from the poor countries to the advanced countries at an average of $25m to $30m.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is tragic.

—It is indeed. It is a flow from the poor to the rich, which means that the developing world is about $70 billion a year worse off measured in terms of control over resources than it was four years ago. Apart from the direct impact that has on developing countries, it is a major constraint on world growth. That only underlines the importance of coming to grips with the trillion dollar-$1,000 billion-debt overhang of the developing countries which is referred to in proposition No. 4 of this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the urging in proposition No. 3 for countries to `reduce their wasteful military expenditure'. There can be no doubt that the enormous cost of maintaining the nuclear balance and spending on armaments generally of the order of $900 billion a year, or about $1.7m a minute, adversely impacts on development assistance. Whilst a very large proportion of total military spending is by the superpowers, it is not confined to them. The complexity, the challenge, the utter frustration in this whole context, the juxtaposition of development needs and high military spending-I recognise the role of superpower rivalry in Third World situations in this context-are underlined by this statistic, that since the early 1980s developing countries have spent more on imports of armaments than they have received from all sources of development aid. Again military spending in total by Third World countries exceeds their spending on education, health and welfare put together.

As I have said on previous occasions, it would be great if we could have some sort of formula which linked the receipt of aid and development assistance with a decrease in spending on arms in recipient countries. The Germans tried this a few years back with some Latin American countries. But I fear that that is utopian, a dream world. Yet this perverse situation should not lead us to curtail efforts to provide development assistance on an increasing scale. That is one important and urgent imperative. But at the same time we-the world powers-have to work out and negotiate for arms control and the restraint of military spending as the other imperative. The situation is not without hope. I instance the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty of last year. While only this morning we had the announcement of a further Reagan-Gorbachev summit, with the prospect of an agreement to reduce long-range strategic weapons by 50 per cent. The imperative is to work on both these fronts at once, in the interests of the development of the world economy and the furtherance of world peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again I have the honour of following the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards). He injected quite a lot of commonsense into this debate. I compliment the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) for raising this most important matter before the House as it is probably central to the well-being and continuation of harmonious relationships between countries on this globe. It is easy to think of Australia and the major industrial countries as being self-sufficient. It is easy to think of them as world policemen. It is easy to think of them as having a high level of development and being quite independent from the developing nations. Yet, as has been said in this debate by the two contributors so far and as has been said in these types of debate before, global problems, identified by the honourable member for Fraser, require global solutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Fraser has knitted them all together in his preamble. He asks the developed countries, in particular the United States of America, Japan, the Federal Republic of Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada-whilst Australia is not one of those seven major countries we must be willing to do these things if we are going to ask other countries to accept responsibility-to bring in a coordinated plan to overcome the severe constraints on global economic growth, on the development of lower income countries, caused by the severe trade imbalances, high real interest rates, massive debts of many countries, historically low commodity prices and industrial and agricultural protection.

We would prefer to start off with a clean sheet. With all the knowledge we have from hindsight, we would like to start afresh and avoid these problems. However, they are very much part of our real world. Many of the mistakes of the past cannot be overturned overnight. It is important that we have the goodwill and intelligence to tackle those problems. The honourable member for Fraser has articulated in seven points the various approaches that could be made to make the well-being, the future and the standard of living in the developing countries somewhat better.

For instance, he referred to the need to overcome the debt problems of the developing countries. It is very easy for people to sit back in their armchairs in a middle-developed country such as Australia and to say that the developing countries have brought the problem on themselves, that they have denuded their forests, increased the amount of desert in their countries and therefore decreased the amount of arable agricultural producing land. We have to remember that all countries, including our own, have gone through several phases of development from subsistence to manufacturing to a predominance of service industries. Unless we understand that the developing countries are still concentrating on their agriculture and therefore their import earnings from agriculture we will not come to grips with the task before them. When we realise the magnitude of their debt servicing problem-50 per cent of their export income earnings, mainly from raw commodities, are required to service their debts-we can see that there is very little left over for the import of capital equipment and technical knowledge to develop their own economies, to develop their own diversification, so they can get on the springboard for industrial development. One of the big tasks for the leading developing countries, the Western countries, is to come to grips with the size of the debt, which is in excess of $1,080m, and determine how we can eliminate that.

The honourable member for Fraser put forward a very interesting suggestion about establishing facilities through the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank for phased partial debt forgiveness and rescheduling. Let me draw an analogy between debt consolidation and eliminating debt in our own country, a modern economy. It is better for the developed countries which are owed money to have a least part of that debt settled and to receive some compensation than to have a mounting debt, a mounting interest bill, that will never be paid. In this country a debt collector is quite happy to pass onto the creditor some portion of what is owed rather than to lose the lot. In other words, half a loaf of bread is better than none. I would support the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank working out a system whereby the developed countries could purchase the debts of the developing countries at a vastly reduced price. I do not know what the price would be, but it would be far better if those who are owed money receive, say, $200m from the developed countries and then wrote off the the $1 billion debt of the developing countries. Both sides would be far better off and the developing countries would be able to use far more of their income earnings from commodity prices for their own development. Much of the servicing of these debts comes not from the importation of technology but from the armaments area. I receive plenty of letters in my electoral office from people who recognise the problem major developing countries face. A large part of their economy is dependent upon the manufacture and sale of arms and the arms race. Much of the opposition to the de-escalation of the arms race, and to Gorbachev and Reagan seeking arms reduction, comes from the very industries that profit from its operation. It is not an overt argument; it is covert. It is very hard to argue that one wishes to make more money out of providing the weapons that will devastate the lives of not hundreds, not thousands, but millions of people and ultimately, with nuclear weapons, may well cause the destruction of the world as we know it. It is exceedingly important that all developed countries support the arms reduction talks and put pressure on those two world leaders to ask countries to forgo export earnings that come with the export of arms and realise that, if it is a choice between, to use the Mussolini phrase, `guns and butter', then it is better to produce butter.

I want to pick up the point of freer agricultural trade throughout the world. We hear a lot about the way Australia has suffered in relation to its export of commodities because of efforts by other Western countries, particularly the European Economic Community and the United States of America, who because of their domestic political situation feel obliged to support the farming community with enormous subsidies and so on. One can imagine how much more pertinent and serious it is for countries that depend solely on their export income from agricultural production to face these embargoes on and barriers to free world trade. The argument for freer world trade is far more important for the developing countries, and that is why I think it is a good idea at this point to remind the House of the efforts made by this Government to develop a seven-point plan to revitalise freer world agricultural trade.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) recently outlined in Davos, Switzerland, the seven-point plan that Australia would support, a plan that I believe the honourable member for Fraser would see as one that the G7 countries should be supporting. Our Prime Minister, quite rightly, called for, first, a commitment to halt farm subsidy increases, to which I have referred; secondly, a reduction in the gap between the internally administered farm prices and real market prices; and, thirdly, a move towards responsible management of stockpiles of surplus farm commodities. It is no use dumping our excesses, our pools, our lakes in the case of liquid exports, on the market because it only devastates the income of the developing countries. Fourthly, the Prime Minister called for a decoupling of farm support measures from farm commodity prices and fifthly, he called for an acceptance of a set of principles for world agricultural trade liberalisation. These were almost the same words as those used in the honourable member for Fraser's motion before the House. Sixthly, the Prime Minister called for an accord on international agricultural reform to be agreed to at the Venice Summit, after the declaration; and, seventhly, he called for negotiations to take place throughout the world to apply effective discipline to farm subsidies and/or price support programs and increased market access.

I am a great advocate of government intervention in the market, and I believe that those who advocate most strongly deregulation and privatisation in this country accept thoroughly a perfect free market situation that exists nowhere outside the economic text books. Many first-year economic students at university would have to reject that model, because in Australia, with its very small population and very small market, its oligopolistic situation with a few producers in any one area, we are a very long way from a perfect market. However, we probably come closest to a perfect market, a free market, when we talk about agricultural products on the world scene. The theories of comparative advantage that we learned at university, that all countries benefit from free trade, are actually realised in practice with a free world agricultural trade market where barriers to world trade, where subsidies, are eliminated. I totally agree with spokesmen from the other side, such as the honourable member for Berowra. I conclude by saying that the motion moved by the honourable member for Fraser has my full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak to a motion of this significance moved by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). Having been interested in this subject for about 20 years, I welcome debate on these issues in this Parliament. But I cannot help warning the House. After listening to a lot of the remarks made so far, and after following the literature on this subject over a period of years, I am constantly reminded of the comment of Dr Samuel Johnson that a second marriage is a victory of hope over experience. The motion before the House today has a substantial element of hope and very little of substance in terms of some of the major solutions that will be required in our current circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the limited time I would like to make just three quick points. The first relates to the nature of our current economic circumstances. I agree with the honourable member for Fraser that they are particularly difficult circumstances and they have been compounded-
