DEBATE.TITLE: TRADE RELATIONSHIP WITH THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House recognises the need to maintain a strong and expanding trade relationship with the USA and that to this end the Government should-
(1) invite a delegation of key US Congressmen to visit Australia for talks with key farm and government personnel as a matter of urgency;

(2) devote more resources to the promotion of Australia's primary industry produce in the US, as less than half of one per cent of Commonwealth outlays go to the Primary Industry portfolio, even though Australia's primary industries account for some 40% of export earnings;
(3) establish a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Primary Industry, with US trade a matter for immediate discussion;
(4) seek to arrange further talks between Australian parliamentarians and US Congressmen and farm leaders; and
(5) maintain regular and direct contact between US administration leaders and Australian Ministers, including the Prime Minister.

This motion was put on the Notice Paper on 15 September last year because there was then, as there is now, a potentially very protectionist trade Bill before the United States (US) Congress. That Bill provided for a broader range of export subsidies, principally through the export enhancement program, thus imposing in the eyes of Australia, and certainly of our primary produce exporters, unfair restrictions on Australian access to the US market, and also creating unfair competition against Australian exports on the world market. The implication was very clear: Australia's exporters cannot rely on the US Administration-that is, the executive wing of government-to protect Australia's access not only to the US market but to other markets because the Congress and the Administration do not necessarily move in the same direction and to the same degree.

The motion was drafted at that time also because of the great initiative of the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), the then Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia and shadow Minister for primary industry, in maintaining pressure on the Australian Government for an all-party delegation to visit the United States to make better contact with Congressmen, who are the key actors and operators in determining law in the United States Congress; that is, to maintain contact at the political level as well as the executive wing level. I emphasise that it was an all-party delegation, because I believe this is very much a bipartisan issue. We must protect our exports, particularly our primary produce exports, because they are now, and will continue to be for many years, the base of our export efforts and the best way in which we can reduce our mounting foreign debt. The success of that all-party delegation was quite clear. It prevented the extension by congressional action of grain subsidies to all United States export markets. Without that success the Bill, if it had gone through Congress, would have been disastrous for one of our major export industries, the grain industry.

When this motion was set on the Notice Paper some months ago it was very significant, but I believe its implications and its meaning have greater significance now. That trade Bill is still before Congress. One of the features of the US congressional system is that individual members of Congress can attach to Bills of any nature special provisions of a quite parochial nature which can have quite a disastrous and perhaps, on some occasions, unintended effect on Australian exports. For example, there has been a to and fro battle about imposing very restrictive lamb quotas through the trade Bill that is presently before Congress. That is something we have to watch all the time by maintaining communication not only at the political and farm industry level but also at the government level between our countries. We have to be alert at all times to see that these things do not happen, and I hope that, with communication, we are able to ensure that they are not even attempted.

The second point of greater significance is that the US presidential election campaign is well under way. Trade issues are being highlighted, and the campaigns of some of the leading protagonists or hopefuls on both the Democrat and Republican sides are alarmingly protectionist. I think it is to the benefit of all Australians that the campaigns of Congressman Gephardt and Senator Dole appear to be, if not dead, declining, because their policies would not be to the advantage of Australia or to a world wanting commercially freed up international trade arrangements. That is important, but it is also important that we are ready to begin talks with the new US Administration when it comes in early next year, because most of the significant decisions on international trade will be made after that Administration comes in. So we have to be ready and be sure that we are communicating so that it is aware of our situation. We have a general need to communicate with the different groups of people in the United States who influence decisions on the general international trade issues-the Multilateral Trade Negotiations, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) round, the Uruguay Round, if you like, the bilateral negotiations which, whether we like it or not, keep appearing and which we must watch very closely,

We do share the common concern of gaining equitable access to that very protected and restricted Japanese market, and beef is very much an issue at present. We are also concerned about the European Community's (EC) disastrous surplus agricultural product disposal policy. We have to make sure that when any decisions are made by the United States, whether made in Congress or by the Government, under pressure from farm industries, organisation and so forth, the US in total is made very much aware of the result and the consequences that they will have for Australia, including, as I said before, the unintended consequences of, for example, the lamb import quotas. We must ensure also that when the US is out to retaliate against what it sees as unfair trade practices by the European Community it does not hurt Australia, the innocent third party in this, more than it hurts the EC.

We must also make the United States aware of the intended consequences as well as the unintended consequences. For example, it should be made aware of the consequences of some of its quarantine decisions, which are purely political, and its disastrous domestic sugar policy, which I would rate even worse than the EC's domestic sugar policy, which is bad enough. By the United States maintaining its sugar price at several times the world level it has caused a dramatic reduction in sugar consumption in the United States. This has had adverse effects not only for Australia as a major exporter of sugar but also for many developing countries that rely almost completely on sugar for their international currency.

We have to be sure, by this greater degree of communication at all levels and at all times, that, when the United States discusses fair trade with the EC and with Japan, it is credible because it, too, must maintain a fair trade stance. I could provide quite a number of examples where it does not take a fair trade stance at the present time. It does not do any harm either to remind the United States that we are and want to remain a major contributor to and part of the Western alliance; but if we are to fulfil our involvement with a strong presence, we must have a strong economy, and that means the ability to have fair trade.

The purpose of this motion is quite clear. It is to provide for increased and better continuing communication at all levels. That communication must be maintained with members of Congress, who are important but distinct from the executive wing of the Government-far more so than in the Westminster system-with farm leaders and, of course, with Government officials. A further purpose of the motion is to provide for a standing committee on primary industry and agriculture in this Parliament. This proposal was inserted for the specific purpose of highlighting the priority we must give and must be aware of at all times to primary industry and its export earning capacity for Australia.

As I said earlier, if Australia's export position is to improve so that our balance of trade deficit is gradually reduced, we must at all times be alert to maintaining primary industry's export competitive advantage to ensure that access is available to other markets. And there are plenty of them. The primary production and agricultural export areas provide Australia with the greatest opportunity for increased trade. In relation to our beef exports, the restrictive quota arrangement that Japan has placed on our beef is the biggest single potential increased trade opportunity for Australia of any commodity of any type of industry at present. Australia exports to Japan, to the United States, the EC, South East Asia and the Middle East. In those markets there exists the potential to increase trade, but at the same time, there is the danger that Australia will be shut out of markets to which it should have fair access.

Pressure must be maintained at all times, not only on this Government, which is acting for Australia's interests, but also on parliaments, governments and leaders of other countries, in particular the United States because of the overwhelming importance not only of trade with the United States but also the consequences that decisions made by the United States have on our trade elsewhere. Although agriculture provides on a net basis 60 per cent of Australia's export earnings, and that percentage will continue to be maintained, it is also important through communications to maintain and improve trade opportunities for related commodities. I am referring in this context particularly to coal, which industry is experiencing difficulty at present. With coal, despite these difficulties, there is a tremendous opportunity to provide increased trade and export earnings for this country.

At the moment there is an urgent need to maximise our communications; to maintain pressure. Information should be provided about the consequences of actions taken by the United States and other countries. As I said earlier, we have Congress and the trade Bill. We have Japan with the 1 April deadline imposed by the United States that, unless it removes its quotas, it will be taken to GATT. We have the GATT round in general, the Uruguay Round, and the EC and its negotiating position on its surplus production. I believe that in recent months the Government has not maintained this overall pressure or there has there been a high profile of senior Ministers maintaining this pressure overseas. I acknowledge that by itself the Government cannot do this. Parliament has to do it and that is the purpose of this motion.

This motion makes it clear to the rest of the world that what we are saying here goes for both sides of the Parliament. This is a bipartisan approach. We are all in it together to try to maximise our export opportunities. Our rural industry leaders have played and will continue to play an important part. However, over the last couple of months, they have been left to carry too much of the burden, when one takes into account both the Sheep Meat Council of Australia and the Cattle Council of Australia. Key people have been visiting countries in relation to those issues. Mr Ian McLachlan, the President of the National Farmers Federation, has been conducting a campaign on behalf of Australia in the United States and in Japan.

To provide adequate time for other members to contribute to this debate I shall conclude on this one point: the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) leaves for Japan at the weekend to participate in this critical round of negotiations for better access for Australian beef to the Japanese market. He will seek better and fairer access. Fairer access is equally as important as better access. That access hinges on two issues: not only the ultimate abolition of those very restrictive quotas that Japan applies against imports of Australian beef, but also the abolition of that corrupt agency, the Livestock Industry Promotion Corporation (LIPC), which handles the great majority of the imports of beef into that country and, in the process, lifts the landed price of Australian grass fed beef by 300 per cent before it is released onto the wholesale market. That helps to ruin the major competitive advantage of Australian beef, which is its cheap price, as well as having the effect of ripping off billions of yen from Japanese consumers.

I wish the Minister well. He has the full support of the Opposition. I urge him to argue not only for fairer access in relation to the more favourable position that the United States has gained over recent years concerning the actual tonnage of beef that flows to the Japanese market, but also the unfair intervention of the LIPC, which corrupts the pricing mechanism on the Japanese market to the disadvantage of Australia with Japanese consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I wish to say that I welcome the majority of the comments made by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), in this debate. This motion is essentially of a bipartisan nature. All honourable members would be aware of the importance of the rural sector and its contributions towards reducing our foreign debt and, of course, in closing the current account deficit. Both those points were made by the honourable member for Murray.

SPEECH.PARA: A further point that should be made at this stage of the debate is that notice of this motion was first given to the Parliament on 15 September 1987. Therefore, to some extent, although the broad sentiments of the motion may certainly be canvassed here today in a bipartisan way, we must recognise that, since that time and certainly before the notice was given, the Government has recognised the importance of Australia's trading relationship with the United States of America (US) and has undertaken steps to ensure that that trade continues unimpeded and in our best interests.

Since we have come to government we have recognised the importance, as all governments have since Federation, to be fair, of our trade relationships with the rest of the world. In the sense of our relationships with the United States during the past five years we have certainly recognised that continual contact with United States congressmen has been essential in that process. It is very easy, of course, for people who do not really understand the nature of the American political system to say rather glibly that all of our activities should be concentrated at the Administration level.

I think that the point made by the Deputy Leader of the National Party is very valid. Certainly, while we should not miss the opportunities to consult and to press home Australia's case as far as the Administration is concerned, we should not lose sight of the importance of continual contact with US congressmen in our relationships with the United States. Of course, that is not a new proposal for this Government. We have been doing that. We have concentrated our efforts on US congressmen ever since what looked to be a highly protectionist trade Bill was first mooted in the US. It now looks as though some of the major detrimental elements about which we were at first very much concerned are being removed. I guess that our efforts have contributed to this change.

I join the honourable member for Murray in paying tribute to the joint parliamentary delegation to Washington in May last year, which played a very important role. It demonstrated the importance of the Parliament, rather than just the Executive Government, making a contribution. While it is important for us to recognise that on a government to government level the Australian Government deals with the US Administration, it is just as important that we, who see trade as being largely a bipartisan issue in this Parliament, should deal with this issue by way of a joint parliamentary delegation, as we did last year. Its objective, as stated in its terms of reference, was to press Australia's agricultural trade concerns and policy reform proposals with the US Congress and appropriate farm groups. We would all recognise the contribution that that delegation made. There was some scepticism about the way in which the delegation would be received when it was first mooted, but overall we can be entirely satisfied that that delegation was very successful.

Other visits were made to the US, including the visit by a former Minister for Trade, the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), in May 1987. He met with a number of congressmen and specifically discussed the trading relationship between Australia and the US. The primary focus of that visit was on meetings with congressional leaders, the major reason being to discuss the concerns of the Australian Government regarding the effects of the possible trade legislation about which we were all concerned.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party also commented about the highly protectionist stance that seems to have been adopted in the United States at present in the lead-up to the US presidential elections. One of the sad things that happen when people in the United States have a set time in which to choose their future leaders is that there is a period during that lead-up in which issues regarding relationships, both internally and certainly externally, are dampened down. Naturally, the incumbent would like to leave office feeling that he has made some sort of contribution. Yet the people who aspire to that office also have to watch the vested interests within the United States. We are well aware of the highly protectionist stance that is being adopted there. We need to be aware of the propensity in the debate in the US to become even more protectionist at a time when a lot of farmers in the US are feeling threatened. While we recognise that, we certainly cannot sit back and watch it happen. It is important that we continue those high level discussions.

The current Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) has made his first overseas visit in that capacity. He went to North America, where he met with 10 congressmen and presented Australia's concerns on the US Trade Bill and our wish to develop and improve trading relationships between Australia and the US. The other important thing in this debate is that we need to have some sort of understanding of the economic, trade, political and military roles of the United States in world affairs. The Deputy Leader of the National Party touched on this issue. While I am pleased to say that he did so in a very sensible way, we must continue to press home the point he made-that is, that we in the Western alliance are friends and we need to make sure that that friendship remains very strong and positive. To be able to maintain that strong and positive relationship, we have to ensure that the wealth of Australia is protected. Nowhere is that more important than in making sure that our export industries, particularly in the commodity areas, are protected in that process.

Of course, we are aware of the role of the US Farm Act, which has substantially reduced prices received by Australian farmers, particularly in 1985-86, when we saw a very severe downturn in the terms of trade. We are aware of the ongoing role of that Act, particularly in regard to the export subsidies under the export enhancement program and the role that that plays in greatly suppressing world grain prices. Many members of this chamber have wheat growers in their electorates who are very concerned about the impact of that program. As I have said before, we should not lose sight of the fact that the Government has recognised these developments in our trading relationships. Right from the word go we have attempted to tackle some of those impacts as positively as we possibly could.

In concluding my comments in this debate-I know that others want to make a contribution-we should look at the point raised by the Deputy Leader of the National Party concerning the promotion of primary products in the US and in general. The first point that we should make is that the United States is a competitor rather than a potential market for a wide range of Australian agricultural produce. Whether we like it or not that is a reality, particularly in the grains area. I think we also, to some extent, have to question this rather glib and simplistic approach the Opposition is taking by relating primary industry promotion expenditures to the budget of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. As most people would be aware, promotion of our commodities is largely financed by the industries themselves. That has been the case for many years and has been particularly emphasised since the Government has moved to reform statutory marketing authorities. It has also been done through Austrade and, as well, comes under the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button.

The chief promotional expenditure undertaken by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy is related to wool, much of which is directed to the US. Many members would recall that the Fraser Government held the Government's contribution to wool promotion constant at $20m for three consecutive years before our Government increased expenditure to its current level of $35.4m. In the current context of what is happening in the wool industry we have recognised the importance of those promotional efforts. The question of Government support for wool promotion is the subject of review at present. No doubt that report will be considered by the Government and a response will be indicated in due course.

Debate on these subjects is important in that in most cases the issues go right across party policy. We all recognise that to survive as a nation we need to make sure that our primary industries are well protected, not in the traditional sense of the word but in the sense of ensuring that our markets are retained and enhanced in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in the debate this morning and to second the motion moved by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), namely, that the House recognises the need to maintain a strong and expanding trade relationship with the United States of America (USA) and that to this end the Government should take certain steps. I welcome and recognise the fact that the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) in his remarks to the House has reflected the bipartisanship of this motion. I recognise, too, that the honourable member for Calare was just a shade sensitive about the motion being raised at all, lest it be seen as a criticism of the Government's track record in this area. Far from this motion being intended as a criticism of the Government's track record, it is intended to alert the Government, lest it be distracted by its current political fortunes and no longer focus the attention we think is necessary on trade arrangements with the USA. I remind the honourable member for Calare that we are simply pleading with the Government not to rest on its laurels.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the opportunity to participate in the debate on this motion which is vested in the long term interest of Australia's most productive sector and that sector of the Australian economy which exports that which is constantly renewable. While the national Press would currently have urban Australia believe that in rural Australia, in some magic way, things have turned around and all is well, the truth is a little different. It is true to say that wool prices are presently booming. If it rains, it will be fair to say that grain prices are barely satisfactory. It is also true to say that there are great opportunities in other primary producing areas, particularly horticulture. But if we look at agriculture in the long term perspective we see that in real terms returns are desperately down.

I want to illustrate this point by using the sort of analogy that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, used in today's news. Senator Button said that the car plan had resulted, sadly, in a rise in the price of the average suburban car by 40 to 60 per cent over the past four years. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you were a barley grower on Yorke Peninsula in my electorate you would consider for a moment this sobering fact: in 1974 with 30 tonnes of barley one could purchase a new Ford Falcon motor car. In 1988 if one wants to purchase a new Ford Falcon motor car one has to produce 200 tonnes of barley. That is a reflection of the way in which the returns to primary producers across Australia have fallen. In no other sector-nowhere in the Australian Public Service, in the work force, in Australia's current transport industries, and I say that for the benefit of the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris), who is at the table, or on the wharves-have employees faced that sort of fall in income. The very fact that there are still farmers in the electorate of Wakefield and they are productive is a measure not only of their productivity but also of their efficiency. In any other sector they would have disappeared off the face of the earth. In this motion we are not suggesting for a moment that farmers have been beaten by the unfair competition of overseas countries; instead we are saying that they have been unfairly impoverished and that no other sector has had to face this sort of decline in income.

It is true that the manufacturing industry as an export industry, along with primary industry, faces the dilemma of having to employ people in a wage protected market and then sell their goods in a producer protected market. Today's motion is designed to focus the Government's attention on the producer protected market. This is not a plea. It does not call for the Government to act and protect Australian farmers. It is not even a plea for the Government to intervene on behalf of Australia's primary producers. Rather it is a call for the Government to be a facilitator or a catalyst that will allow us to continue to reduce the unfair competition-unfair, mark you-that Australia's primary producers have to face overseas and, in the case of this motion, particularly in the USA.

The motion moved by the honourable member for Murray, the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, has five recommendations attached to it. First, it calls on the Government to invite US congressmen into Australia, reflecting precisely what the National Farmers Federation (NFF) has been endeavouring to do by informing congressmen in the US about what their protectionist policies are doing to Australian farmers. We are inviting the Government to bring congressmen into Australia not to berate them but so that we can inform them of the effect of their protectionist policies on the productive measures that Australian farmers might currently have in place. We do not want to berate them. We want to appeal to their US pride. We want them to recognise that they are a major factor in world trade, that they dominate world markets and that they have a responsibility to keep world trade alive. We want to point out to them the hazards of their present policy continuing. Those hazards are as much a danger to US producers as they are to Australian producers.
Honourable members should consider the editorial in the Australian of 29 January. The President of the NFF, Mr McLachlan, on his return from the US, stated:

The US sheep industry is the best example in the world of an industry being helped our of existence. It has been broken by subsidies. In four decades they have gone from 60 million sheep to 9 million sheep.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?
—From 60 million sheep to nine million sheep because of the protectionist policies of the US Government. The editorial continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr McLachlan said the slow demise of the sheep industry had been paralleled by the number of farmers sent broke by government featherbedding.

The Australian wool industry, which was facing ruin less than two decades ago, is now strong and vigorous. Rather than give in when prices fell, woolgrowers established a self-help scheme to stabilise prices and enable their industry to ride out the fluctuations that must be expected in any world market for rural produce.
We are saying to the US, `Come and see what we are doing and act as we are acting not only in our interests but in your own interests'.

Secondly, we are calling on the Government to be involved in a small way in the promotion of Australian products. I noticed that the honourable member for Calare said that this is unrelated. He said, `How can you compare the Department of Primary Industries and Energy budget with promotion for Australian products?'. Only half of one per cent of Commonwealth outlays goes into primary industry. All we are doing this morning is focusing the Government's attention on the fact that Australia's primary industries do not make demands on the taxpayer. They currently generate 60 per cent of our export earnings and it would be reasonable for the Government to consider doing something to facilitate the promotion of Australian primary products overseas-not in the interests of Australia's primary producers, but in the interests of our whole society, because we need more exports and more export sales to address our balance of payments deficit. So we are saying, `Let us consider the Government giving some attention to the promotion of Australian primary industries'. Furthermore, the US is the second largest market for our export produce-21 per cent of our export produce finds its way into the USA. We could be sorely tempted to enter into the sorts of trade deals with the USA, one for one, that would create, once again, the sorts of cartels that have so failed world primary industry. We are resisting that. We are, instead, inviting the Government to aid the promotion of Australian primary industry overseas.

Thirdly, this motion calls for the establishment of a standing committee on primary industry. If honourable members look at the Notice Paper on these benches any day of the week they will see that it is full of standing committees that have been set up by this Parliament. I do not want to run through them because time does not permit, but it would be reasonable to say that, in an area as important as primary industry and so calling for a bipartisan approach as primary industry does, we ought to consider the establishment of a standing committee on primary industry. The fourth point of the honourable member for Murray's motion calls for further talks between Australian parliamentarians and congressmen. The fifth point encourages the US Administration leaders and Australian Ministers to talk about what we can do to break down the present protectionist mentality of the United States.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the motion moved by the honourable member for Murray is a timely one. It is designed to slot in with the current United States presidential election campaign and to encourage United States farmers to accept what they already know-that, fundamentally and simply, not only can the present level of protection not continue, but it is not in their own interests. Of course there are faults in our own economy; of course there are faults in the way we go about things in Australia. We are not proud of the fact that, while exports as a percentage of gross domestic product have increased in North America, East Asia, Western Europe and the world in general between the years 1960 and 1988, the Australian figures have fallen. We must address that decline. The motion before the House is part of the steps we must take to do that. I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I first congratulate the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) on moving the important motion now before the House. Having said that, I wish to tackle some of the matters raised by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I always find it interesting that we have an Opposition which wants to slash expenditure to the bone, which goes to the electorate calling for cuts of $8 billion but which every day in this House criticises this Government.
—It is $11 billion.

—I am rightly corrected by the Minister. Daily in this House members of the Opposition debate matters economic, calling for further expenditure cuts, but when it suits their political purpose they regularly stand up in this place and call for increased expenditure. It seems to me that they want to have their cake and eat it. One cannot, on the one hand, call for reduction in public sector spending and, on the other hand, support the sort of motion moved by the honourable member for Murray. That is an impossibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers and Senate Committee System

Though I am supportive of the general thrust of the motion, it fails to tackle the problem facing Australia in terms of our international trade. Though the United States of America is a key player in the trade difficulties we face, the problem is not limited to that country. The harsh reality is that, like it or lump it, the United States is using its protectionist arguments in its battle against the European Economic Community (EEC) and Japan. One cannot isolate the United States as the source of the problem facing Australia's agriculture and resource exports. The world must examine where it stands in matters of international trade. It must look carefully at the distortions occurring in the wealthier nations, such as the EEC, the United States and Japan, whose collective policies deny free trade and entry into their markets of cheaper unsubsidised goods, such as those which Australia exports.

Japan, of course, has a strong anti-import regime. Australian beef, which could sell very cheaply in Japan-considerably below the current price-is denied entry. I understand that a kilogram of beef currently sells on the Japanese market at a price equivalent to $A480. It staggers me, as it must any Australian, to think of anyone paying such a price, when our country has the capacity to export to Japan tonnes of prime fresh beef which would substantially lower the cost of living and provide the Japanese with good food. The Americans face a similar problem in the importation of beef into Japan.

I stress again that the motion before the House is too narrow. It does not go to the problems facing the United States; it does not go to solving the great problems of world trade. For those reasons I believe it has some deficiencies. It is interesting to hear members of the Opposition talk about statements made by the National Farmers Federation, the body which only two years ago raised a large amount of money from Australian farmers, estimated at millions of dollars. In terms of the promotion of agricultural exports-

DEBATE.TITLE: APPOINTMENT OF MINISTERS AND SENATE COMMITTEE SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House urges-
(1) the political party that wins the next and subsequent elections to appoint all Ministers of the Government from the Members of the House of Representatives; and
(2) the Senate to further expand its committee system and to adopt greater powers of investigation and inquiry.

This motion is not designed in any partisan way. It is not designed to give a political advantage to one party, or to allow one party to score political points at the expense of another. I have moved this motion in an attempt to put in place a better administrative system in the Parliament, so that it can more efficiently perform the function expected of it by the public. I bring this motion forward because parliament is simply not doing that. It would be an understatement to say that there is widespread community disillusionment with parliament and parliamentarians of all political persuasions. All honourable members receive that reaction when they go out into the community. The community is not satisfied with the standard of public administration in Australia. As the elected representatives of the people, it is incumbent on us to put in place a more effective and more efficient system.

Most voters believe, when they go to the polls, that they are electing a government. They give no thought to the difference between government and parliament, but in reality there is an enormous difference. Perhaps the roles between government and parliament should be more distinctly defined. In the years since Federation, the distinction between government and Parliament has become blurred by the impact of political parties. No-one could criticise our founding fathers because they were unable to predict the impact that political parties would have on our political structures and, therefore, our structures of public administration. At the time of Federation, political parties were new; they were in their embryo stages, and our founding fathers would simply have been unable to predict their impact. The Executive Government is formed by those appointed as Ministers. The task of the Government is to plan policies and to administer all the departments of state.

On the other hand, the Parliament is made up of all elected members and senators. The role of the Parliament is to legislate laws to scrutinise the functioning of those laws and to monitor the actions of the Government. The Government can make proposals, but only the Parliament can make laws. In theory the Government must be accountable to the Parliament for all of its actions; however, in practice it is the Government that dominates the Parliament. My comments are not a criticism of the present Government or of past governments. It is a fact of political evolution that must be taken into account by the present elected representatives. Though such a state of affairs was never intended by our founding fathers, it has evolved because of the rigid discipline applied by all political parties. The political process has moved markedly from that originally conceived, but at the same time the Public Service has become a very significant power source in its own right. At present 30 Ministers are trying to administer about 200,000 public servants; at the same time they must cope with all the political pressures to which they are exposed. It is little wonder that the Yes Minister syndrome has now become a well-entrenched fact. The public is disillusioned, and who can blame it for that? The standing of our Parliament and its members has never been lower in the public estimation. Parliament is simply not doing what is expected of it by the public. There is a clear need to reform the Parliament and its procedures so that it will reflect modern day political and administrative realities. In framing reforms we must keep in mind the distinctive roles for the government and for the Parliament but we must also bring into sharper focus the different responsibilities carried by the Senate and the House of Representatives. It should also be accepted that the influence and the discipline of the political parties will remain a very firm and fixed political fact of life.
Ministers &Senate Committee System

The function of government is to plan policies that allow the country to run in an orderly and progressive manner. Its further responsibility is to ensure that government policies and the laws of the land are efficiently administered. The Public Service is available to administer government programs but the Public Service has also become increasingly involved in policy planning. There is now a significant policy unit in each government department. The government needs help to administer the Public Service. It is unrealistic to expect one Minister to be accountable for the actions of thousands of public servants while, at the same time, helping to plan government policies and coping with the intense political pressure that Ministers are exposed to.

Parliament must legislate laws and scrutinise government policy and government actions. To fulfil those roles, the Parliament has two Houses-a House of government, which is the House of Representatives, and a House of review, which is the Senate. For legislative purposes each House has equal authority. A proposal cannot become law unless it is passed by both Houses. However, when scrutinising government activity, each House should have distinctly different functions. That was what was intended by the founding fathers but, to a large extent, it is not happening at present. Because of political parties what is decided in the House of Representatives will simply be mirrored and reflected in the Senate when the proposals reach that chamber.

Governments are made and unmade in the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives is the House of government, and it should be the House of government. The House of Representatives comprises members from competing political parties. The ambition of all of those members is to win government. Party allegiance is very powerful in the House of Representatives. It is the discipline exercised by the parties that allows the government of the day to maintain superiority over the Parliament.

The Senate, on the other hand, is the House of review. It has a distinctly different function from the House of government. Its role is to ensure a very thorough scrutiny of government proposals and government activity. In reality, however, the Senate has now become equally dominated by party allegiances. The Senate takes on political significance only when the Government party does not have control of a majority of senators. If the Government party does have control of a majority of senators, then proposals of political significance in the House of Representatives will simply be rubberstamped or mirrored when they reach the Senate.

Added to that, a number of Ministers are also drawn from the Senate. Unfortunately, the Senate has now become an extension of the House of government rather than a distinct House of review. The Senate committee system is much more extensive than that of the House of Representatives, but the outcome in the Senate will reflect the decisions made in the House of Representatives. The systems need to be changed so that each House fulfils a distinct and different function. The House of government needs to be distinctly different from the House of review. The House of Representatives must be the House where the Government and the alternative Government parade their policies and give public expression to them.

The committee system of the House of Representatives should be structured so as to assist the parties to gather facts and information that will be helpful in determining policies for the future. That is not to say that the House of Representatives should determine those policies; nor should it be the Public Service that determines them. Rather, the structures of the House should be designed in a way that will allow the political parties to gather facts and information so that they, within their philosophies, can put together policies so that the public can judge competing policies when elections are being held. The rules of the House should also be changed, but not in great structure, because each political party, Government and Opposition, should have equal opportunities to present their policies to the public so that the public can then make a reasonable assessment and judgment of those policies.

To ensure that the House of Representatives is a genuine House of government all Ministers should be drawn from the House of Representatives. The Senate should have no Ministers. The Leader of the Government in the Senate should be a member of the Executive Council, but without portfolio responsibility. The structures of the Senate should be changed to give much greater emphasis to its review process. Not only proposed legislation should be reviewed, but also the functioning of past legislation and the general efficiency of government administration. It is an unfortunate fact that we in this Parliament pass many laws but we do not have the capacity to go back and review their efficiency and functioning. It may well be that programs that were put in place five, 10 or 15 years ago are still in place within the Public Service structures but may no longer be appropriate to modern day community living. We should have a structure within our Parliament to be able to go back and look at past programs and laws to see whether they are still appropriate for contemporary Australia.

I am suggesting that it is through a restructured and much upgraded Senate committee system that we should have that capacity. At the moment the only way that past legislation can be reviewed is if the Government decides to reintroduce it into the Parliament. That is not good enough. The Senate, through its review process, should have much wider powers and a much wider capacity to review past legislation and programs.

Much more emphasis should be given to the Senate committees. The committees should be geared so as to review constantly all departments, as well as the programs and legislation for which the departments are responsible. I am suggesting that the Senate committees should have the power to review the efficient administration of the Public Service departments because, so often, public servants are hidden in the cloisters of departments of state with one Minister being responsible for their administration. We cannot expect one Minister to know what those thousands of public servants are doing. I am suggesting that the Senate committees should have the power to go into departments to see whether they are operating efficiently in an administrative sense, and, if they are not operating efficiently and to the satisfaction of those Senate committees, the Senate ought to report that fact to the Parliament.

The Senate committees should also have the power to subpoena documents, witnesses and Ministers and the power to take evidence under oath. No area of government activity should be exempt from Senate scrutiny. I know that people will be aghast at this proposal to give a committee of the Parliament the power to subpoena a Minister to appear before it. But it happens in other countries, in particular in the United States of America. I see no reason, if we are to make this Parliament perform the function that the public expects of it, not to give that power to committees of the Senate. I think it would play a very large role in improving the efficiency of public administration in Australia.

In summary, I bring this proposal forward not in any attempt to criticise the present Government or any past governments in Australia but as a proposal that as elected representatives we consider trying to improve the efficiency of the administration of the institution for which we are responsible, to make parliament and the process of government and the process of public administration more efficient, more appropriate to what the public expects so that the public can have more confidence in the administrations that they have representing their interests. At this stage we should all accept that parliaments and governments have never had lower esteem with the public. I think it incumbent on all of us as elected representatives to apply our minds to put together a much more efficient and appropriate system of public administration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I believe the major function of the motion is the opening up of debate something like 90 years after the first debates which established the basic rules under which this Parliament has operated during the entire time since Federation. An unfortunate consequence of the contract which was reached at the time of Federation was that the parliament that was adopted was entrenched in an almost ironclad Constitution which it has not been possible to re-examine or adapt to meet the changes that have taken place in society, government and responsibilities since Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: The only major change which has taken place in the relationship between the Houses and the way in which they function took place in the 1940s when the system of election to the Senate was changed to proportional representation. This guaranteed that some balance between the major political parties would be evident in that House. Prior to that an almost farcical situation existed in the Senate wherein one party had all but a handful of the senators in the chamber.

When this Parliament was established it was established by an Act of the British Parliament. All of those who had an involvement in the preparation for Federation were persons whose major experience was with a Westminster style parliament. But even with that background, and with the Minister of the day in the British Parliament determined that the Parliament in Australia should reflect the British experience, we did not in fact adopt a Westminster style parliament; we adopted a Westminster style government, which is quite different. We adopted the basic rules and privileges which existed in the British law at that time. However, we adopted a parliament which took for the House of Representatives the House of Commons structure and the system of government of Great Britain as had operated in that chamber at the time of the passage of the Constitution Bill. We did not adopt a House of Lords, be it by appointment by the colonies-now the States-or by some other form of appointment or tenure. We adopted the American Senate as the model for the second chamber of this Parliament and the strictures which have existed since Federation have prevented the evolvement of what was expected to be a quite different chamber of the Parliament from taking place.

I do not think that anyone should seriously consider that the passage of a motion such as this will bring about the evolution in our Parliament which we now have the opportunity to commence. Not only are there constitutional constrictions on parliaments; there are physical constrictions. The Federal Parliament spent 27 years in temporary accommodation and has now spent 60 or 70 years in this building. We are about to embark with a totally new set of criteria. The new Parliament House has had built into it facilities for functions which were impossible in this building and it is incumbent upon us, and I suggest the members of the Senate, to look at the way in which we conduct our affairs to see whether they can be better conducted.

There is no way in which the House of Representatives can be changed from what it is. It is the House where the acquisition of a majority of members to support a particular ministry is necessary, and necessary to be continuous, in order for government to take place. There is no justification or reason for the Senate to ape or imitate that system while putting forward some pretence of having a superior ability to do it because its members do not have direct electoral responsibility in the same way as occurs with members of the House of Representatives.

Some years ago there was fairly wide discussion about changes in the relationships between the Houses. In the early 1970s resolutions were prepared by the Standing Orders Committee of this House which would have enabled Ministers from this House to appear in the Senate in order to answer questions raised with them by senators. That was a first step towards a parliamentary, as opposed to a house, system of government. It did not get past first base because of the campaign by those people who saw what was good enough in 1900 as the be all and end all of all examination and all operations of the Parliament into the future. I believe the Senate would be enhanced if it were not the second chamber of government but rather the chamber of the Australian Parliament which examined the way in which government operated, which carried out substantial inquiries not inhibited by the presence of Ministers and its role as a government chamber.

I think it is important that a serious and real examination of the manner in which we conduct our affairs should take place. I reiterate what I said before: This motion is not an attack on a chamber; it is an attempt to revitalise a debate which started 20 years ago and which died on the altar of the lack of interest and the protection of the status quo. The Parliament should examine itself on a regular basis. It should examine how it can better perform the changing functions that now exist as compared with those which were envisaged: because there was no parliamentary experience in Australia at the time of Federation. A change took place in the 1970s when the Senate set up a committee system. That committee system is now looking old, tired and almost irrelevant. Senators find it an imposition to have to serve on more committees than they can devote themselves to. It is time we examined the present system and the move to the new Parliament House makes it imperative that we do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a rare occasion when this House has the opportunity to look at the relationship between the two Houses of the Parliament in a dispassionate way. On most occasions when that occurs it is in the heat of some major contentious issue. We have a worthwhile opportunity today to look at this, and I congratulate the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) for raising the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: From the earliest discussions of the possible role of the Australian Senate, it has been held by liberals-those of the more philosophic variety, not to be confused with those opposite-that the Senate as contemplated was undemocratic. The conservative position, regarding the Senate as a body that would protect the society against the rise to power of the hotheads of the lumpenproletariat, is one which still has currency. Today it is quite obvious that the philosophic distinctions have become somewhat muddied and the contemporary apologists for the Senate are to be found in superabundance on both sides of politics. Their motives might differ, but they are there, nevertheless, and the justification for the Senate as a necessary entity of constitutional politics in Australia is now very rarely debated seriously.

The role or function of the Senate is also dealt with only occasionally and even then in a rather narrow context. Occasionally this function becomes the subject of very bitter and acrimonious debate. We on this side of the House will never forget the events of 1975, which simply illustrate the problem we encounter.

The relationship between the Senate's function and that of the House of Representatives, in practice and in theory, is clouded by rhetoric, by self-interest, by State paranoia and, unfortunately, by unexamined precedent. The more conservative elements among those Constitutional Convention delegates of the 1890s saw the role of the Senate very precisely. Crisp, on page 175 of the Parliamentary Government of the Commonwealth of Australia, says:
These sought for the Commonwealth a States House which would also constitute a bulwark for property and the established social order.

As my colleague the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) indicated, we derived our lower House from the House of Commons and our upper House largely from the American Senate, but farther back the notion of having to have an upper House was again from the House of Commons. It was also recognised that the Senate should not be accorded the same status as the House of Representatives because senators are more indirectly elected than members of the House and, therefore, senators are less representative than members because they do not face the people as directly in elections to be judged on their own merit and record.

Senators are, in fact, required to face the people, which is different from the system that was discussed before Federation. The fact that they are elected from a State-wide electorate does, for all practical purposes, remove them from the direct and ongoing scrutiny of electors. There was an assumption that senators would have considerable latitude to engage in debate outside the restraints imposed by party discipline, but such a view was not held universally, even if the Senate was referred to, hopefully, as the States House and the House of review. My celebrated and illustrious predecessor in the seat of Ballarat, Alfred Deakin, saw this with quite remarkable clarity. I quote once again from Crisp at page 177. He quotes Alfred Deakin as saying:

The contentions in the Senate or out of it, and especially any contention between the two Houses, will not and cannot arise from questions in regard to which States will be ranked against States . . .
He says further:
Contests between the two Houses will only arise when one party is in possession of a majority in the one Chamber and the other in possession of a majority in the other Chamber . . .
Further he says:

The contest will not be, never has been, and cannot be between States and States . . . It is certain that once this Constitution is framed it will be followed by the creation of two great national parties.

I suppose the coalition falls roughly into that category. This was Deakin's very acute observation in 1891. In fact, there was considerable divergence of opinion on the role, status and functions of the Senate. What is true, though, in practice is that the Senate became, and still is, a tool of party politics. Its desire to act as either a States House or as a House of review is based on a rather archaic and romantic but quite erroneous perception. Senators are, by and large, preselected by their party machines and are rarely known in a non-party context by many citizens. This contrasts with the position of members of the House of Representatives who, while also chosen by their respective party machines, as a rule must run the gauntlet of local electorate examination.

It is in respect of the appointment of a person to replace a senator who has resigned or died that we see the difference in the relationship between a member of the House of Representatives and a member of the Senate. Without entering into the details of procedures to be adopted as specified in chapter I, part II, the Senate, section 15 of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia as amended by the Constitution Alteration (Senate Casual Vacancies) Act 1977, let me say that such a person need not be elected by the people of the State but rather appointed by the Governor of the State. It is, therefore, not so much to the individual electors that such a person is directly responsible but to that body called the State. Such is not the position should a member of the House of the Representatives resign or die. The replacement member shall be chosen at a by-election as stated under section 33 of the Constitution. It is in part IV that the functions of the Houses are spelt out and it is here that the source of so much disputation exists. It is, for instance, clear that there is a legislative distinction between the House of Representatives and the Senate. This applies in particular to section 53, which states inter alia:
Proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys, or imposing taxation, shall not originate in the Senate.

Further, section 53 imposes strict exemptions to its powers in respect to the above such matters, that is, the powers of the Senate. It is worth recording once again the details of this section. I do not want to go through it all, but it does impose major restraints upon the powers of the Senate. So it is also in that section that a point of major dispute about the powers that ought to reside in the Senate arises. The final paragraph of section 53 states:
Except as provided in this section, the Senate shall have equal power with the House of Representatives in respect of all proposed laws.

It seems that, in effect, where the behaviour of the Senate is concerned there is a conflict built into section 53, and in this section and in section 57 the confusion of functions can be seen. All of this derives from the role of the Senate as the House of review. The questions we should ask ourselves are whether the House of review should have the power to reject or simply defer Bills, as is the case with the House of Lords; and, secondly, if it should have such a power, whether this sits well with the functions of representative government. We need to address both of these questions because it is quite possible that the assumed powers of the Senate, in theory, conflict with the role some senators have as Ministers of the Crown, of the Government. That is the point that the honourable member for Lyons makes. At present they are required not only to debate legislation and review it, but to act as Ministers of the Government at the same time. There is a confusion of roles. It seems to be a confusion of roles for a senator, as a Minister, to introduce a Bill, which certainly happens, and to advocate its smooth passage as its protagonist when, according to one interpretation of the Senate's function, he or she should be reviewing legislation.

The reality is that the roles of the two Houses overlap, and it is here that we might question the fittingness of such an arrangement. The duality of the Senate's functions as a House of government and a House of review certainly presents some conflict of roles, and because the Senate never really fulfilled its function as a States House but rapidly became a party House it is simply an extension of the House of Representatives, but with a major difference-parties, because of the vagaries of the Senate electoral system, can frustrate the will of government even though the people elected a party of the House of Representatives to be the Government.

I agree with the motion: it is inappropriate for the Senate to be both a House of Representatives and a House of the States and of review. Changes to the Constitution ought to be made, first, by changing the powers of the Senate to reduce its power to frustrate the will of the House of Representatives, the people's House, the House of government, by removing from the Senate the power to defeat legislation; and, secondly, by requiring that all Ministers-that is, the Government-be members of the House of Representatives. The added benefit of such a change would be to ensure that Ministers, that is, the Government, are all elected in the same way and are responsible in a more direct way to the will of the more closely defined electorate, and it would also mean that the Senate would have more clearly defined functions as well. It could act as a House of review and it could have the most appropriate committee system, although I doubt whether for all practical purposes it could break away from the party structure and become a States House.

Some might well suggest that there are no particular virtues in the proposition that there should be a States House, anyway. They might well claim that the concept of a States House is not just anachronistic but positively destructive in that it poses divided and divisive loyalties for both politicians and private citizens. That, however, is another issue. I wish to lend my support to this motion.
Debate (on motion by Mr Scott) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House advises His Excellency the Governor-General that the arrangements for the opening of future Sessions of the Parliament, whether after the dissolution of the House of Representatives or the prorogation of a Session, should be altered to remove all elements which place the House of Representatives in an inferior position to the Senate and, in particular, that-

(1) the declaration of the opening of a Parliament by a Deputy appointed by the Governor-General and the speech of the Governor-General on the occasion of the opening of a Parliament be delivered in the Members Hall or the appropriate equivalent in the new Parliament House; and
(2) all parliamentary arrangements for the formal opening be the joint responsibility of both Houses.

This motion does not have the potentially far-reaching consequences of the motion we have just been debating. The moving of this motion at this time is designed to address a situation which has no relevance at all to the functions of this Parliament and to accept the opportunity presented by the different facilities which will be available to the Parliament in the new Parliament House. The arrangements for the formal opening of Parliament are those which exist in the British Parliament, and they reflect a totally different parliamentary structure from the one that exists in Australia-a structure which has embodied in it a second-class role for the members of the House of Representatives.

The origin of the present ceremonies and the delivery of the speech from the throne goes back into British history. It does not have a parallel in Australian history. There has never been a House of Lords in Australia and there has never been a king's or queen's council, an advisory body which exists in the United Kingdom today and has existed since prior to the development of a House of Commons, which came into existence to place a brake on the excesses of the Crown and the Crown's advisers, namely, the barons of England.

We still go through a ceremony at the opening of our Parliament in which the members of this chamber do not enjoy equal status with the members of the Senate, and the members of the Senate allow themselves the luxury of the pretence that by some means they are the successors to the king's council of a day gone by. The President of the Senate is not the Lord Chancellor. He is the President of an elected chamber of the Australian Parliament. The Speaker of this Parliament is not a minion subservient to the barons of England, to be summoned before the bar of the Senate to sit at the end of the table and be lectured. The Speaker of this Parliament should have equal status in all things, including the opening of the Parliament, as should the members of this House with the members of the Senate.

It is an illusion of grandeur and a pretence that an elected House of this Parliament is in some way parallel to the House of Lords in England. There are not many members on this side of the Parliament-I do not know about the other side-who would mind if the Senate declared itself to be parallel to the House of Lords. Accepting that position, I would even give them life tenure if they want it. They could vegetate over there for ever. The House of Lords no longer has any powers whatsoever over the decisions of government. That is what they want; that is what the evolution of the British system has brought about today. The Budget can be passed without even being referred to the House of Lords, and certainly it is no longer necessary for it to be passed.

To deal with the motion: we will move to a new Parliament House in the next six months. It has facilities which have never been available in this House and so we have never been presented with the opportunity to really examine what is in fact the role of the two chambers. I inform the people who do not know what goes on here at the opening of Parliament that the members of this chamber sit and wait to be summoned, like schoolboys, by the Usher of the Black Rod to attend in the Senate to have a proclamation read to them. Why can the proclamation not be read in the Great Hall? In fact, why could it not always have been read in King's Hall? The motion mentions the Members Hall or more suitable accommodation. That does now exist. If the Governor-General can appoint one deputy, he can appoint two deputies. He does that on occasions for the swearing-in ceremony. The message is 50 seconds long. That is no great hardship and I am sure that the judges of the High Court of Australia are all able to read for that length of time.

The motion calls for a change in the arrangements whereby at the opening of Parliament all members are summoned and all senators are summoned to attend the reading of the proclamation. They are then requested to return to their chambers and elect their Presiding Officers. I would envisage that the representative of the Crown-or the Crown itself-would read the speech from the throne in the Great Hall of the new Parliament, with the Presiding Officers seated appropriately beside the representative of the Crown, and that members and senators would be given equal status within that ceremony. I understand that if this motion is carried there will be an amendment to refer it to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not like its chances there.

—I am aware of the grandeur and pretence of the House of Lords. But I hope that if the Senate decides it is not prepared to accept equality between the Houses, it is at least prepared to accept that it should change its role and become the barons of England and not a representative House pretending to be something that it is not.
—Order! Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather noteworthy that there is such an ecumenical spirit in the House today, and quite clearly it is based on a fairly firm conviction as to the merits of the proposition that the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) has put to the House. He has done so on a thoroughly informed basis and has been most persuasive. I would be surprised if any thinking member in the House found reason to differ with his proposition that the Houses of this Parliament should be at least of equal status. I would like to think that in due time the House will, in a manifest way, support the proposition. But I believe, as foreshadowed by the honourable member for Corio, that the motion as it is put in the first instance invites a further qualification. I therefore move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following words be added to the motion:
``; and that a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it take similar action''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion moved today by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), and I recognise the contribution of the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar). There is often criticism that there is too much division between the Government and the Opposition of this country. But those who are listening to this debate would be delighted to know that there are many members in the chamber from both sides who support the proposition, such as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), my colleague the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), who is a very hard working member, the honourable member for Wide Bay, the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) and my colleague the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins). There is a good mood of support for this proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a couple of quick observations in support of my colleague the honourable member for Corio, who himself has been a Speaker of this House, and the honourable member for Wide Bay who has been Chairman of Committees. They have a good understanding of both the relationship between the House of Representatives and the Senate and our obligations to the Australian community. This motion is put with a great awareness of that responsibility. In practical terms the motion means that if on our move to the new Parliament House this ceremony is to be conducted in the Great Hall we can have a far greater assemblage of the public, and that is something that attracts my interest, and certainly that of other members of this House. If we were to make that change we would be saying to the senators that we are not above them, but we are simply equal partners in the process of policy making.

TALK.START.PARA: —The galleries would be full.

—We could have the galleries filled in the Great Hall. If people think intelligently about that, I am sure they will recognise that that would be a great gesture towards the Australian community, which is already very interested in this event. It will be a very significant event in the history of this country. But it will also tap into something else. I am happy to pick up this theme mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Corio. There is a mood of Australian nationalism, not rampant nationalism but properly thought through pride in the Australian community, and we, as an Australian Parliament, ought to be supporting that mood. One of the pleasures that I have as a member of this chamber is to be part of that process of making decisions on behalf of the Australian community and supporting the community's pride in its country.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is really part of the recognition of that. It recognises that arrangements were struck at the time of the writing of the Constitution, but we now say that those arrangements do not reflect the new mood in Australia. They in fact reflect the mood, as my colleague has said, of England at the time the arrangements were struck there. But in the Australian community today we, as members of the House of Representatives, feel that we are equal to those in the Senate. I am happy to support this motion. I believe that those in the Australian community who are listening to this debate will gain some confidence from the thought that we are bipartisan in this approach. I respond to the intelligent remarks of the honourable member for Wide Bay. I believe that if we were to make this move more people could witness the opening of Parliament in the Great Hall of the new House, and I am sure they would take great pride in that event.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: New South Wales Election-Cronulla-Sutherland Rugby League Football Team-National Surf-lifesaving Championships-Buy Australian Campaign-Tourism-Economy-Social Justice Strategy-Railway Track Defects-The Late Mr Kevin Hooper, MLA-International Fund for Ireland-Organised Crime

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate because last weekend was remarkable for three separate events in the electorate of Cook. In the first place, and of great interest to this House, I feel sure, the Liberal Party of Australia won all four seats within the Sutherland Shire in the New South Wales State election on Saturday last, 19 March. In the St George area, it won the seats of Earlwood and Georges River and held the seat of Hurstville, leaving the Australian Labor Party only the former Premier's seat in Rockdale and the seat of Kogarah, which remains doubtful. Not only do the Liberals now hold seven of the nine seats in the St George-Sutherland area, but the seven young men who hold these seats are of outstanding quality and each one of them will be an adornment to the New South Wales Parliament and to the parliamentary process in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The three who were re-elected were Malcolm Kerr in Cronulla, Ron Phillips in Miranda and Guy Yeomans in Hurstville. All were returned with vastly increased majorities which reflected not only the Statewide swing, but also the appreciation of their electorates for the tremendous work each of them has done during his first four years. The new members in the area are Allan Andrews in Heathcote, Chris Downy in Sutherland, Phillip White in Earlwood, and Terry Griffiths in Georges River. I still have confidence that Stephen Milgate can get up and win Kogarah. If he does not this time, he will next time.

The relativity of these results to this Parliament lies in the clear warning they give to the Australian Labor Party that, irrespective of what money it puts into the next campaigns for the seats of Hughes, Barton, St George and Banks, the Liberals are going to win the lot. The clear message of this Liberal resurgence in southern Sydney is that the people of southern Sydney have had enough of Tammany Hall-type politics. They have shown that they are concerned about the quality of their representation and they achieved this in seven out of the nine electorates in the Sutherland and St George districts last Saturday. This is a dramatic change from 1981 when the Labor Party held all nine of those seats. I do not intend to take up too much time of the House in discussing this remarkable situation but it should be borne in mind that it comes as a clear illustration that middle Australia rejected the Labor Party throughout New South Wales and will do so next time this Federal Parliament goes to the people, because, essentially, the same group of the Labor Party is controlling this Federal Parliament as controls the New South Wales Labor Party and the now former Labor Government.

I do not wish to sound as if I have a political prejudice in this regard, but I am delighted with the results and I am confident that the State of New South Wales under the leadership of Nick Greiner, a man of great personal integrity, and his team will bring a long absent honour and integrity to public life in New South Wales. As a New South Welshman in this House, I have grieved at the reputation which my State has gained throughout the rest of Australia during the past 12 years. The canker of corruption within the law, the chaos that exists within the health services and the lack of direction, that is, political direction, in education, have been monstrous obstacles to my State. Let me assure this House that all this will change under this new State Liberal Government; but I suspect that as the new Ministry come to grips with individual portfolios, it is going to take a long and sustained effort to put things right. I wish Nick Greiner and his team the success they deserve and to which the State of New South Wales is at long last entitled.

Though this is a grievance debate, I have no intention of grieving for any of the eight defeated Labor Ministers, nor do I find myself grieving at the loss of Premier Unsworth from his position. Let their fate be a warning to all the Ministers in this place and in the remaining Labor-run States throughout Australia. I do grieve for the mess in which the State of New South Wales finds itself after 12 awful years of Wran and Unsworth-led socialist governments. I will use another opportunity of the House to discuss the mini-series of lectures we received last week from the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) on the role and significance of polls. Though I have a grievance with what he said, I shall not waste the time of the House today on that subject.

On a somewhat different note, the second and third matters concerning the Cook electorate last weekend were both of a sporting nature. In the first case, we had the great pleasure of seeing the Cronulla-Sutherland Rugby League team notch up its first win for the 1988 season-a cause for great celebration.
