As an avid supporter of that club, I congratulate the team and wish it well for the rest of the season. I am confident it will finish among the top five clubs at the end of the year.

The third great event we had in my electorate over the weekend was, of course, the national surf-lifesaving championships. This is Australia's largest annual sporting event in so far as the number of sporting participants is concerned. It is my great pleasure to note that these are the third national championships to be held in my electorate while I have been the Federal member. The first was in 1968 at North Cronulla, which was distinguished by the attendance of Prime Minister Gorton. He thereby became the first Prime Minister to ever have attended a national surf-lifesaving championship. Other Prime Ministers, but not all, have followed his lead since then. John Gorton's visit to that 1968 carnival will long live in the memories of those who were there and closely associated with that great carnival. He found time to have a surf during the carnival, which added great interest and some amusement. The second time our district hosted a national championship was in 1981, when the Wanda club did an absolutely magnificent job staging what is now regarded as one of the finest national surf championships Australia has ever seen.

This year, as part of the bicentennial, the Surf Life Saving Association of Australia agreed for the carnival to be held at Wanda Beach again, but under the joint sponsorship of the four clubs in my electorate, namely Cronulla, North Cronulla, Elouera and Wanda. What a splendid four days it turned out to be. I thank the national president of that association, Alan Whelpton AM, national executive director Gus Staunton MBE, and the Australian Championship group of the Surf Life Saving Association of Australia for having allocated the bicentennial carnival to my four clubs. His Excellency, the Governor of New South Wales, Air Marshal Sir James Rowland said in a foreword to the official program:

How appropriate it is that the Sutherland Shire Beaches have been chosen for this year's Australian Surf Life Saving Championships. Just across the sand dunes in Botany Bay is where Captain Cook landed, and later in 1788 where Governor Phillip first dropped anchor before going on to Port Jackson to proclaim New South Wales.

I agree with his remarks. For the information of honourable members it should be known that more than 4,000 surf-lifesavers competed at these championships, each one of whom had undertaken his or her beach patrol obligations and passed his or her annual proficiency test. The significance of this national sporting championship is that it is a national sporting championship of active Australian lifesavers who go each weekend to serve the surfing public. The championship was a great success. I offer my congratulations to all the medal winners.

The local organising committee was chaired by my good friend Bill Stafford. The secretary was another good friend, Alan Cameron, as are treasurer Doug Bruce, and Shirley Cameron, who acted as assistant secretary to Alan. I congratulate them on having achieved such success after having worked so tirelessly since 1985 when it was first known we were to have the championship at Wanda. My thanks and deep appreciation also go to the 40 members of the organising committee, who worked so diligently for so long.
It is also appropriate to thank the major sponsors-Kelloggs, Cadbury-Schweppes, Speedo, Ansett and BP. The national president, Alan Whelpton, said:
This kind of support by the sponsors allowed the SLSA to display the life saving skills of our members at no cost to the public.

I thank the Sutherland Shire Council, which has been a very active and generous supporter of surf-lifesaving clubs for generations, for its continued generous involvement. On this occasion, it was helped substantially by the locally-based transportation company, Rapid Transport, which I also acknowledge.

In conclusion I should like to offer my personal congratulations to outstanding lifesavers Warren Rennie of North Cronulla Club and Bill Marshall of Cronulla Club who were among seven great men who have served the Surf Life Saving Association well and who were presented with their life membership badges at this carnival. I thank all those who were involved. I just wish that more members of this House had been able to attend what is a distinctly Australian sporting activity, essentially of amateur sports people around the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members would be aware, for some time I have been personally concerned with the Buy Australian campaign and the need for the campaign to be promoted broadly. From time to time I have drawn attention to examples of positive and less than positive activity in this regard. Today I wish to make mention of a number of matters that cause me both pleasure and concern in relation to the Buy Australian campaign and the need for Australians to show a preference for Australian-made products.

SPEECH.PARA: On many occasions I have indicated my view that many problems have been due in part to lack of packaging and marketing skills on the part of Australian enterprises. I remember drawing to the attention of the House an example of a particular cheese brand, Geramont, which for all intents and purposes looks like a European imported cheese-it has a French or German sounding name-but is a high quality Australian-made cheese. I criticised this company for not having applied to license the product as an Australian-made product. I am pleased to say that it has now done so.

When people look for this brand in the supermarket, they will now see on it the green Australian made label which depicts a kangaroo. There is just one problem: it is stacked on the supermarket shelves horizontally. The logo is on the top of the packet, so that when people look at the supermarket shelves the logo is hidden because the packets are stacked one on top of the other. So while we are making progress, some thought must be given to the way in which products are presented.

That leads me to the other side of the story. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you come from central Victoria and would be most interested in this matter. I draw the attention of the House to a small firm named Kyneton Fine China which has been established in Kyneton in my electorate. It is making beautiful handcrafted and very precise fine china products such as the little penguin I have here with me in a package. It is developing an exclusive market for both local and international buyers. Its products are of a very fine quality of which we can all be proud. The most important thing is that the company has researched the tourist market. It has seen that Japanese tourists in particular have complained that they cannot get high quality, very fine precision work. The firm has realised that the Japanese are looking for products which can be packaged and taken home without fear of their being damaged in the plane. It has gone to the trouble of providing fine quality boxes, packing the product in foam, and supplying authentication certificates. The firm has properly researched the sorts of things that need to be done to produce a high quality product that tourists coming to Australia will want to buy and for which they will pay a good price. I want to draw the attention of the House to that comparison and I congratulate Kyneton Fine China.

The principal point I want to make today will cause some controversy. I draw attention to an article in this morning's Sydney Daily Telegraph which refers to plans of the Government to allow Swissair Pty Ltd to fly additional flights into Australia but not to allow those flights into Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. A decision like this has been too long coming, in my opinion. Many people want to travel to Australia. We are trying to present ourselves as a high quality tourist destination, yet we have the absurd nonsense of flights from places such as Hong Kong and Singapore having to leave at midnight in order to arrive in Australia at 6 o'clock in the morning after the curfew at Sydney Airport. Of course, there is congestion resulting from that. I believe that we have to take a much more rational approach to the use of our airports and facilities. It is time that the international operators-not only Qantas Airways Ltd but others-took a good hard look at scheduling many more flights to arrive in Australia at Tullamarine Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could fix up Sydney.

—The honourable member interjects that we could fix up Sydney. Sydney Airport has been a problem for a long time. There is talk about additional runways and that sort of thing. A plan is on deck to build a second airport in Sydney. While all that takes place we have major airports in Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth which have facilities available 24 hours a day. I believe a lot more flights should use those airports. We have the infrastructure at Tullamarine Airport particularly to develop a fully fledged aviation industry. We also have the infrastructure to develop a bigger and better freight zone. Because that airport was planned later, everything has been tied together. The highways from Sydney and Adelaide converge, and there is also the planned new R5 freeway. There are close links to the railway and to the dockyards.

SPEECH.PARA: There is every opportunity for us to develop the area around Tullamarine Airport as a major trade zone for Australia. I have to say that in many other countries it is quite a common practice for an aircraft to be diverted, for instance, from Los Angeles to San Francisco, which for the international traveller is only an hour down the road, so to speak. It is quite common now for people to arrive at an airport and take an internal commuter plane up the coast to their final destination. Perhaps if we were to merge Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines, we would be able to take that further by scheduling some of these things so that we made much better use of those airport facilities. It is essential, in my view, if we are going to develop fully the commercial prospects of the growing areas around central Victoria-Ballarat, Bendigo-and if we are going to exploit the opportunities being presented to us by the companies such as Kyneton Fine China, to look at a much more rational approach.

So, for all those reasons, I am foreshadowing my own view that while we go about the process of trying to get in place a second airport at Sydney, and while we are now acknowledging that while the curfew stays in place, and that is the wish of the people around the area, those resources are no longer suitable; they are not assisting Australia in developing its full potential as a high quality tourist destination. I am suggesting that both within the Government, and certainly within the operations in the management of the major airport operators and, I guess, for the interest of the Federal Airports Corporation, they will have my support for every step that is taken to better utilise the opportunities that are available at Tullamarine.

I guess, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am foreshadowing my grievance that we are putting the pressure on organisations and companies. We met with the National Farmers Federation last week and talked about this very issue of the packaging and marketing of Australian made products. As we do more of this, as we encourage more tourism to Australia and as we embrace the world better as a trading partner, then it is essential that we use these airports and our infrastructure in a way that fully develops the potential. In my view, Tullamarine Airport, which is under-utilised by at least 40 per cent, represents a prime opportunity and should be further explored as an option.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —After more than five long years in government, the defence of blaming the previous Government for the shortcomings of the present Government and our present economic malaise is wearing more than a little bit thin. In fact, Madam Deputy Speaker, the ploy is as threadbare as the mental processes bedevilling the Hawke-Keating Government as it looks for some new and better scapegoats in the wake of dismal outcomes and of its commensurately dismal economic management. It is a compelling indictment of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in particular, because it is increasingly difficult, I must say, to take the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seriously these days.

SPEECH.PARA: For the Treasurer to have to confuse present needs and future directions with the events of over five and up to 12 years ago shows that the pressure from the Australian Labor Party factions, his prime ministerial ambition and inability to make timely and correct decisions, and the pressures of his office, have made him somewhat of a toothless tiger; in fact, I would say, a fiscal eunuch. In his desperation, the Treasurer dredges out the same drivel he was peddling when this Government came to office over five years ago. On the rare occasions he gets down to questions and problems that only he and his Government can answer and resolve, the technique he uses is to cite a single statistic and build a story or prophecy around it. If for the time being there is no statistical straw to grasp at-and there have been many such occasions-it then becomes necessary, it seems, to dig up some obscure forecast, usually published overseas, which may only in part be flattering of Australia's economic prospects.

In earlier days it might have been Moody's assessment but that was before it relegated us from our AAA credit rating which, I might say, was diligently earned and jealously protected before the present Government was elected. Even Gough Whitlam's Government could not achieve that doubtful honour. Sometimes the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) is selectively quoted. The uninformed do not generally realise that OECD figures and predictions merely parrot information from the Treasurer himself. Making use of the OECD material is just another fine example of the chicanery and deceptions being practised on this Parliament and the people of Australia.

The confidence trick practised by the Treasurer when he selects a particular statistical indicator is, of course, as varied as the numbers of indicators published. The House does not need to be told that there are hundreds of economic statistics and indicators published every month, so there are plenty of opportunities to indulge in that sort of political trickery. How many times have we heard the Treasurer say something like, `The latest figures for such and such show a favourable trend', or, `The current account deficit is in line with the Budget forecast'. Never mind that the latest figure is the first, and maybe only, lower figure after a series of record highs.

Having been driven to the heights it seems that we are expected to applaud the still outrageously high, and albeit slightly reduced, figure which can by this Treasurer alone be deceitfully interpreted as indicating a new and favourable trend. It is a lot of nonsense. It is absolute nonsense. The Max Walshes of the media are among the few who swallow that line any more. To make a virtue out of our current account deficit being on target with the Budget forecast is equally deliberate deception. Never mind that it will be $10,000m or $11,000m for the year to 30 June. Never mind that that figure is the second or third highest ever and that the only other higher annual deficits were also reached under this Treasurer. Never mind all of that.

The Treasurer would have us stand up and clap for him and his wondrous fiscal achievements. I suppose the need for applause is explainable coming, as it does, from a fiscal eunuch and there is not much else that will please him in that circumstance. But it would be taking charity just too far for us to go along with that sort of rhetorical nonsense. To go along with and condone what is, in effect, plea bargaining with the voting public by the Treasurer would also be to ignore the effects which impinge so seriously on the well-being of all but his wealthiest mates. All the fudging in the world will not obscure the fact that the living standards of low, middle and fixed income earners and their families have fallen dramatically during the terms of this Hawke-Keating Government. It is as simple as that.

Inflation as measured by the consumer price index is in no way an indication of the increased costs of everyday living for families in Australia. That circumstance, along with the tax bracket creep which reduces discretionary income even before hard-earned wages or salaries are spent at supermarkets and petrol stations, is at the very heart of falling living standards. The direct cause is to be found in a combination of deliberate, considered action and inaction of the Hawke-Keating regime. It is to be found, in particular, in the Government's approach to economic management of budget strategy, economic policy, monetary policy, which means, I might say, no stated policy at all, and interest rates.

There also is the Government's conniving with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). Last weekend we witnessed hopeful signs that the voting public has at last seen through the charade. For the Treasurer merely to claim that he has taken the tough decisions to arrest falling living standards is no longer good enough. Getting to a balanced Budget by increasing taxes and letting high inflation and ensuing bracket creep take more billions of dollars out of wage and salary earners' packets and pockets is not a tough decision. It is the opposite. It is the easy way. What is more, the prospect of getting responsible, whether tough or otherwise, decisions from the Treasurer is very, very bleak indeed.

For reasons all too obvious to those observing the Treasurer and his increasingly apoplectic Prime Minister in the chamber these days, ministerial changes to the Cabinet are long overdue. I suggest that the Treasurer should be relieved and made Minister for aspiring to the Prime Ministership. That would give him time to stroke and soothe the factions and the faction leaders and at the same time create an opening for the present de facto Treasurer of Australia, Mr Simon Crean. Alternatively, perhaps, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) could become Treasurer as he has long wanted to be and his present portfolio could be allocated to the de facto Minister for Industrial Relations, who is Mr Bill Kelty, also of the ACTU.

To reach a more serious conclusion, there are ominous signs that the onerous responsibilities of the present Treasurer will become next to nothing while he aspires to please his parliamentary colleagues in his personal push to become Prime Minister. It will be a very sad day indeed for Australia if because of his pursuit of personal popularity the Treasurer does not devote all his time and all his energy to redressing the economic malaise which his Government and his policies have largely created.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I came into the Australian Parliament and spoke for the first time in the House of Representatives the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), was kind enough to say, and I quote him, in reply to my maiden speech:

SPEECH.PARA: I respect the integrity with which he holds a genuine Labor viewpoint. I welcome the prospect of sharpened debate along ideology lines with Labor opponents espousing what I have always understood to be the essence of Labor Party policies.

Those words, of course, are a welcome comment from the Leader of the Opposition when describing my attitude to social reform and to the Australian Labor Party, but they are equally true of the commitment that the Hawke Labor Government has to social reform in its historic third term of office.

I seek in the time available to me to speak on a subject that is not often talked about in the House of Representatives and that is the philosophical differences that exist between the Australian Labor Party and our conservative opponents on the Opposition benches. It is quite clear that the core of the Liberal and National parties' philosophy is that individualism is put on a pedestal but solidarity with disadvantaged groups in society is rejected. As a result of that, injustice obviously increases. Their philosophy is predicated on absolute and uncritical support for the free market opinion moulders who say that people must make it on their own. They say, in essence, the law of the jungle and the survival of the fittest.

We in the Australian Labor Party reject that philosophy and believe that we are, indeed, advanced as a society in our relatively wealthy society and a moral one. We ought to be putting in place social priorities and structures that take us beyond the law of the jungle. It is for that reason, Madam Deputy Speaker, that we have seen evolving in the Australian Labor Party a grand plan, a clear philosophical base to our third term of office which will take us as a Federal Labor Government well into the next decade and to the year 2000.

That strategy, that grand plan, is, of course, the national social justice strategy of the Party and of this Government. That strategy is only just being understood by many people in the media but it will be the main talking point, I believe, about this Government's approach to social reform in the remainder of our term. So it is, therefore, important that his House and the Parliament understand what that social justice strategy is all about. It has been given tangible form by the establishment of a social justice unit in the Prime Minister's Department which will soon be producing a national social justice achievements document that looks to what this Government has achieved already during its period of office and also looks to the future.

Importantly, Federal Labor parliamentarians have adopted a proposition that the pieces of legislation coming before the Labor members and the Caucus ought to have a social justice impact statement attached to the document so we can gauge, as representatives of the people, the impact of that particular legislation in meeting the goals of the Party to implement social justice. Madam Deputy Speaker, it is not an overstatement to say that social justice is the Labor Party's reason for existence. It is the common goal that unites all of us as parliamentarians in the process of social reform. It is truly the major strategic objective of Labor in government. The Australian Labor Party has now held power nationally for four years and during this period Labor has endeavoured to rebuild industry, provide employment, expand the social wage, restore welfare provisions and improve the lives of Australian people, but much more needs to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have failed on each.

—I note, again, the honourable member for Gippsland has interjected. The honourable member for Gippsland, of course, who purports to represent the Victorian establishment, is best known in this chamber as being the rudest, most offensive, young member of Parliament. Many people, of course, in his own Party, believe that he is not really an appropriate person to be representing what was once the party representing rural Australia.
—Order! I must draw to the attention to the honourable member for Hughes that it is against Standing Orders to cast personal reflections on members in this House.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I will hope that you will ensure that the honourable member for Gippsland ceases his intemperate and rude behaviour.
—The honourable member for Hughes can be assured that I will continue to note what members on both sides of the House are saying.

—The Australian Labor Party in its 1986 National Conference unanimously resolved to adopt the national social justice strategy and that strategy involves not only the Federal Labor Government but also the National Executive of the Australian Labor Party, the Federal Caucus, the national policy committees and State branches of the Party. It is a strategy which, I should emphasise, is concerned not only with ideals, but I stress that it is not an impossible list of expenditure items. It argues that a government fully committed to social justice must be tough-minded and committed to achieve it with the resources and organisation it already controls.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. Again it is an example of the sort of rude behaviour I have been referring to that brings the whole Parliament into disgrace. There are four essential elements of the social justice strategy of the Australian Labor Party. They are equity, and that involves a commitment to fairness in the distribution of economic resources in political power; equality, the notion that equal and effective and comprehensive rights for all people are an essential part of modern democracy; and it involves the concept, thirdly, of access, which means that fair and equal access should be accorded to Australians to essential services including health, education and housing. It involves, very importantly, the concept of participation; that Australians should have the opportunity to participate fully in their personal development in social and community life and the decisions which affect their lives. I have a great commitment to that ideal. Having served for many years in local government, I believe that what we ought to be striving for in society is not just triennial ballot box democracy, where we accord to members of Parliament a blank cheque to do what they like, but far greater accountability for members of Parliament and rights to citizens, to Australians, to make decisions and contribute to decisions that affect their everyday lives.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to emphasise that the social justice strategy of this Government is not just about welfare measures. It looks far beyond welfare measures and short term improvements to the principles that govern society. It seeks to broaden the meaning of citizenship by endowing all Australians with certain inviolable rights. It is concerned about outcomes and fair shares, not just about fair rights and opportunities. The social justice strategy of the Party is not something that we see as confined to the members of the Australian Labor Party. It is something that we see as involving the entire Australian population because we believe, in the Australian Labor Party, that as members of Parliament we have enormous rights and responsibilities as members of this Federal Parliament. If we are really serious about achieving social change, about really reforming and improving our society, then what we have to do as a government, and what we will do with our social justice strategy, is to mobilise public opinion and to get the full and participatory support of Australian people in our social justice strategy.

I make two final points: I believe that we have to have concrete objectives. We have to have main points of emphasis in our social justice strategy. I welcome the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government on child poverty but I believe the other main commitment that we ought to rally behind as a Government is the issue of unemployment. That means becoming very involved in a comprehensive policy on investment, retraining and restructuring. I commend the social justice strategy to the Parliament. It is one that strikes at the very heart of Labor's reason for existence. It is our light on the hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the Parliament to a serious but largely unknown public safety issue. It is one with which I would expect you, Madam Deputy Speaker, with your distinguished record as chairperson, or chairman if you will allow me to use the better and more traditional language, of the House of Representatives Transport Safety Committee, to be familiar. I refer to the fact of defects within railway lines. There would be few people who are aware that there are some 5,000 rail track defects detected every year in Australia and that is with only a hopelessly inadequate amount of testing. I will say more of the current testing procedures later.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me start off by outlining the nature of the problem. Information I have to hand leads me to believe that in Victoria there is a fault in the rail track every 1.9 kilometres, on average. For every kilometre of track tested on V-Line there are faults detected every 1.9 kilometres. A breakdown of specifics shows that on the Melbourne-Albury line 248 defects were detected over 307 kilometres of track with a frequency, therefore, of a fault every 1.2 kilometres. On the Mangalore-Toolamba line there were 54 defects over 55 kilometres tested, with a fault frequency of one fault every one kilometre. On the other side of the coin, on the Ararat-Sunshine line there were only four defects over 211 kilometres, meaning a frequency of one fault for every 53 kilometres.

The situation is just as serious, if not more serious, for Metrail which is, of course, Melbourne's rail system. On the Flinders Street-Pakenham line there was a frequency of a fault every one kilometre. On the Camberwell-Alamein line every 0.4 of a kilometre a fault was detected. On the Flinders Street-Sandringham line there was one fault for every one kilometre; on the Spencer Street-Werribee line there was one fault for every two kilometres.

I should say that I have figures for all over Australia and they compare just as unfavourably with what V-Line's figures reveal. It is not surprising that few people have to date expressed much interest in the safety issue of rail lines because the defects are invisible to the naked eye. The splits and fractures are inside the rail and not externally obvious. Madam Deputy Speaker, and again I note your special interest in this area, the testing occurs when a rail-bound car carrying sophisticated ultrasonic equipment as well as computers, locates defects in the rail below it. Australia's technology is equal to the most advanced in the world. Indeed, opportunities for one of the principal operators in this field, Sstech Railway Technology Pty Ltd, are possibly opening up in Malaysia, New Zealand and the United States. Sstech is based in the Latrobe Valley in Victoria and has proposals to construct, to varying sizes, these rail-bound test cars.

The possible establishment of a manufacturing and maintenance plant in the Latrobe Valley has been enthusiastically embraced by local authorities, particularly by the Latrobe Regional Commission. But to what extent would Sstech's services be utilised? On present indications, as well as past indications, precious little. There can be no underestimating the gravity of the problem. In Australia there have been several derailments over the past few years, fortunately though, with relatively few deaths. There is no question that a number of those derailments have been, or should be, attributed to defects in the rail track. It is next to impossible to know with certainty the exact numbers of derailments caused by track defects as the results of internal inquiries are rarely, if ever, made public. It may well have been, Madam Deputy Speaker, a proper reference for your House of Representatives Transport Safety Committee to inquire into. Sadly that Committee, on the resumption of this Parliament following the last election, has been disbanded.

I would submit that the problem of inadequate rail testing and maintenance is so sensitive and revealing that rail authorities will not publish the causes of derailments. The inescapable conclusion is that rail testing in most parts of Australia is appallingly inadequate. In Victoria it is an outright joke. Yet, the safety of the travelling public and crews manning passenger and goods trains is at risk. Annually New South Wales tests for flaws or fatigue in the rail track a total of 16,000 kilometres; Queensland tests a total of something approaching 8,000 kilometres; Australian National Railways, 4,000 kilometres; Tasmania, 500 kilometres; Westrail, the Western Australian railway system, 500 kilometres; and Victoria with all of its tens of thousands of railway kilometres tests a paltry, almost insignificant, 2,500 kilometres. Compare those figures to the mining railways which annually test 19,000 kilometres.

I understand, as would at least all of my colleagues on this side of the House, the need for budgetary restraint by State governments. But increased traffic density, higher axle loads and faster trains make the problem even more serious than before. State governments, particularly the Victorian Government, must afford rail testing a higher priority. Put simply, our rail network is an accident waiting to happen. On the Nullarbor Plain and at Hornsby derailments occurred in the last couple of years and a life was lost in both of those accidents. The Federal Government has a central role to play in addressing this problem; after all, it is Commonwealth grants which directly, or indirectly, fund State railways.

What is needed is a Federal body within the Department of Transport to act out a watchdog role. I do not for a moment suggest yet another quango or statutory authority; far from it. Instead I suggest a realignment or reorganisation within that massive Department to create a central forum that would set standards and would collate information, as well as dispense the new technology in this field. This would go a long way to lessening the danger of undetected faults in the rail line system. The Federal Government cannot run away from its responsibility to correct the failures of the State governments.

Obviously it is not possible ever totally to eliminate the inherent dangers but a lot more could be done that is not being done at present. What price safety? The Victorian Government puts a price of $88,000 only on sophisticated rail testing; $88,000 only was spent last year in testing in this manner. In my own electorate of Gippsland the line between Sale and Melbourne has not been tested for two years. Yet I can only hazard a guess at the number of people who have travelled on that line in that time. This is the State in which the Southern Aurora crash of the late 1960s-from memory Australia's worst rail crash-occurred. One would have thought that the Victorians had more of an appreciation of the dangers of loss of life caused by derailments due to defects in the track than any other State.

The technology for ultrasonic detection of rail flaws or fatigue is available. The latest computerised high-tech equipment is just waiting to be used. All that is needed is to employ this technology. There has to be first a recognition by both Federal and State governments of the seriousness and depth of the problem and, secondly, a reorganisation of priorities within transport departments to allow greater testing for defects. Neither I nor any other rational person in or outside this Parliament wants the loss of life to occur before governments are galvanised into action. For once let us act before the accident actually occurs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today relates to the now obvious blatant victimisation of a former Labor member of the Queensland Parliament by the then Premier of the State, Bjelke-Petersen, and the denial of justice to the member's widow after his tragic death some four years ago. The late Kevin Hooper, MLA, was a fearless campaigner against corruption in my State of Queensland. Recent revelations before the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Queensland have completely vindicated the scores of allegations made by the late Mr Kevin Hooper. It is indeed sad that he is not alive to witness the day to day proceedings of that inquiry. I feel sure that the tangled web of vice now being unravelled would not be better understood by anyone than Kevin Hooper. He has even been denied the `I told you so' that he knew would eventually come.

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 May 1980 the Labor MLA for Archerfield, Kevin Hooper, was involved in a minor car accident while driving home. I was a practising solicitor at that time and was for a long time prior to the accident the Hooper family solicitor and friend. I acted as Mr Hooper's solicitor in the court case which followed the incident. My advice to Kevin, based on a not inconsiderable amount of experience in these matters, was that he could expect to be charged with undue care and attention which in Queensland is an offence under the Traffic Act.

It is important to note at this stage that Mr Hooper was not charged at the time of the accident but some time later by way of summons. The accident attracted a considerable amount of publicity. But while Kevin and I suspected, no one could have known the level of interest shown in the case by people in the highest of places. We now know as a result of the tablings at the Fitzgerald Inquiry of the former Police Commissioner's diaries that the incident attracted the attention of not just the media. Entries in the diary of the now stood-aside Police Commissioner, Sir Terence Lewis, indicate that he phoned that other infamous Queensland knight, Sir Joh, then the Premier of the State, just days after the accident in relation to Mr Hooper's alcohol content.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I seek your ruling as to whether or not the matters being touched upon by the honourable member breach the sub judice rule, as the matters he is referring to are not yet the conclusions of a royal commission under way.

—I would believe that they are not before the court at this stage and therefore are not sub judice. I would like to check on that to be quite accurate. According to the Standing Orders and the Pettifer ruling, I can see no reason why the honourable member should not continue along these lines, but I would caution him that when he makes statements he should in no way prejudice the well-being and rights of people who are before the Fitzgerald Inquiry and who may, in fact, be before a court in the future.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. Incidentally, the blood alcohol level at the time of the accident was .038, less than half the legal limit at the time. On 14 May, the Premier of the State phoned the Queensland Police Commissioner, and I quote from the diary, `Wanting Hooper blood samples safeguarded'. Honourable members should remember that at this stage Hooper had not been charged with any offence and yet the State's top law enforcement officer was asked to safeguard his blood sample by the Premier. That is something which has come out as a result of the diaries and has been the subject of massive publicity in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: According to his own diary, Sir Terence phoned Dr Shaw from the blood bank two days later regarding Hooper. Six days after this and four weeks after the actual accident, Mr Hooper was summonsed and charged with the criminal offence of dangerous driving. He was subsequently convicted, fined $300 and disqualified from driving for six months. The more usual offence of undue care and attention under the Traffic Act would have resulted in a loss of points and a small fine.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I can still distinctly see Kev Hooper leaning across my desk and saying to me, and I quote, `Con, if it was anyone else, do you think they would be doing this?'. Knowing the circumstances of the case, I had to admit that he was being treated differently. On 9 March 1984 after faithfully serving the people of Queensland and the Parliament for a period of 12 years, Kevin Hooper died aged 57 of cancer. What followed was a most pathetic lack of sympathy or compassion shown by Bjelke-Petersen towards Kevin Hooper's widow, Terri. The question of whether Mrs Hooper was entitled to receive a lump sum from the parliamentary superannuation scheme was a subject of much controversy in the months following Kevin's death. The State parliamentary superannuation scheme had been changed not long before his death. At the time parliamentarians had three months to consider transferring to the amended superannuation scheme and many members, including Kevin, had neglected to sign up with the new scheme.

This resulted in a technical anomaly which prevented Mrs Hooper from receiving her lump sum entitlement and a pension. The extent of the anomaly can be seen, Madam Deputy Speaker, by the fact that had Kevin resigned rather than died in office he would have been eligible for a lump sum payment of about $160,000 in 1984 terms and Mrs Hooper would have still been entitled to a pension after his death. But because he died, Mrs Hooper could receive only a pension of about $200 a week. This is despite the fact that Kevin had contributed about $33,000 to the scheme over his 12-year period of service in the Parliament.

Mrs Hooper commented at the time that she would have to live to be some 80 or 90 years before she even got back her husband's contributions, at the rate of pension she was being paid. So ridiculous was the anomaly that the then Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, and now member for Capricornia, in this place, Mr Keith Wright, urged State parliamentarians to sign undated letters of resignation to avoid the anomaly which would arise if they died in office.

Kevin Hooper was not a wealthy man. He was described as having very long arms and very short pockets when it came to donating his money to charity. He left a large family for Terri to feed and their small house is in the Brisbane working class suburb of Inala. Despite representations from the Opposition, the community and the church, the Premier stood firm and repeatedly insisted that nothing could be done, that the rules could not be bent in the slightest to get around this obvious flaw. In the words of the Courier-Mail editorial, `To many people a pension of $224 might seem like the riches beyond the dreams of avarice. In light of Mr Hooper's contributions however, it seems rather unfair, and it is precisely this kind of anomaly which the Government must address'.

Madam Deputy Speaker, the Government and, in particular, Sir Joh, showed a complete lack of willingness to address the anomaly or, it seems, even to consider the suggestions, despite attempts by the new member, Henry Palaszczuk, in that State. I understand that, in fact, a motion was put forward at the time but the Government would not accept it. In an act of incomprehensible determination to ensure no lump sum would be paid to the Hooper family, the Government of the day refused to allow the motion. You do not have to be much of a believer in conspiracy theories to believe that Kevin Hooper and his family were victimised by Sir Joh and his band of cronies.

Kevin was an annoyance, a thorn in the side of the Government, corrupt police, the former Police Commissioner, and organised criminals. He had some powerful enemies; enemies who discussed his car accident and his blood alcohol content. After having been requested by the widow and the children, who are now all grown up, as a result of the fourth anniversary of his death, which occurred only some two weeks ago, I wrote to the Premier, because he is a new Premier who said that he had a new vision of excellence and he was going to right wrongs. I wrote to him. I did the right thing. I said to him, `Look, I ask you for some compassion in this case. In view of what is going on about superannuation payments, think about it'. He said publicly, `I will give it to my Under-secretary of the Treasury to look at'.

How obscene, Madam Deputy Speaker. The Under-secretary happens to be Sir Leo Hielscher, who only recently announced that he is going to retire, I think, on 30 April, with $800,000. This morning, after three weeks, after a lot of public pressure from the community throughout the whole of Brisbane and Queensland, for that matter, I received a letter from the Premier saying, `Sorry, but we cannot do anything because the law is the law'. Now, I asked him in my letter to change that law; to make it retrospective, and to put in amending legislation to allow this one person to obtain what she was rightfully entitled to. The fact is that he has refused and he is to give it to a person, as I say, who obscenely will be taking $800,000.

The Police Commissioner, who has now been stood aside, is eligible for some $800,000 or $900,000 and yet the Government up there is in a quandary as to whether he should get it or not. But they certainly have said `no' in this case. I call upon the Premier of Queensland to look at it again. Let us not just say that it is a new broom. This seems to be a case of a new broom which refuses to sweep clean. I call upon the Premier to look at this, to try to rectify this obvious anomaly and, in the name of justice and equity, I ask him to look at it once again; otherwise he will be forever condemned by the people of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I have from time to time spoken in this House about Australia's foreign policy and I have tried to make sure that my speeches give a balanced view of the direction of our foreign policy. Sometimes I have been critical of actions the Government has taken, but by no means always. Today what I want to do is raise the issue of Australia's relationship with Ireland, both north and south, and to express my very deep concern that the Australian Government is conducting that relationship in a casual and negligent way.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us, I think, will have been very struck in recent weeks by the extraordinarily horrible and poignant photographs we have seen on television of violence in Northern Ireland. I do not think, as Australians, it does us much credit, or is a particularly constructive thing to do, to go out and pick and choose who is particularly responsible for these appalling acts of violence. But, suffice it to say, it is my view that the Sinn Fein political movement in Northern Ireland, which is the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, is one of the most abhorrent political movements in the Western world. But, at the same time, I am no apologist for some of the really terrible things that the loyalist side of the debate in Northern Ireland has also been responsible for.

Honourable members will be aware that some three years ago, in 1985, the British and the Irish governments came to an agreement with a view to making some sort of constructive progress towards a settlement for the problem of Northern Ireland. That agreement is known as the Anglo-Irish Agreement. It has been extremely controversial, and rejected by Sinn Fein, of course, because it does not put all power into its hands. It has been rejected by some of the loyalists and the unionists in Northern Ireland because they feel that it is in some way a sellout by the British Government to the Republic of Ireland. But, I think, as outsiders, we would see it as a first step towards some sort of intelligent cooperation between the two communities, the Catholic and Protestant communities within Northern Ireland.

One of the things that came out of this 1985 Anglo-Irish Agreement was the establishment of something which is called the International Fund for Ireland. This was established formally in December 1986. The objectives of the fund are outlined in article 2 of the agreement to establish the fund-the agreement between the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland governments. Article 2 says:
The objectives of the fund are to promote economic and social advance and to encourage contact dialogue and reconciliation between nationalists and unionists throughout Ireland.

That is a pretty laudable objective, an objective that I know everybody here in the House would support. And we are particularly conscious, I know, of the economic problems in both Northern and southern Ireland which lie as one of the causes of the terrible political difficulties which endure in Northern Ireland. When we go through Belfast, in particular west Belfast, and we drive up areas like the Falls Road as I did last week, and see the deprivation, the unemployment, the economic strife that those people live in, perhaps we should not be surprised that terrorists find it easy to find recruits in that area. If jobs could be created, if economic development could be advanced in that part of Belfast and throughout Northern Ireland and indeed in the Republic of Ireland, it would be all the easier for the security forces in those two countries to fight terrorism in the way that they are having such difficulty doing at the moment.

It comes back of course to the role of the International Fund for Ireland, because what it is designed to do is to get funds from other parts of the world to try to relieve the economic crisis of Ireland, north and south, in order to try to tackle the very deep-rooted political problems there. Do not forget that in Northern Ireland unemployment is now 18 per cent and in the Republic of Ireland 19 per cent. There are major economic problems. The International Fund for Ireland was set up to try to attract funds principally from countries outside of Europe which have large Irish communities.

There are really four relevant countries-the United States of America of course, Canada, New Zealand and Australia. And, Madam Deputy Speaker, I would remind the House that some 25 per cent of Australians, it is estimated, are of Irish origin in one way or another, although I would point out that I do not happen to be myself in that 25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surprise, surprise.

—That is a very interesting comment which would need to be analysed by a sociologist, that the honourable member would regard that in some way as a surprise. Historians, too, would be interested in that sort of comment. Coming back to the International Fund for Ireland, its objective is to spend funds that it can raise from the governments, in particular but not exclusively, of those four countries on a whole range of different projects. For example, some of the money is to be used to help establish local businesses and enterprises in Northern Ireland and in some of the border counties of the Republic of Ireland. Some of the money is to be spent on tourism projects; some of the money is to be spent, thank goodness, on urban redevelopment projects.

SPEECH.PARA: The donors are able to direct, if they wish, how the funds should be spent and in the case of Canada, which is one of the donors, it has asked that its contribution be spent on youth training and exchanges and on business cooperation. Other countries who have contributed have not necessarily asked that the money be directed specifically. So far, there have been contributions from three countries out of the four which have significant Irish populations or people of Irish origin: the United States of America has contributed $85m to this fund; Canada has contributed much less, $1.5m; and little New Zealand, with only three million people, has contributed $300,000. In total, in pounds sterling, the fund has contributions of #53m.

Madam Deputy Speaker, it will not have escaped you that the country which has not contributed to this fund, shamefully, is Australia. It comes as a real surprise to me that a Labor Government which has its roots so deeply embedded in Irish Australia, a party which has often said it was founded by the Irish in Australia, and that party in government in Australia and, has turned its back on the problems of Northern Ireland and the pleas of the Republic of Ireland to contribute to the resolution of those problems in a small way.

When the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke) last year visited the Republic of Ireland he arrived on the tarmac there and made some platitudinous comment about how, whilst he was not of Irish origin himself, he was somehow home. It made many people snigger, I can tell you, around Australia. But, when he was in Ireland during his visit to so-called `home', Mr Haughey, the Prime Minister of Ireland, raised this issue of an Australian contribution to the International Fund for Ireland and the Australian Prime Minister told Mr Haughey Australia would not contribute because, apparently, in spite of being one of the richer countries of the world, in spite of the claim of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that all is well with the Australian economy, we could not afford it.

I was still away last week, but I was browsing through last Thursday's Hansard, the Hansard of St Patrick's Day, and there it was again. The Prime Minister, ever conscious, I suppose, of the need to try to get the Irish vote in Australia, was making a glittering speech about his passion for Ireland and moving some motion to be sent to the Prime Minister of the Republic of Ireland saying how much Australians cared about the Irish. There it was again, political presentation, but where was the reality? Whilst a month or so ago, the Australian Government announced that it would give $100m over three years to the front line states of Africa, the Prime Minister of Australia has I think disgracefully told the Prime Minister of the Republic of Ireland and the British Government as well that Australia will not contribute one brass razoo to the resolution of this frightful confrontation in Northern Ireland that we see night after night on our television screens. I think that is a really disgraceful matter.

I do not raise that as a party political point; I raise it with great sincerity. I am utterly aware that there would be many members of both sides of this House, perhaps particularly the other side in the Labor Party, who would be very surprised to hear this story and very concerned about the negligent and irresponsible way Australia has handled this issue. I call on the Prime Minister and I call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), in the light particularly of the recent horrific events in Northern Ireland, to reconsider that decision and show just a little bit of generosity from Australia, from the Australian Government. I know that many millions of Australians, particularly of Irish origin, would be anxious that we would play some small part in trying to resolve the horrendous situation that exists in Northern Ireland.

I am pleased to hear the gentleman, in fact, say that. Then, of course, he says we should increase our expenditure. —Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. Is the Grievance Debate supposed to be a debate amongst members about the previous speech? This speech that the honourable member for McEwen is making is totally irrelevant to today's events.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. When they bleed they bleed very openly, do they not? When facts are pointed out and the sham which they represent is pointed out, they bleed. I was not going to mention that but having listened to the speech I thought it was a most appropriate point to make.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed last night on the conclusion of the debate on the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill, the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), said:
I have no doubt that it was the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, who coached the honourable member for McEwen, Mr Cleeland, as to some of the things he said in his second reading contribution.

That is a point which the honourable gentleman may make as a throwaway line, but let me assure the House that my comments on organised crime, my concern on organised crime, my contribution as to the extent of organised crime, the fact that I pointed out to the House that organised crime now has tentacles leading into the very basic structures of this community, are observations of my own. They are observations based on my own experience as a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.

It may well be that those throwaway lines expose a shallowness of the Opposition's approach to all matters involved in the reform of our criminal systems and the attack on organised crime. It was not the Opposition which mounted the greatest legislative attack on crime in this country; it was the Labor Government, the Hawke Labor Government, which when it took office, found a complete lack of organised crime attack, no legislation in place at all, and extradition treaties which were ineffectual because the former Government had even failed to bother to update the Extradition Act, had failed to bother to negotiate extradition treaties with other countries so Australian criminals could escape overseas from the jurisdiction of Australian courts.

It was this Government, this Labor Party in government which, in fact, changed all of that. It was this Government which introduced and got through this House the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, not the Opposition. It was this Government that introduced and passed through this House the Proceeds of Crime Bill. It was this Government that introduced and passed through this House the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. It was this Government that passed and got through this House the legislation establishing the National Crime Authority and it was this Government that introduced and got through last night the legislation the extension of the term and the removal of the sunset clause. It was this Government which introduced important changes to the Extradition Act and the associated treaties with other countries.

None of those things was ever suggested as a policy matter by the Opposition; none of those attacks on organised crime was initiated or suggested by the Opposition. Yet in this House continual shallow throwaway lines pass for debate which indicates all the time the lack of real concern of the Opposition in anything to do with organised crime. If honourable members opposite do not know and do not care that organised crime is entrenched in this country and if they are prepared to treat such debates with throw- away lines like that, it does, indeed, denigrate this Parliament. It does mean that legislation which is intended to cut off some of the hydra-headed monsters that organised crime represents is treated shallowly by the Opposition.

I shall say again that I need no coaching from anyone as to my attitude to organised crime because I will stand here day in and day out as long as I can get a forum to speak on and oppose it. I will stand here day in and day out trying to educate the Australian community that in this country we have an enormous problem and there are many, many people in this country of wealth, substance and standing who know about organised crime, who are involved in organised crime and who need to be exposed. Some of those people may well be too close to some people in this House; I do not know, I hope that is not true. Because of the reactions we get from some people in this place, we must sometimes wonder.

It is about time that due credit was given to the Labor Government. It is about time that credit was given to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), because on the record, on the facts, without question there has not been a government in this country's history, federally, that has passed the quality legislation, the amount of legislation and the legislation which is necessary to attack the tentacles of organised crime. I have no doubt that the Government's approach on organised crime will not stop the legislation being introduced but the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, will continue to search for ways, will continue look for vehicles of legislation, for approaches to changes to law and systems of law which will ensure that those changes already made will be strengthened. Any person who wants to become involved with the major organised crime links will face some degree of certainty that he will be caught, that the veil under which he hides will, in fact, be lifted and he will be exposed as a criminal no matter what his status in life is, no matter what his position in society, no matter what his wealth. That is the aim of the Government. It is an aim I support and in that aim I certainly do not need any coaching from anyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lately it has become very fashionable to say that Labor has abandoned its base.
