—I want to raise the subject of the disastrous housing situation in South Australia. The situation quite simply is that Federal and State Labor Government-imposed charges are putting houses out of the reach of young Australians. The level of new housing starts in South Australia is the lowest of all mainland States. The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show South Australian housing starts for the last half of 1987 were 4,200; that is less than half the next lowest State, which was Western Australia with 8,790. Every State and Territory, even the Australian Capital Territory--
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Minister visits Japan this weekend, with the support of the Opposition parties and the cattle industry, to negotiate better access for Australian beef to that market. The Minister will be aware of the tremendous pressure the United States (US) is maintaining on the Japanese Government on this issue, including threatened General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade action from 1 April unless the very restrictive quotas which are unfair to Australia are abolished. Will the Minister not only argue for open and fair access for Australian beef in relation to quotas but also press for the termination of the corrupt Livestock Industry Promotion Corporation (LIPC) importing system, which outrageously destroys the competitive price advantage of Australian beef and rips of billions of yen from Japanese consumers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia for his question. The points he has made are very true and accurate. Australia is arguing so vigorously that liberalisation of the Japanese market is the only way to remove discrimination because of the way the present quota arrangements are being administered by the Japanese through the LIPC. That discrimination was recently analysed in great detail by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. It was pointed out, for example, that beef coming into Japan from the United States has an effective tariff against it of 180 per cent, whereas for Australian beef the tariff rates is about 210 per cent; and yet the beef is charged out to Japanese consumers at the same rate. Similarly, with respect to diaphragm beef, a tariff is charged and it is nearly double the rate of frozen beef from Australia. With respect to that part of the quota that particularly concerns Australia, chilled grass fed beef, there are quite severe constraints on our trade and access to the Japanese market.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not for me really to tell the Japanese that they need to give up the LIPC, but if we can get liberalisation within any sort of sensible, economically based time scale the LIPC should naturally disappear because once the market determines the demand for beef in Japan there will be no need for all this rigmarole of regulations and administrative mechanisms which, as I said, clearly discriminate against Australia's beef.

I hope that the pressure that both Australia and the US are putting on Japan will lead to a situation that was best described by the Japanese Prime Minister when he said to me that Japan has been the main beneficiary of free trade. He understands fully the benefits of free and growing trade. I am sure both sides of the House acknowledge the fact that Japan is a great customer for Australian goods, just as I hope the Japanese understand that we are also a great customer for theirs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the House of the outcome of the trial of the Australian missionary, Mr Ian Grey, in Mozambique? Will the Government be taking any further action to assist Mr Grey in lodging an appeal against his conviction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been reported, and correctly, that Ian Grey, an Australian citizen detained and charged with serious offences against the internal security of Mozambique, has been found guilty of a number of those charges. He has been sentenced to a term of imprisonment slightly in excess of 10 years. I think that on balance and from what I know-I say this from what I know of past gaol sentencing for offences such as this-Mr Grey has been most fortunate. Other people sentenced for offences similar to this one have received gaol sentences of between 20 and 30 years. Mr Grey was also fortunate in that the main charge against him of espionage was withdrawn. The mandatory sentence there is death.

ANSWER.PARA: I suggest that the active involvement of the Australian Government right from shortly after Mr Grey's detention has been beneficial in protecting Mr Grey's interests. I should also say that, from my experience as Foreign Minister for several years now and being exposed to what is done by other countries in various parts of the world in looking after their nationals, no country does more than this country in looking after the interests of a national. Very few indeed would do as much as this country, if indeed any do.

I think it should be borne in mind that there is an extremely high cost borne by the Australian taxpayer in providing the consistent attention which the Australian Government provides in defending the consular rights of Australian citizens cast into a situation similar to that of Mr Grey. The Australian Government will now make representations to the Mozambican authorities for remission of the sentence. I should parenthetically put on the record the fact that many of these things which have evolved in the last 48 to 72 hours are matters which were touched on only properly in my discussions with Dr Macumbi, the Foreign Minister of Mozambique, and President Chissano of Mozambique, when I was there some few weeks ago. We will now make representations to see what can be done to present a case for remission of the sentence. We may or we may not be successful.

There are two things I want to say now: the first is that when we handle these very difficult and sensitive consular cases there is a need for patience on the part of members of the Australian community-that includes some of their representatives in this House. Operations are not helped in any way at all by cheap domestic political point scoring at a time of sensitive and difficult negotiations with representatives of foreign governments on behalf of Australian citizens who find themselves in a very difficult situation.

At the time of the Barlow-Chambers case we had the experience of at least one person being bitterly abusive towards the Government, no doubt to cover up his own shortcomings as a legal representative, for not having done enough. The fact is that we knew at that time that one of the duo had confessed to Australian sources that he was guilty of the offences for which he had been found guilty and was part of a drug running operation. We are placed in a very difficult situation in such cases. We have confidential information and, at the same time, we have an obligation to respect the laws of other countries. We also have an obligation to look after the consular rights of these people.

The case of Mr Grey was not helped by some cheap gimmickry point scoring by the honourable member for North Sydney who was more interested in trying to promote himself at the expense of Mr Grey than in displaying a genuine concern for the rights of Mr Grey.

In the Pantelich case a little earlier, we were making some slow but difficult progress in representing Mr Pantelich's rights to a government of a country with a totally different political system and a totally different system of court processes to that which we are used to. The point scoring which occurred then resulted in the Australian Government's position being put in reverse and made much more difficult. It took considerable effort to overcome that sort of adversity.

One other thing I want to say is this: the honourable member for North Sydney in the course of engaging in cheap political point scoring was critical of the $6m in aid which we agreed under a memorandum of understanding to provide for Mozambique. That was a decision taken some considerable time before my arrival in Mozambique. Perhaps to give the flavour of the need to provide humanitarian aid-and it was largely food relief aid-I could quote from a cable sent to us from Geneva. The cable said simply:

Senior officers of the International Commission of the Red Cross and the United Nations High Commission for Refugees describe the Mozambican refugee situation as being the worst they have ever witnessed.
The cable went on to say:

Dewy (an official) also gave a dramatic description of the crisis. Measles and other diseases were very prevalent amongst the refugees but they were fleeing not only from starvation and disease but from the actuality and the fear of `every human rights abuse in the book'. In reply to my question, Dewy said that, all things considered, Malawi and its infrastructure (including its health services) were holding up surprisingly well under the load of 400,000 desperate refugees.
The refugees referred to came from Mozambique. The cable continued:
There was, however, a serious problem developing in regard to potable water supply.

In these circumstances we are not prepared to engage in some cheap political gimmickry and say that we will withhold a miserable $6m-which is a very modest amount-of emergency food aid from the people of Mozambique, who are suffering the most extreme forms of distress, even worse than that experienced in Ethiopia. We will not withhold, or threaten to withhold, that sort of aid, because the only people who will suffer are starving men, women and children. The infants and the aged will be the first and most telling casualties. But that is what the honourable member for North Sydney, on behalf of the Opposition, wants us to do. Furthermore, from my experience the withholding of aid would have had no influence and would have been totally counterproductive to the sort of result we were trying to bring about in protecting the interests of Mr Grey. Today Mr Grey has been sentenced to imprisonment for a little over 10 years. That is a severe sentence by our standards, but in terms of what is generally passed in the court system in Mozambique for the very serious offences-and they were serious offences-to which he pleaded guilty, it is quite a moderate sentence.

The Opposition was of absolutely no help in this matter. The honourable member for North Sydney was completely counterproductive in the statements he made on this subject, just as he has been totally unhelpful when engaging in cheap political point scoring in other instances where the Government has painstakingly, patiently, and with great dedication represented the interests of Australian citizens detained in other countries with different cultural and legal systems. I repeat that Mr Grey has nothing for which to thank the honourable member for North Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware that 160,000 travellers have refused to pay the $5 arrival tax in its first two months of operation and that it is estimated that this number will reach one million by the end of the year? Is the Minister also aware of the damage the tax is doing to Australia's reputation as a tourist destination? In view of the fact that the Australian Tourism Industry Association estimates that the average tourist generates about $1,000 in taxes and charges to Federal and State treasuries, and that the Minister has been reviewing the arrival tax, will he now admit that its introduction was an outrageous bungle and scrap it forthwith?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be pointed out that, when the tax, the levy, which is a charge on incoming airline passengers, was imposed, it was indicated that its purpose was to enable immigration authorities to update and produce new processes by which incoming passengers could be processed more quickly. If we are to effectively move passengers through the processes of visa examination, we must introduce new technology. I have always understood that the coalition's position on an issue such as this is that the user pays. Anyone who claims that a $5 charge will act as a disincentive to potential tourists, Japanese or otherwise, is talking palpable nonsense. The second point I make is that the airlines requested that the Government allow them to work out the method of collecting the charge. That was a reasonable request and we acceded to it. The fact that the airlines have not merely failed but there is substantial evidence to show that some airlines have gone out of their way to consciously obstruct the collection of that fee that does not reflect well on them. Despite that, on three separate occasions the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and the Territories and I have met with airline representatives to look at a methodology to upgrade the processes and move tourists far more quickly through our airport terminals. Only this week have the airlines produced their preferred position, which is being examined. I do not make an apology for the Government's position on this issue. I say to the shadow Minister: let us know what the Opposition's policy is on this matter. The Opposition continually tells the Government that it must cut costs. However, when one speaks of cutting costs, one is talking about cutting the living standards of the average Australian. At the same time, when it comes to adopting the principle of user pays, those opposite do not want to be in it.

ANSWER.PARA: We are looking at quite substantial sums of money, and the charge does not have any effect at all on the tourist trade. For the honourable gentleman opposite to suggest that it does indicates that he is adopting the same lazy, sleazy approach of most shadow Ministers. If he did his homework, he would realise that the airlines have made a series of submissions to the Government. Those submissions will be seriously considered, but only on the basis that this Government will not impose additional burdens on the average taxpayer to meet the cost of providing new facilities which can and should be borne properly by overseas tourists visiting Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Treasurer. I preface the question by drawing the attention of the Treasurer to comments made by the Leader of the Opposition, delivered one octave below hysteria, responding to Mr John Elliott's renewed and untimely calls for a consumption tax.
—Order! Just keep to the question.
—I ask the Treasurer whether he could please inform the House--
—On a point of order--
—Order! I have asked the honourable member to keep to the question. Keep your asides out of it and stick to the question.

—Will the Treasurer please inform the House how he intends to finance the corporate tax cuts which he foreshadowed in last year's Budget and which he and the Prime Minister have indicated are likely to be announced in the May statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The corporate tax review being undertaken by the Government will be undertaken on a revenue neutral basis-that is, one where the Government is quite happy with the current mix in the tax arrangements between personal and business taxes in this country. The point of the exercise is to pull down the corporate tax rates so as to level the playing field within the corporate tax system; in other words, to remove the dead hand of tax preference which affects the allocation of resources within the economy. Because the tax system has developed, particularly under 30 years of coalition government, without any rhyme or reason to many of the provisions, and because the dead hand of tax preference misallocates resources, that is having a compounding effect on the way in which the economy operates and on its efficiency.

ANSWER.PARA: Our tax reform will be unlike that of the United States (US), the United Kingdom and New Zealand where there have been reductions in the nominal rate of company tax and increases in the aggregate level of tax paid by corporations to the treasuries. Let me give an example. Total corporate tax collections in New Zealand have increased from 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 1985-86 to 4.1 per cent in 1987-88, a substantial rise. The US has lowered its company tax rate but expects to collect an extra $120 billion over a three-year period. In other words, those countries have had nominal rate reductions in, but increases in total collections of, company tax.

The President of the Liberal Party, Mr John Elliott, constantly maintains that in some way Australians are paying a higher proportion of tax than people in other countries. He says that the tax base in Australia is rising, whereas tax bases around the world are falling. That is untrue. He repeats it perpetually in Australia and out of Australia. He has no loyalty to the place. He is always bagging Australia in London, New York and everywhere else he gets the chance. He has no concept, not just of promoting his own country, but of referring to it in accurate and decent terms.

Let me take the opportunity to kill the notion that Australia is a high tax country. Our total tax burden of 30 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) compares with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average of 37 per cent. Our corporate tax burden of 2.8 per cent compares with the OECD average of 3 per cent. I have some OECD tables here, which I will table at the end of my answer, which show that Australia is at the bottom of the OECD league table in relation to total taxation and corporate taxation as a proportion of GDP. Mr Elliott's claim is not correct. The Australia tax burden, the tax base, has not been rising, whereas other tax bases have been rising even though those countries have had nominal rate reduction.

The essence of what Mr Elliott has been saying lately is that he wants a company tax rate cut financed by a consumption tax. In other words, he wants some redistribution of the cake from the poor to the rich. That is his idea of tax reform. He said that he is going to bring that to the next meeting of the Liberal Federal Council and argue it strongly. He is saying, `We do not want a revenue neutral reform. What we want is some money pumped up the system from the general public to allow reductions in both personal tax and the corporate rate'. For the information of the House, I had a couple of calculations made which show that if Australia were to use a consumption tax simply to reduce its company tax rate to that of the United Kingdom-35 per cent-it would require a 5.9 per cent consumption tax. If we were to reduce the rate to that of New Zealand-28 per cent-it would require a consumption tax of 6.8 per cent. In other words, Mr Elliott is trotting around the country saying that we should put a 6 or 7 per cent tax on items such as food, children's clothing, footwear, school textbooks, pharmaceuticals, electrical bills, stamps-everything-to reduce the corporate tax rate to levels which he thinks are appropriate for the companies which he controls to operate within.

At the same time Mr Elliott had the hide in the newspapers yesterday, or earlier, the tax advantages available in having a box at the Victorian Football League with everything laid on, courtesy of the tax system. These are the standards of the Liberal Party's President in relation to taxation. There are his fallacious claims that Australia's tax burden is rising when it is not, claims that cannot be substantiated. Australia's ratio of tax to GDP is amongst the lowest in the OECD. He advocates a corporate tax reform financed by a consumption tax which would blow our inflation rate to pieces, putting another six to seven percentage points on inflation, while we are recovering our competitiveness in our current account deficit-so that we can have the kind of tax mix that he thinks is appropriate for the Liberal Party at this time.

No wonder the Leader of the Opposition is ropeable with him. He could hardly conceal his anger on a television report yesterday when Mr Elliott made it clear that he was going to take all this to the next meeting of the Liberal Party's Federal Council and argue it with vigour. Perhaps a few more facts along with the vigour might lead the Liberal Party to conclude that the changes to the tax system which the Government is promoting are the only decent, sensible and fair ones for Australia and that all the changes it wants are essentially about ripping money off ordinary people and sticking it into the pockets of corporations. I table the two charts to which I referred earlier in my answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS LEGISLATION: LEGAL OPINION

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the proposal which was announced last December to include in a preamble to legislation a declaration to recognise that Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were the prior occupiers and original owners of Australia and to the Attorney-General's letter to me recently in response to my freedom of information (FOI) application and I ask: Since the December announcement, why has it been necessary for the Attorney-General to obtain a Queen's Counsel's written opinion? Why has the Attorney-General referred to the matter as being of `high sensitivity' and refused to release that legal opinion under the FOI Act? Is it not a fact that the Cabinet decision of 7 December 1987 was made with the benefit of legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department included in the coordination comments attached to the relevant Cabinet submission and a hurried opinion received orally from the Queen's Counsel on the same day?

—I recall that the honourable member was suggesting that an opinion was available at the time the Cabinet made the decision. That was not the case, except for the coordination comment from my Department. That is where the honourable member was in error in the first case. Secondly, as the honourable member knows, there is litigation related to the matter. Queen's Counsel is involved in that litigation. Naturally, following the introduction of the legislation, the Queen's Counsel expressed a view about the preamble. That is the extent of the matter. In no way does it affect the case. In no way does it affect the legislation.
—The legal opinion was received on 7 December.
—Order! The honourable member asked his question and got his answer.
—Will the Minister for Defence inform the House of progress on the new submarine project? What does the project mean for South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member will no doubt be pleased to know that the construction of a $123m facility is currently under way in Adelaide to establish the means by which the submarine can be produced. It will produce a great deal of work for Adelaide. The honourable member would also be pleased to know that contracts worth $50m have so far been won by South Australian companies for ancillary work related to the submarine. Those companies include British Aerospace Australia Ltd, Nilsen Electrical Industries Pty Ltd and Fairly Australasia Pty Ltd. Many more companies in South Australia will become involved as the project proceeds. It is a critical project for the development of South Australian industry. Whilst this Government remains in office, as it will for a considerable period, the project is not under threat. That, however, is not the situation which is offered by honourable members opposite. The chairman of the all-powerful back bench finance committee of the Liberal Party persistently comes into this place setting aside what are alleged to be the views of the Opposition defence spokespersons on whether that project will proceed. Just as persistently as he says it will not, persistently the others speculate on whether we might get nuclear-powered submarines. It is clear that, when one suggests that, one suggests, in effect, cancellation of that project because that is not the type of build site one would need for nuclear powered submarines. One would have to cancel the project and go through to a totally different type of production.

ANSWER.PARA: The submarine program, by subterfuge and directive, is persistently being threatened by senior figures in the Liberal Party and senior figures in the National Party. That needs to be borne in mind because the future employment prospects of people in a wide range of industries in South Australia, from the black trades through to the electronic industries, are very substantially dependent on that project going ahead. Whatever persiflage Opposition members go on with in this place of saying `It does not matter if a few of our back bench chairmen of committees, or whatever, happen to say they do not believe in it, we believe in it but at the same time we will put to study nuclear submarine programs', there is a clear indication from them that as soon as by-elections are out of the way, as soon as they feel they have cleared the decks in the area, they will be straight into that project, as they have been from day one.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS LEGISLATION: LEGAL OPINION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his statement to the House on 10 December 1987 in answer to a question as to whether he had received legal advice on the implications of the preamble to the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I have not received any advice in the area.

I also refer the Prime Minister to a letter received from his Department which states that Attachment E to Cabinet Submission No. 5436 includes no coordination comments on the implications or legal consequences of the preamble. I ask: Does not the correspondence from his own Department contradict the Prime Minister's answer given in the House on 10 December 1987?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no, it does not. I made it quite clear what the position was then. Clearly I was referring to the concept of formal legal advice which, clearly, as the Attorney- General has just said, had not been received and instructions were given for the reception of such advice. The facts are clear. They have been for so long now that I do not know why the honourable member has waited this long to raise the subject, unless it is another desperate attempt to get down in the gutter where he properly belongs.

—Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training inform the House of progress with the implementation of the Government's reform of student assistance? Can he say whether there is any substance to recent Opposition allegations of delays in the processing of Austudy applications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. One of the important areas of policy which this Government had to review on being elected in 1983 was the situation in which young people in school were being enticed to leave school early as a result of the mismatch of assistance schemes available to those within the education system and those outside it. Madam Speaker, you might recall that a young person from a lower income family could receive nearly twice as much by leaving school and receiving the unemployment benefit as he could by remaining in school to finish his secondary education. As a result of decisions taken by the Government, we have now removed that Liberal Party imposed incentive to leave the education system and have replaced it with an incentive for young people, particularly those from low income backgrounds, to remain in school until the completion of their secondary education, with the hope that they will then proceed in other forms of formal education and training beyond the secondary school system.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the changes that we have made there has been some 50 per cent increase in the expenditure on assistance to students compared with a real decline in support for such people during the period from 1979 to 1983. So our commitment to enhancing the opportunities for young people from lower income families is clear, whereas the previous Government was intent on ensuring that those young people continued to have inferior opportunities as they approached a working life.

My colleague the Minister for Employment and Education Services has informed me that the administration of Austudy has improved markedly from last year. It is true that there were some difficulties in the administration of Austudy as a result of the substantial changes that we had introduced but I am informed by my colleague that as of 18 March the Department had received some 220,000 applications, of which 90 per cent had already been processed, and students were therefore looking forward to receiving their Austudy payments. We expect during this year to receive applications from some 245,000 students compared with 225,000 last year. This very substantial increase will be reflected, of course, in a continuation of the increase in retention rates, which increased from 36 per cent when we were elected to 53 per cent last year. These Austudy improvements, combined with the effects of the family assistance scheme, represent a very substantial boost to the circumstances of lower income families, particularly those with students.

I make the point in conclusion that those students who may be eligible for Austudy and who have not yet applied should do so before the end of March. If they do so they will receive allowances for the full academic year, whereas if they apply after 31 March, and are eligible, they will receive benefits from the date of application. I should also remind those students in the education system who are about to turn 16, when they become eligible for Austudy, that they can apply up to two months before their sixteenth birthday to ensure that the payments are made to them as soon as they become eligible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS LEGISLATION: LEGAL OPINION

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to his statement in the House on 10 December 1987 that he had `no specific advice of a legal nature' on the proposed preamble to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Commission Bill. I also refer the Minister to: firstly, the Attorney-General's answer given a few minutes ago acknowledging the existence of advice in the coordination comments; secondly, a letter from his Department which states that the Minister's Cabinet submission included coordination comments prepared by a legally qualified officer in the Attorney-General's Department on the subject of the preamble; and, thirdly, a further letter from the Attorney-General's Department stating that additional legal advice was obtained from a Queen's Counsel on the same day as the Cabinet considered the Minister's submission on the preamble. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that this correspondence contradicts his statement to the House on 10 December that he had `no specific advice of a legal nature' on the implications and/or legal consequences of the preamble?

—As usual, my answer has been taken out of context by the shadow Minister, as has been his wont with a number of Press releases. My answer to a specific question asked by the Leader of the Opposition was: `I have received no specific advice of a legal nature on that point'. I stand by the Attorney-General's earlier answer and the answer I gave on 10 December.

—I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. In the light of this Government's united commitment to the national social justice strategy, could the Minister explain the differences in the approach taken by this Government and that of the previous Government on the important issues of unemployment programs and the labour market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government, unlike the previous Government, has not administered the Department of Social Security as some sort of massive automatic teller machine that spits out placatory cheques for the unemployed. This Government, unlike the previous Government, has not been content to sit back and watch the number of people receiving unemployment benefit increase. When the Government came to office, the number of people queueing up was increasing by an average of 20,000 a month. The number reached 635,000 in April 1983. It is now 502,000, which is a dramatic reduction in the number of people receiving benefits and reflects the extraordinarily successful management by this Government of the economy, the success of the labour market programs that have been the responsibility of this Government, and the effectiveness of the Government's strategy to link income support and labour market programs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Employment, Education and Training just referred to the changes that occurred in relation to Austudy enabling the removal of any disincentive for young people to be on the unemployment benefit as opposed to being in education. Measures such as compulsory registration with the Commonwealth Employment Service in order to maintain eligibility for the unemployment benefit, the requirement for personal lodgment, and a number of other changes have ensured that income support going to the unemployed and their families has been sustained and, indeed, has increased in real terms during our period in government.

Since March 1983 the real value of unemployment benefit for a person with a spouse and three children and renting privately has increased by almost 25 per cent. The Government has been concerned to introduce programs to allow people of all ages with all sorts of skills, as well as those with a lack of skills, to find employment. It has been concerned to re-establish the integrity of the unemployment benefit program, to break down stereotypes of the unemployed, such as the unemployed being dole bludgers, an image encouraged by the previous Government because it could not offer real solutions and offered no real hope for the hundreds of thousands of people who were thrown out of work during its period in office.

The people of this country and in this Parliament ought never to forget the years 1981 and 1982. In those years the government of the day gave this country its only period of negative growth since the Second World War. The direct result of its actions during that period was that 300,000 Australians were thrown out of work in the prime of their working lives. That scarring of lives which occurred in 1981 and 1982 is something that will remain as a scar on the Opposition for many years to come. The honourable member for Bradfield talked yesterday with a crocodile tear approach about how long term unemployment and child poverty had been created under this Government. No-one in this Parliament and no-one in the Australian nation ought to forget what that scarring meant. There is a cohort of people who went into the unemployment benefit system in 1982-83 and are still there today. They are there today not because of the policies of this Government but because they were so scarred during that period. That is the tragedy of the previous Government's performance and that is the legacy it left, along with the prospective deficit of nearly $9 billion.

In terms of policies, the Opposition can offer nothing but further attacks on the unemployed, threatening to remove people after six months and cancel labour market programs, and suggesting that somehow, to fund the $8 billion worth of savings that the Leader of the Opposition promised, one can single out the unemployed and supporting parents to get the large part of these savings. It is in that context that one has to look at Mr John Elliott, the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, who is suggesting that, while those savings no doubt ought to be endorsed, we ought to rip more money off the unemployed and sole parents, and that while we do that we ought, in some strange notion of justice, to introduce a consumption tax, with no compensation, which is likely to affect adversely those people who have been the victims of that recession of the Fraser-Howard Government and of its policies.

It is all very well for John Elliott, who would not be too proud to have his Party impose a consumption tax, but what about those who would not be too proud to pay a consumption tax or who are just too poor to pay a consumption tax? What does John Elliott have to say to these people? It is all very well for him to say that his grandmother, or his mother, was perhaps too rich to accept benefits but then he condemns those who are necessarily dependent on social security.

The honourable member prefaced his question with a reference to social justice. What this Party has been about in government and opposition is some sense of fairness and equity. What the John Elliotts of this world are on about, and indeed the honourable member for Bradfield and certainly the right honourable member for New England are on about, is negative redistribution, as the Treasurer said. They are on about protecting the millionaires who are on pensions. They are on about ensuring that the capital gains tax is removed and they are on about ensuring that the taxpayer pays for the businessmen's lunches. On the other hand, they are on about ripping into sole parents and the unemployed. That is not what the policies of this Government are about. They are about some fairness and some equity.
