SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—In the course of an answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) today he said, amongst other things, that I was critical of a $6m decision on aid to Mozambique, and he went on to say, `We will not withhold aid to starving people'. The Foreign Minister managed, with his exquisite talent for the half truth, to convey the clear implication that I had no concern for the starving and would withhold humanitarian aid. I have been critical with respect in particular to the following matters: the priorities shown by this Government on aid, the aid announcement which was made and which coincided with the Foreign Minister's trip so as to elevate his political profile-something that I described as a cynical and futile exercise-and Australian aid to Mozambique in a particular context. I quote from a Press release of 14 March, in which I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian aid should not be given to Mozambique unless and until-
I repeat: unless and until-
the Australian missionary, Mr Ian Grey, gets a trial that is demonstrably fair or is released.

Then I went on to say that, if Mr Grey's case was not fairly dealt with, the $6m aid package announced by the Minister should be diverted to another country. There are, I interpolate, a lot of people in need of our aid, in Africa and elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: the honourable member is debating the matter.
-The honourable member might come to where he has been personally misrepresented.
—I have stated that; I am just pointing it out. I also said in a Press release of 22 February:

SPEECH.PARA: Would it not have been a much more sensible use of Australia's humanitarian aid to Africa to concentrate it in one area of great need with supervision by Australian aid personnel to make sure that aid gets to the people who need it, and that it is not politically or corruptly misused?

The implication which the Foreign Minister, in one of his regrettably characteristic personal attacks, sought to make against me is as I have explained to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I entirely reject it.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have the opportunity of making a personal explanation?
-Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—I claim to have been grievously misrepresented by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), once again in that characteristic fashion he adopts.
—The Minister may proceed.
—The honourable member for North Sydney said in his Press statement that if Mr Grey's case was not fairly dealt with--

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: my point is very simply that a personal explanation may be made by a member for the purpose of correcting a misrepresentation. I gave a personal explanation. It was not interrupted or ruled out of order by you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and that is an end to the matter. The Foreign Minister is now seeking to debate the issue by reference to parts of my Press release. If he wishes to have a debate on the subject of his lamentable exercise in diplomacy, I will be glad to accommodate him.

—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney gave a personal explanation in which he raised a number of issues he was concerned about. He was provided with a fair level of tolerance, even when a Minister called a point of order on him. I will hear the Minister for Foreign Affairs on a matter of misrepresentation.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. May I commence by apologising for upsetting this crumpled Rumpole of the Sydney bad debts court who has come into the Parliament to grace the front bench of the Opposition as an addition to the brightest and the best it has to offer. It shows why the Opposition is going into liquidation rather rapidly.
—Come on, you bitter little man.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will not interrupt. The Minister will come to where he was misrepresented or resume his seat.

—What I said was that the honourable member for North Sydney had argued that we should hold the starving and the needy of Mozambique up to ransom by declaring that they would get no aid unless certain things were done for Mr Grey. That is all I said, and I said that was unacceptable to us. The honourable member did say that, if Grey's case was not fairly dealt with, the aid package should be diverted to another country-which means we do not give them any aid unless they do the things we say, and if they do not do the things we say they do not get it.
—Order! The Minister might come to where he personally has been misrepresented by the honourable member for North Sydney.
—He said that I misrepresented his position, but I represented it absolutely accurately. I should add that the food aid to the starving also subsidises the grain farmers of Australia.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the Foreign Minister has to abide by the rules of the House as well as anybody else. He knows very well he is seeking to abuse them, and he should be sat down.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for McPherson. I think the Minister is past his misrepresentation.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
-Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—He may proceed.

—The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in Question Time indicated again that my views and the Opposition's views were that we would move to cancel the submarine program which has now been in place since May 1987. Since that time he has been peddling this gross untruth, and I would think even the people of Port Adelaide would be getting sick and tired of it.
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson might come to where he has been misrepresented.
—The misrepresentation is simply that that is not my view. My view and the Opposition's view is that on that contract--
—I think the honourable member for McPherson has said that it is not this view; he has cleared up the misrepresentation.
—Mr Deputy Speaker--
—Is there a further misrepresentation?

—There is. In that answer the Minister for Defence also said that as soon as we attained government and pursued plans for nuclear powered surface ships and submarines we would cancel the existing submarine program. That position has never been expressed by this side of the House. It is not our view and it is an absolute disgrace that the Government has never pursued the nuclear option, as we intend to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
-Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Last evening when we were debating the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Bill, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) entered the House rather late in the piece and listened in silence, for which he is not characteristically known--
—Order! The honourable member will come to where he was misrepresented.
—Thank you very much. This is very important. When I finished my address-I quote from Hansard-Mr Howe said:

SPEECH.PARA: You ousted hundreds of thousands of families, Connolly, and you know it.
The fact of the matter is that that is a physical impossibility, and I am not an Idi Amin or anything like that. I take the greatest exception to even the inclusion of such comments in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has made his point.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage done by the Government to prospects for continuing reconciliation between Aboriginal and other Australians by its insensitivity and unrealistic raising of expectations.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not satisfied with the answers it received today in the House to questions which we put to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), and we intend to make sure that we pursue the matter further. Before going on to the details, I begin by addressing my remarks to the general nature of Aboriginal affairs at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: I want, firstly, to comment on the extent to which this Government has raised expectations far beyond what could be delivered. I raise this matter of public importance because of both my deep concern and that of the Opposition about the Hawke Government's performance in Aboriginal affairs and its impact on the prospects for any continuing reconciliation between Aboriginal and other Australians. There is no area that better illustrates the Government's abject failure to come to grips with the needs of Australia's disadvantaged people. As the Minister has said, `Too much has been said for so long and not enough action'. These words were said over eight months ago. The Minister may well fall back on the claim of increased Government spending in the area of Aboriginal affairs as evidence of its commitments. The simply staggering and tragic fact is that not one of the recognised social indicators has shown any improvement. In fact two or three of the key social indicators have got dramatically worse, even though $2.5 billion has been allocated to Aboriginal advancement in the past five years under this Government. The fact is that the Australian Labor Party's judgment that grandiose solutions would meet Aboriginal needs has been wrong in the past and is wrong now. Why should the Australian people generally, let alone Aboriginal Australians, believe that the rhetoric of the Labor Party will bear fruit in 1988? It obviously will not. The rhetoric of the past is proving to be empty and barren.

I want to go back over some of the empty promises which have been made over the past five years by this Government. Remember the Holding resolution of 1983 which raised the hopes of Aboriginal people. It lapsed and now gathers dust in the Table Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't even remember Mr Holding.

—Indeed, that is very true. Remember the national land rights proposal, when the Government broke the spirit of bipartisanship and brought on a confrontationalist model, only to abandon it when the Western Australian Labor Government looked like being defeated. It will be years before the disillusionment, despair and bitterness of the fallout from Labor's land rights debacle are overcome.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the Government's standing promises in the area of Aboriginal affairs. The Government is committed to introducing a program to house all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people over a period of six years to a standard acceptable to them and devised in consultation with the Aboriginal people. This has been Labor Party policy since 1983. Now with less than one year to go the Aboriginal Development Commission has estimated that the housing backlog has actually increased 6 per cent since the Government came to power. Instead of moving forward and achieving its goals, the Government is going backwards. To achieve the goal of meeting housing demand it would need to spend $1.3 billion.

The next commitment of the Labor Party is to ensure that there will be 1,000 Aboriginal teachers by 1990. It is clear that that commitment will not be achieved. Whilst projections fall well short of Government promises, the Government is not going to maintain the Abstudy special teachers training award. In fact, that has disappeared. There are likely to be no new grants this year and, as I have said, the Government is certainly unlikely to meet its commitment of 1,000 teachers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another broken promise.

—Another broken promise, as the honourable member for Curtin has said. The Government's failure to meet expectations in such a vital area is a real blow to the hopes that many families had of gaining better schooling for their children. The Government's third commitment is to ensuring that during this year the proportion of Aborigines and Islanders employed by Commonwealth departments will be at least equal to their proportion within the Australian population. Again that is another promise that will fail.

SPEECH.PARA: When we recount this sorry chequered record is it any wonder that many in the Aboriginal community now view any initiatives by governments with a great degree of scepticism and mistrust? We condemn the Government for raising expectations far beyond what is achievable because we believe that in so doing the Government has put back what is achievable. Father Frank Brennan-and I see him sitting in the chamber today-adviser to the Catholic bishops on Aboriginal affairs, has said so succinctly:

The broken promises are the greatest breach of faith committed by any Government towards the Aboriginal people since white settlement . . . Their votes have been bought, they have been betrayed totally.

By seeking to do the impossible the Government has made the possible impossible-a disaster in political terms. Here we are, five years into the Hawke Labor Government and we are yet to see one significant policy advance from this Government in the area of Aboriginal affairs. I repeat: we are five years into this Government's term of office and we are yet to see any advances in the area of Aboriginal affairs.

The coalition parties have an extensive list of achievements over a period of 12 years in government. Not only did the coalition have a sensitive and caring understanding of the situation; it also had the political competence to put in place measures of far-reaching consequence. Expectations were not raised beyond what was achievable and, as a consequence, a degree of mutual trust developed which enabled progress to be made in this area.

It is this Government which is betraying the trust of many Aborigines. It is this Government which has increased the volatility of racial feelings by creating mirages for the Aboriginal community. With a new Minister a fresh start could have been made. The Minister made it clear that he did not intend to make promises. There was the hope that we were going to leave the land of promises and move forward for the first time in 4 1/2 years. The hope was to be short lived. In this term the Government has promised to remove child poverty by 1990. Does anybody truly expect that there will be no Aboriginal children living in poverty in this nation in 1990, in two years time? Does anybody expect that to be the case?
Opposition members-No!

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members have said, certainly not. Children suffer because families suffer. Considering the depth of need amongst the Aboriginal people, can anyone in this House believe that there will be no children in poverty? That is certainly not going to be the case. In a similar vein the Government has also committed itself to the elimination of Aboriginal disadvantage by the year 2000. Further, the Government has announced the Aboriginal employment development policy, with a target of creating 46,000 extra jobs. The whole exercise is reminiscent of a past media stunt, when the Prime Minister tried to con young people into Priority One. If the Aboriginal employment policy is equally as effective as Priority One, no more than 8,500 jobs will be created-and there was a promise of 46,000 jobs. There is no way in which that will be delivered either. So much for a no promises administration of Aboriginal affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: But perhaps the most breathtaking of promises was the Prime Minister's commitment to a treaty. The Prime Minister was making policy without due consideration. His insensitivity to the feelings and aspirations of many Aboriginal people in wanting a treaty was shown to be all the more callous when he later told the Parliament that it was a considered statement. Clearly, a treaty was always unachievable.

The Government has again betrayed the trust of the Aboriginal people. Three days after the Federal election the Prime Minister announced that the main Commonwealth bodies within the Aboriginal affairs portfolio would be amalgamated into a new commission; a most substantial reorganisation of Commonwealth administration in this area carried out at the whim of the Prime Minister. There would be no review and no consultation with the Aboriginal people. It would take place even before a Minister had been appointed. The Minister was appointed some 10 days later with one of his major agenda items already determined for him.

On 10 December 1987 the Minister presented Foundations for the Future, a document that included a preamble filled with warm glow statements. On the one hand the preamble pledged that the Aboriginal people were the original owners of Australia; on the other hand it claimed that these rights had been extinguished. What advantage was that to the Aboriginal people? I make it clear that the coalition believes that an important step to promote reconciliation would be for the Australian community as a whole to come to terms with the history of Australia, both Aboriginal and post-1788. However, we know that we are here in this Parliament not as a writers club for historians but as law makers.

The first question we raised was: Since this is a proposal for a law, what are the legal implications of this form of words? To our amazement the Prime Minister and the Minister both claimed that they received no legal advice on the issue. We found that hard to believe. The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), lodged freedom of information requests with the Minister, the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General. I shall leave it to the shadow Attorney-General to flesh out those ideas. I shall continue to outline briefly what has happened.

It has become increasingly clear that legal opinions were drafted even before the proposal went to Cabinet. Correspondence from the Attorney-General indicates that a document dated 27 November 1987 was prepared by Mr McDonald in his capacity as a legal adviser, in which he advised on legal issues considered by the Attorney-General's Department to arise out of the submission. Further, the correspondence confirms the existence of another document consisting of extracts from a draft Cabinet submission and comments, in relation to those extracts, from a legally qualified member of the Attorney-General's department, and it states:
comprised legal advice in the capacity as legal adviser to me.

These legal documents were produced not only before the launch of the Foundations for the Future proposal but also before the Cabinet considered the proposal, in what I believe was a marathon session on Monday, 7 December 1987. The Prime Minister determined to put a warm glow statement on the record before Australia Day 1988. Cabinet approved the proposal in the last sitting week in 1987 and the proposal was tabled on the last sitting day of the House for 1987.

It is apparent that this bulldozing approach caused heartburn in the Cabinet. The Attorney-General confirms the existence of a further fax sent on 7 December, which records views of a legal nature previously orally expressed by counsel. It was a fax presumably hurriedly sent to the Cabinet room to try to reassure the waverers. Yet the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs came into this House on 10 December and claimed that they had no legal advice. This is a very serious matter. The Minister acknowledged this when, in a report in the Canberra Times on 16 January, a spokesman for the Minister said that allegations that the Minister had misled the Parliament were being treated will all the seriousness that they deserve and that the Minister would probably issue a statement on the following Monday. We are still waiting for that statement.

I demand an explanation from the Minister as to how he has not misled the House. If he is not willing to do that, he should resign. Further, the correspondence indicates that later in January the Government received legal advice from a Melbourne Queen's Counsel. The freedom of information process has also raised some real concerns about the bona fides of the Government. In answer to a question put to him in the House on 10 December 1987 the Prime Minister called for bipartisan support for the preamble. That bipartisan support has not really been forthcoming from the Minister or the Prime Minister. The situation is that the Government has not addressed the issues of Aboriginal people in this nation. I conclude this matter of public importance with the following comments: We believe that 1988--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the luncheon break we gave this matter of public importance some thought, thinking that it would be something constructive and worthy of a response. It is based on the argument that nothing has been done and on a desire for everything that is being tried-attempts are being made in a whole range of areas-to improve the lot of Aboriginal people to fail. That is the message that I got from the contribution of the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). Never have I said in this place or anywhere else that everything that ought to be done is currently being done and that every program will be 100 per cent successful.

SPEECH.PARA: On every occasion I have spoken on this issue in this Parliament I have tried my best to adopt a bipartisan approach. A bipartisan approach is something we all ought to strive for, and as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said, we were hoping that the Opposition would adopt that attitude too. However, as has happened in recent years, it did not take long for the shadow Minister to fall into the trap of his predecessors. Perhaps it would be fairer to say that he is not permitted to express his own private views in a public forum. He has been gagged and harnessed by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and those who surround him. I find it extraordinary that the shadow Minister's statements in recent times do not correspond with the lengthy discussions I have had with him in my rooms and around the corridors of this building. About that I am extremely disappointed.

I for one had great hopes of being able to work with him, as people have in the past with members of the Opposition, trying to improve things. He has indulged in cheap point-scoring by coming in here telling us that problems exist out there in the Aboriginal community. We know that. I have just completed 49 days of continuous travel around this country attempting to talk to as many Aboriginal community organisations and individuals in a manner that has never before been attempted. I have not bragged about that in the past but I will inform the honourable member for Braddon about it. It would do him well to travel around and talk to these people also, because he is a long way short of the mark.

I have said also that I will not make promises that I cannot deliver. I defy the honourable member for Braddon to tell me of any instance when I have made a commitment or promise to an Aboriginal community, while I have been the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, that I have not fulfilled. That will be the record that people will judge me on in my time in this position-my achievements. I do recognise, however, and this was alluded to by the honourable member for Braddon, that governments and people in power over the past 200 years have been guilty of gilding the lily when talking to Aboriginal people. We are all guilty of this-members on both sides of this chamber, even members of the National Party of Australia who are part of the Opposition side of the House. But that time has passed.

I wish to refer now to the latter part of the contribution of the honourable member for Braddon. He referred to the amalgamation of the four areas into a new commission. In this chamber I said that discussions would have to be held with the Aboriginal people, and that we had to get it right. I said that we would take note of what they said. I did not say, `This is what we are going to do; cop this'. I said to people, `This is a concept developed by examining various documents that people have prepared over many years and by analysing proposals that have come forward from Aboriginal people and trying to put together a package and make it work'. We have then gone into the Aboriginal community and talked to the community in a way that has never been done before.

Let us cut out this nonsense by the shadow Minister's Party, and others who are feeding him the information, most of which is incorrect, that consultation of this type took place when the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) was formed. I say to him that there is no way that that happened-not to the extent of the consultation that is currently in process. We have conducted 453 meetings around Australia; I have attended 46 regional meetings. A series of repeat meetings is taking place. Never before have so many Aboriginal organisations and people been brought together to discuss a government's concept or proposal prior to such legislation being introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unprecedented.

—That is correct, it is unprecedented. The days of governments ramming things down Aboriginal people's necks have finished. The honourable member would do well to take heed of that instead of trying to score cheap political points. I thought he was better than that.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem today is that the Liberal and National parties have moved back from the position they held in the 1970s and early 1980s. Most other political parties around the world-some slowly, but most-are moving forward in a progressive way. The Liberal Party is moving backwards at a hundred miles an hour. I refer the honourable member to the Bonner-Withers motion in the Senate to which I have referred previously, which urged the admission of prior ownership. That was proposed in 1974. In 1980 Senator Chaney, a member of the Liberal Party, moved a motion relating to the Aboriginal Development Commission which recognised past dispossession and dispersal.

In 1980 there was acknowledgment by Ministers Chaney and Viner that there had been no divisive political argument on the justice of Aboriginal claims, or of the prior ownership of Aboriginals of the whole of Australia before British settlement. In 1981 Senator Peter Baume told the Parliament, `The Government is prepared to acknowledge prior ownership'. For God's sake! Minister after Minister under Fraser said these things, yet under the Leader of the Opposition there is a movement backwards. A member of the Liberal Party has the audacity to talk about land rights when the Liberal Party in New South Wales will rip the guts out of land rights legislation. The New South Wales Liberal Party leader campaigned about that during the election campaign. The National Party in New South Wales has been saying it for years. The honourable member has the audacity to talk about our land rights proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us a copy of the legal opinion. Let's hear it.

—We have a broken down suburban solicitor sitting at the table who cannot even read Hansard. I am normally a very placid person, but I greatly dislike it when people do not tell the truth. The fact is that the honourable member for Flinders put out a sleazy Press release-I am very disappointed in the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because he put his name to it, too-in which he misquoted me. He did not have the decency to quote me correctly. He used the trick of leaving out a few appropriate words. I have not misled the Parliament and the honourable member, as a lawyer, knows it. I was asked a specific question and I gave a specific answer. There is no doubt that I told the truth in this place. I ask him to read my answer. He has a great inability, apparently, to do that, or he had better get a new typist, because he left out the appropriate words. This was another of the sleazy exercises they engaged in during January when they selectively put out Press releases implying that people had misled the Parliament. It is not true.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the more important points which were raised by the shadow Minister. He talked about people being let down. I concede that. I have told him privately that it is my job to ensure, as best I can, that no one, whilst I am the Minister, lets anybody down. We are engaged in genuine consultations with Aboriginal people. In tours around the country and in the trip I have just undertaken regarding the new Commission, I was presented with a unique opportunity to talk to many members of the community about other questions-questions that went to the points the honourable member raised concerning the plight of people in terms of health, education and the frightful housing situation in this country. But it is simplistic in the extreme to say that these things can be fixed just like that. I have never said that they can be, and the shadow Minister knows that. The Government has never said that they can be fixed quickly. No Government, not even the previous Government, has ever said that.

It seemed to me-I do not know what the people listening thought-that the shadow Minister wanted all these things to fail. What is wrong with Aboriginal people having expectations? What is wrong with the Government saying, `We are going to try to eradicate illness in the Aboriginal community.'? What is wrong with the Government saying, `We are going to try our best to train 1,000 Aboriginal teachers.'? What is wrong with saying, `We are going to house all the Aboriginal people.'? What is wrong with saying, `We are going to try to create 48,000 jobs for the unemployed in the Aboriginal community.'? What is wrong with adopting that approach? There is nothing wrong with it. It is honourable to say that we are going to try to achieve these things. The shadow Minister ought to wander around a bit further from his home town than he has in the few selective visits he has made. As has occurred in the past, my Department will make every effort to ensure that he sees everything he needs to see, wherever he goes.

Another point that has been made concerns the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The shadow Minister came to me as the spokesperson for his Party. During a break in the consultations-after about one hour and 45 minutes of briefing by me on the first half of the consultations-I said, `I will make available to you all the necessary information, all the minutes of the meetings, all the discussion papers and every conceivable thing I have at my disposal about this proposal we put forward to the Parliament'. Why? Because there is nothing to hide, because we want to get it right, and prove to the whole of Australia, through the Liberal Party and through my Party, that we will get this right. What has happened? It is as though that offer was never made and we are trying to hide something. I say to the shadow Minister again that that information is available to his Party, as it will be made available to the National Party, if it so desires, and certainly to the Australian Democrats. That offer still stands. There will be nothing to hide in this amalgamation.

The amalgamation will bring together four areas of government, namely, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the ADC, Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. The shadow Minister knows that. He said in his remarks that he welcomed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not exactly a quote.

—The shadow Minister made the point that he had some reservations about certain aspects, namely, the preamble. I acknowledge that. In the discussions I had with him about the treaty, the compact, the makarrata, the agreement-whatever it is that the people in the Aboriginal community and the rest of the Australian community determine to agree upon-I said to him, `Why don't we keep out of it? Why don't the politicians, for a change, keep out of the debate?'. Why do we not let the community-that is, the Aboriginal community and the non-Aboriginal community-discuss this issue and stop muddying the waters, like politicians normally do on these issues? We should keep away, let the community have the discussion, and then have the political debate. But we should not try to kill it off, like he and his Party are trying to do now. The honourable member cannot welcome something on the one hand and then go about undermining that statement on the other hand by saying, `We don't need a reconciliation, a treaty or a compact', thus undermining the discussion before it is properly off the ground.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the plea again to the Opposition to give it a go. What is wrong with allowing the community outside Canberra, where the people live, to have a discussion about this important issue? The important issue before us is the treaty or the compact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you release the documents then? No answer to that.

—The honourable member might get away with that behaviour in a suburban court where he comes from while arguing about land deals, but even his former leader in the upper House in Victoria gave him away, so I am not terribly worried by him. The point about it is: why do we not give it a chance out there in the community? How can members of the Opposition say that this is unacceptable or will be unacceptable to the Australian community before it has even discussed the issue? It is elitist in the extreme for them to come in here and say that this is unachievable. I believe that the Australian community desires this discussion to take place. I believe, from my discussions with people and from the many letters that the Department and the Government have received, that there is a desire by people to give it a go, to talk about it, to question, to find out about Aboriginal culture, to look beyond 200 years, to question what did occur in that period of 200 years and to see whether an agreement can be reached between us. I see nothing wrong with that at all.

SPEECH.PARA: But, no; members of the Opposition are back in the bunker and they have decided that it is not on. They are going to do everything they can to undermine it. It gets back to my original concept; that is, it seems as though members of the Opposition want these things to fail. I say to members of the Opposition again, irrespective of what the honourable member for Flinders who is at the table says, that I expected better of them. In recent times their Press releases have been following the normal pattern of opposition as though they are obligated to oppose everything the Government wants to do.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) asks what is wrong with his approach. Let me tell the Minister, chapter and verse, what is wrong with his approach. The fact of the matter is that he came into this Parliament on 10 December last year and said, `Joy, oh joy, you are going to have a preamble'. He described it as an historic and significant declaration that was going to be the hallmark of his policy. Since then he has dropped it like a hot potato. That is the first thing wrong with the Minister. He has no capacity to follow it through.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. What the honourable member has said is not true.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—On a further point of order--
—Order! Does the Minister have a further point of order?
—On a further point of order: I seek your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Will the Minister get to his point of order.

—In terms of the point of order, if a member comes into the House and states something which is blatantly untrue, does another member have the right to object at that point, or should that other member raise--
—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister can make a personal explanation at a later time in the debate.

—The second thing that is wrong with this Minister's approach is that he comes in all sweetness and light, with all reason to prevail, and the reality is that he has misled this Parliament on an essential part of the policy which he has been putting to this Parliament. The reality is that when he says, `Let us have a public debate about this matter', he says that--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that my understanding as to this debate is that there was to be one speaker from each side of the House. We seem to be in a position where there is a second speaker--
—Order! The Chair is not aware of any arrangements that have been arrived at by the parties. If a member stands, the Chair is required to call the member.

—For all this talk about encouraging debate, the Minister does not tell the Australian electorate-but let me inform the Australian electorate now-that, when I ask him for some documentation to support his position and the legal opinions that he has received on this issue, up go the shutters. I am in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal trying to get some documents out of this Minister. I go to other Ministers and ask them for some documents and what do they say? They say, `The documents exist but, of course, you cannot have them'. That is the reality of his idea of informed debate. He has the information but there is no release of the documents. That is why the matter is going off on appeal.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put this whole matter into some context. On 7 December 1987 this Minister goes to the Cabinet with a submission. The submission is that he will introduce legislation which will have some introductory comments in it, to be known as a preamble. Included in that Cabinet submission, as is often the situation, are some attachments. The attachments have within them some comments from the Attorney-General's Department. They are called co-ordination comments. On the same day, as a result of discussions presumably within the Cabinet, advice is obtained from a leading Queen's Counsel in Melbourne. How do I know that advice has been obtained? Because the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has told me in writing.

Honourable members can imagine the situation. Members of the Cabinet have this proposal before them and it is a pretty complicated sort of legal area. There is a case in the High Court of Australia. One of the members of the Cabinet says, `Look, Gerry, we know that you are full of good intentions, but I think we ought to just see what are the legal implications of all this'. Members of the Cabinet have a look at the advice prepared by the Attorney-General's Department and someone says, `Look, I would like a bit more advice on this'. It seems that someone rings Mr Graham, QC, in Melbourne and obtains advice. I know, because the Attorney-General has told me, that that advice is communicated to the Attorney-General. So the picture is that on 7 December there was, apparently, a seven-hour heated discussion in Cabinet about the Minister's proposal.

What happens then? The Attorney-General gets the advice, presumably, from one of his departmental officers and probably Mr McDonald, who has been handling the matter. The Attorney-General says, `Look, I will be going back into the Cabinet with this advice from the Queen's Counsel, but I think we had better cover the situation. You, Mr McDonald, prepare a memo and send it down to Mr Graham to confirm what Mr Graham has told us, so that we have it in writing'. The Attorney-General waltzes into Cabinet with a copy of the fax which has been sent down to the Queen's Counsel and says--

TALK.START.PARA: —On what date was that?

—It was on 7 December. The Attorney-General says to the Cabinet, `Look, we have the co-ordination comments'-which, I might add, are prepared by a legally qualified member of the Attorney-General's Department and, I might further add, have been the subject of a freedom of information request.

SPEECH.PARA: Why has the request for them been refused? The ground of exemption claimed is that legal opinion and professional privilege status applies to the documents. Here we have co-ordination comments, legal opinions prepared by the Attorney-General's Department and a copy of the fax which has been sent down so that the Attorney-General has got himself covered in terms of the advice that was received orally from the Queen's Counsel in a hurried consultation over the phone because members of the Cabinet were considering the matter and they wanted to have the best possible advice before they made a decision. That happened on 7 December. There was a Cabinet decision with the benefit of advice from a member of the Attorney-General's Department and a senior barrister in Melbourne-a Queen's Counsel, a silk.

On 10 December in comes the Minister with his proposal. He announces it in the morning. At Question Time the Opposition asks both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs two very simple questions-the same question to each. The question is: `You have introduced a preamble proposal this morning. What legal advice have you got on the implications of it?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true. Quote what I said.

—I can quote it to the Minister, chapter and verse. I will give him the documents. He can read it. It is all there clear as day, chapter and verse, in black and white. It is as clear a case as one could possibly get. He comes in with his answer on that day, 10 December, only three days after Cabinet considered the matter. Surely there will be no excuses about poor memory in terms of what advice members of the Cabinet had when they considered it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister was very generous in his response. He said that he did not have any advice whatsoever. That is not right because the Minister wrote to him at the end of October with a copy of his submission. In that submission, as advised to me by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, there were comments on the legal implications and/or consequences of the preamble. So the Prime Minister is not off on this one as yet. That is the situation. The Prime Minister says that he has not had any advice whatsoever. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is a bit more careful either because presumably he has been talking directly to the Attorney-General's Department-he nods his head-or because his advisers have been talking to the Attorney-General's Department because of the co-ordination comments. He is very careful. As recorded on page 3196 of the Daily Hansard, he said:
I received no specific advice of a legal nature on that point. I did, however, receive a lot of advice from a number of people on the question of this proposal.

And off he went. That is no misrepresentation; it appears in Hansard and I have given a copy of it to the Minister. Today I asked a very simple question of the Attorney-General. I told the Attorney-General that his Department was providing the legal advice that the Minister and the Prime Minister say they have never received. I asked the Attorney-General what advice was given on this preamble. What was the Attorney-General's reply? He said:

I recall that the honourable member was suggesting that an opinion was available at the time the Cabinet made the decision. That was not the case, except for the co-ordination comment from my Department.

That is where the Government was in error in the first place. The Attorney-General cannot say `except for the co-ordination comment' because that is the legal opinion. The best answer the Government now has is, `Here is a legal opinion but it is not a legal opinion'. When is a legal opinion a legal opinion? Is it when it is produced by the Attorney-General's Department? Is a legal opinion such a document when prepared by a qualified legal officer of the Attorney-General's Department? Is it not a legal opinion when the Government claims that the Opposition cannot have it because it is a legal opinion? The reality is that the Minister and his colleagues have been replying to my freedom of information application and telling me I cannot have the documents. However, the good thing is that they have been telling me what the documents are and what they contain. The reality is that on that day, 7 December 1987, the Cabinet had before it legal advice on the proposals. The documents prove it. When the Minister came into the House on 10 December and said that he had no legal advice, the reality was that he did. I have the documents to prove it and now the Minister has a copy of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset may I address some of the comments made by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) in what can only be described as a diatribe. The Government has cooperated in consultations with those opposite in a bipartisan endeavour to solve some of the difficulties faced by Aboriginal people in this country. It is appalling that the honourable member could speak only about legal opinions and freedom of information, with not one phrase in relation to the better standards of living that Aboriginal people deserve.
—Because they don't care.

—There is no doubt that they do not understand. Aboriginal affairs has always been a sensitive and contentious issue. If the attitude shown by Opposition members continues, the position will only deteriorate. Who will be the meat in the sandwich? Who is the pawn in this game? The shadow spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), was appalling and pathetic in the attitude he displayed to the matter before the House. Let us consider those who really require us as a nation, as government, including members of the Opposition, to address the difficulties they face and to come forward with a positive and constructive method of overcoming them. It is interesting to note the recent media approach of the shadow Minister. He is condemning the preamble; he said that it could be used to undermine the constitutional framework of Australia. The coalition condemns the Government's reckless disregard for possible legal consequences. That certainly addresses the difficulties of the Aboriginal people. I find it somewhat difficult to follow through, but the shadow Minister sees some difficulty in the preamble that has been mentioned. We must start somewhere-and I commend the work of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in this regard-but Opposition members are prepared to simply sit on their hands, as they did for so many decades when they were in office.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the shadow Minister's comment about the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) dropping the proposal for a treaty. Once again, that is a very negative approach to Aboriginal affairs. Unfortunately, the honourable member for Flinders had some difficulty in reading the proposition; if he did read it, he certainly did not speak to it. It referred to raising the expectations of the Aboriginal people. Members of the Opposition will never be guilty of that, because they give the Aboriginal people nought and expect them to get nought. It is a disgrace. The bipartisanship that should be shown in this area has been undermined in a disgraceful and despicable manner by members of the Opposition.

Let us look at the question of the Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme (ABSEC). What has the Opposition done about that? Once again, an extremely positive contribution of nothing! According to the shadow Minister, ABSEC is a proposal the Government is promoting for the use of Department of Aboriginal Affairs boundaries, ignoring tribal and cultural affiliations, with State-based zones not being acceptable. If the shadow Minister knew what was going on in this nation, he would know he is wrong on every count. He cannot get anything right. He sits in the House with a smirk on his face, worrying about nothing. What about the Aboriginal people? I say to him, `Put a smirk on your face and go out and address them'. ABSEC is an attempt by this Government to address some of the difficulties faced by the Aboriginal people. Time and again the Minister has said-and I will repeat it for the benefit of the shadow Minister-that ABSEC will not be proceeded with if the Aboriginal people are not in favour of it. As a result, consultation is taking place throughout the nation at a grassroots level, not by sitting back in the party room despicably planning how to undermine positive steps for the welfare of Aborigines.

The Government does not do things in the comfort of the party room in Canberra; it goes out and speaks to the Aboriginal people, their delegates and leaders, and those at the grassroots level. In the past three or four months the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has had more consultation on these matters than any former Minister who held that portfolio. The Government will act on the feedback being received from the Aboriginal people. As I have heard the Minister say on more than one occasion, the shadow Minister is welcome to have access to the minutes of the meetings and to the attitudes expressed by Aborigines. If he wants to do his job half properly, I suggest that he avail himself of that information, because everything he says, and every document emanating from his office, is wrong on every count. The bipartisanship which should not be in question in issues such as this has been undermined. We are going backwards. Again I ask: Who are the pawns in this game? It is not the Government; it is not Opposition members, who have a negative approach to any suggestion; it is the Aboriginal people themselves.

I find it appalling-to be honest, quite sickening-that the shadow Minister can come into this House and simply blurt out negative responses to any suggestion to create a future for Aborigines. The proposal before the House has a stench about it. It follows upon the disgraceful and despicable discussions and decisions of the New South Wales colleagues of those opposite, who intend to take away the rights for which Aborigines have fought over centuries. This matter was proposed to simply dress up the retrograde and negative steps that will be taken by the New South Wales coalition parties as a result of their recent election victory. Mr Wal Murray, the Leader of the National Party in New South Wales, should be condemned for his comments on Aboriginal people and their rights. However, I know that the mentality of cockies is such-and we have witnessed this for many decades-that they go into the streets and say to people, `If we give the Aborigines a bit of land today, tomorrow it will be your farm'. That is the negative and unrealistic approach of the National Party. I do not wish to comment further. The proposition is baseless and hollow. It has a stench about it. It is simply an attempt to dress up the decisions made by the Opposition's colleagues in New South Wales.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The proposed Admiralty Bill will give Australia, for the first time, a comprehensive, up to date, locally enacted and uniform law governing the exercise of admiralty jurisdiction by Australian courts. The law will replace existing Imperial legislation. In the bicentennial year it is appropriate that we remove one further piece of old, inherited British legislation from our statute book and replace it with legislation specifically designed for Australian conditions. This the Bill is designed to do. The Bill follows the recommendations contained in report No. 33 on civil admiralty jurisdiction prepared by the Australian Law Reform Commission and issued at the end of 1986. That report followed a reference given to the Commission by the former coalition Government in 1982.

The need for reform in this area has been recognised over a long period. A Joint Committee of the Maritime Law Association of Australia and New Zealand and the Law Council of Australia, with Justice Zelling as Chairman, in 1982 had produced a joint report on reform of admiralty jurisdiction. The Law Reform Commission was required to have regard to this report in its consideration of the matter. It received as well input from other maritime and legal bodies, State governments and individuals whom it consulted in the preparation of the report. All were agreed on the need for reform of admiralty law. The report is a comprehensive analysis of admiralty jurisdiction and the Government, in seeking reactions to the report, found widespread support for early implementation of the recommendations contained in it. I commend the Commission for its report, which has been widely praised.

Admiralty has long been a distinct jurisdiction in the court system. Business expectations rely on the fact that jurisdiction over ships and shipowners will be asserted in special ways. Australia is principally a country of shippers rather than shipowners and is dependent on foreign shipping for much of its import and export trade. It is, therefore, in Australia's interest to support a broad admiralty jurisdiction which is dependent principally on the presence in the jurisdiction of the ship or sister ship in relation to which a maritime claim arises. The proposed legislation, therefore, asserts a broad admiralty jurisdiction but at the same time takes account of international trends and remains within internationally acceptable limits.

Admiralty jurisdiction exercised by the courts has its own distinctive features. The key feature is the ability it provides to bring an action in rem-that is, the power to arrest a ship, including foreign ships, within the jurisdiction of a state and to use that ship as security for a maritime claim. Actions in rem arise from the existence of a maritime lien or a statutory right of action based on a proprietary or general maritime claim arising under the general law and involving the ownership or operation of ships.

The Bill also provides for admiralty jurisdiction to be exercised in relation to claims in personam-that is, claims directed against a specific person-in relation to maritime claims or claims for damage to a ship. The Bill does not attempt a substantive overhaul of the law. It does not, for instance, create new causes of action or, with the exception of clause 34, create new substantive rights, as distinct from creating new procedures. The Bill, therefore, seeks to clarify what claims are subject to admiralty jurisdiction and which courts can exercise that jurisdiction. It is proposed that the Federal Court of Australia as well as the State and Territory supreme courts be invested with admiralty jurisdiction.

I turn now to address the significant features of the proposed legislation. Maritime claims are defined in detail in clause 4. A distinction is made between proprietary maritime claims and general maritime claims. Proprietary claims involve claims relating to ownership or possession of a ship. General maritime claims include a wide range of claims arising from the operation of a ship. The legislation retains the existing distinction in admiralty law that exists between actions in rem based on maritime liens and statutory rights of action in rem based on causes of action arising under the general law and involving the ownership or operation of ships. It confers a right to proceed in rem over claims involving maritime liens in clause 15 but does not seek to codify or define the substantive law governing maritime liens. Their traditional priority, ranking ahead of other maritime claims, is maintained.

The scope of the statutory right of action in rem is defined exhaustively and in detail. The circumstances in which claims in rem can be brought on maritime claims are set out in clauses 16 to 19. These clauses outline the nexus between a ship and the relevant person against whom the claim arises which is required before an action in rem can be brought. Provision is made in clause 19 for the first time in Australian law for arrest of surrogate or sister ships. This is a feature of admiralty law in certain other countries, including the United Kingdom and New Zealand.

Admiralty jurisdiction in personam is conferred in clause 9 with respect to maritime claims and in addition with respect to claims for damage done to a ship. Concurrent jurisdiction in admiralty is conferred on the Federal Court and State and Territory supreme courts. Appeals will proceed through the Full Court or Court of Appeal of the relevant Federal, State or Territory court to the High Court of Australia under the ordinary rules governing appeals from the respective courts. The experience of the State supreme courts in admiralty matters is preserved.

Provision is made for the promulgation of uniform admiralty rules, applicable to all admiralty actions. There is provision for a rules committee with a judge of the Federal Court and a supreme court to advise the Attorney-General on the rules and possible amendment to them. The rules will be made by the Governor-General-in-Council and will be subject to disallowance by the Parliament. The Bill will remove the uncertainty that arises from the continued application of old Imperial legislation. In particular, the 1890 Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act will cease to operate in Australia. A number of other old Imperial enactments are repealed. The Bill makes a number of minor consequential amendments to the Navigation Act 1912 and the Shipping Registration Act 1981.
Financial Impact Statement
The financial impact of the legislation is expected to be minimal. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In line with the Government's commitment to ensure that the National Crime Authority has all the necessary powers at its disposal to fulfil its functions, subsections 219a to k of the Customs Act 1901 are being amended to provide the NCA with the same powers as the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to apply for a judicial warrant for the use of a listening device in the investigation of narcotics offences. The abuse of both legal and illegal drugs is acknowledged as one of Australia's most serious social and law enforcement problems. As exemplified by the national campaign against drug abuse, the Commonwealth Government, together with the State and Territory governments, is committed to fighting drug abuse on both fronts.

The National Crime Authority's primary function is to assemble and furnish admissible evidence to Commonwealth and State prosecuting agencies. Its concern over drug trafficking, as a major profit earning activity of organised crime, is reflected in the fact that the majority of its eight references and of its general investigations involve drug-related offences. In order to perform its functions effectively and efficiently, the National Crime Authority, as with any law enforcement agency, needs to have at its disposal the most effective investigative techniques. Over recent years it has been recognised that traditional methods of detecting and investigating criminal activity are rarely successful against the increasingly sophisticated techniques of organised crime. Electronic surveillance techniques such as telephone interception and listening devices have now emerged as an invaluable investigative tool in this area. Overseas experience, particularly in the United States of America, has confirmed that such a useful tool should be available to all agencies investigating organised crime, especially in relation to drug trafficking.

If we are to be successful in our efforts to attack major drug trafficking networks, it is important that the NCA be put in the same position as the Australian Federal Police and State police in having available the most appropriate, up-to-date techniques. Listening devices have made key contributions in a number of major narcotics investigations undertaken by the Australian Federal Police, for example in the Paltos case. The amendments to subsections 219a to k of the Customs Act 1901 also clarify the disclosure provisions for information obtained by use of a listening device under warrant for the purpose of conducting legal proceedings, in particular to ensure that prosecution authorities and defence counsel are able to be provided with the necessary information for the conduct of the proceedings. The amendments will also extend the disclosure of such information to applications for orders in confiscation proceedings under the Proceedings of Crime Act 1987 and to extradition proceedings. This is consistent with the current provisions relating to confiscation proceedings under the Customs Act, and will contribute to law enforcement agencies' ability to deal effectively with major drug importation and related offences.

Part III of the Bill effectively makes five amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987-the MA Act. That Act provides the legislative basis for Australia to enter into and give effect to treaties and arrangements with other countries whereby it can request or grant assistance in criminal matters. The assistance relates both to the investigation and prosecution of crime. The range of assistance covered by the legislation includes provision of evidence, documents and articles, location and identification of witnesses, execution of requests for search and seizure, and tracing, freezing and seizure of proceeds of crime. A number of implementation problems with the MA Act emerged during recent treaty negotiations with other countries. All but one of the five amendments proposed in this Bill are to redress those problems.

The first amendment is for the purpose of expanding the current definitions of `Australian forfeiture order' and `foreign forfeiture order' in the MA Act. These amendments are consequential upon amendments to the statutory forfeiture provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act-PC Act-whereby an Australian court can make a declaration that automatic statutory forfeiture of property has occurred. Under section 30 of the PC Act statutory forfeiture occurs where a restraining order made against property of the defendant is still in force six months after the defendant's conviction of a `serious offence' as defined by the PC Act. Such a declaration can then be recognised for enforcement purposes by a foreign court pursuant to a request by the Attorney-General under section 32 of the MA Act as a judicial order for the purposes of executing an MA request by Australia. A further amendment will enable a similar declaration by a foreign court, where the law of the particular foreign country has equivalent `automatic' forfeiture procedures, to be registered and enforced by an Australian court pursuant to an authorisation by the Attorney-General under section 34 of the MA Act.

The second amendment is to include a definition of `political offence' in the MA Act. Offences of a political character are excluded from those for which assistance may be granted under Australia's extradition and mutual assistance legislation. Until recently it was left to the courts to determine whether an offence was of a political character. The Extradition Act 1988 now limits the offences which may qualify as political offences for extradition purposes. That limitation was to declare Australia's clear abhorrence of terrorist conduct and our unwillingness to withhold extradition to other countries seeking to bring to justice criminals whose serious or violent crimes have been allegedly perpetrated for ideological reasons.

The amendment is intended to achieve the same objectives in the field of international mutual assistance. Clause 13 of the Bill inserts a limiting definition of `political offence', and substitutes that expression for `offence of a political character' in the operative refusal of assistance provisions of the MA Act. The definition excludes from political offences crimes which have been recognised by the international community in multilateral treaties as being extremely serious-hijacking, safety of aircraft, genocide, torture, and the taking of hostages-and the protection of internationally protected persons. The definition also permits crimes to be excluded by way of regulation, such as crimes recognised in future multilateral conventions to which Australia becomes a party, crimes against heads of state or heads of government and crimes of violence committed in circumstances where a collective danger to innocent life is created.

The third amendment deals with the foreign law testimonial immunities of persons who give evidence in Australia as a result of a request by a foreign country or by Australia. Where a person gives evidence in Australia as a result of a request by a foreign country, the amendment confers on the person the testimonial immunities the person would have if giving evidence in the requesting country. Where a person consents to come to Australia temporarily to give evidence as a result of a request by Australia the amendment preserves the foreign law testimonial immunities which apply in the requested country. The amendment ensures that the person may refuse to answer a question or produce a document in the Australian proceedings on the grounds of a privilege, duty or obligation which does not apply before Australian courts, but which would enable or oblige the person to so refuse in proceedings in the person's own country. This is to remove concern that such a person, upon return to his own country, could be liable to civil or criminal action for breach of the duty or obligation on which the privilege is based. The amendment also provides for a certificate procedure to facilitate proof of, and application of, foreign law immunities in particular proceedings, together with a definition of `foreign law immunity certificate'.

The fourth amendment is to clarify the ambit of immunity from civil suit of a person when in another country to give evidence or assist in an investigation at the request of that country. The intention of the existing provisions is to ensure that advantage is not taken of the presence of the person for the purpose of civil proceedings in the requesting country. In particular, the intention is to protect the person from the commencement, continuation or enforcement of civil proceedings, which could not occur but for the presence of the person in that country. A number of countries have also expressed concern that the Act arguably protects the person even from suits which do not depend upon the person's presence. The proposed amendment will clarify and limit the immunity to that which was originally intended. The final amendment will ensure that the Attorney-General is able to grant a request where the foreign government gives an adequate undertaking of civil suit immunity, even though it falls short of an unconditional guarantee. Several foreign governments had doubted whether their authorities had the practical or legal competence to give what they regarded as the unconditional guarantee of civil suit immunity on their reading of the Act as presently worded.

Parts IV and V of the Bill contain amendments to the National Crime Authority Act 1984 and the National Crime Authority (Status and Rights of Chairman) Act 1984. The primary purpose of the amendments to the National Crime Authority Act is to enable the National Crime Authority to disseminate information relating to criminal activity or to security matters in a proper and timely way. The Authority's significant achievements to date in combating organised crime in Australia have resulted in a growing amount of unsolicited information relating to criminal activity being provided to the Authority by members of the public and other agencies. Under the present provisions of the National Crime Authority legislation the Authority has prescribed to it as one of its general functions, the dissemination to law enforcement agencies and designated persons, criminal information and intelligence related to `relevant criminal activity'. The Authority also has a clear discretion to furnish to law enforcement agencies any information that comes into its possession in the course of an investigation conducted by it, concerning the commission, or possible commission of a Commonwealth, State or Territory offence. The Authority has a similar discretion in respect of passing information to authorised authorities and persons responsible for taking civil remedies action arising out of offences against Commonwealth, State or Territory laws.

Much of the unsolicited information now being received by the Authority, however, falls outside the definition of `relevant criminal activity' in the Act and is not relevant to any investigation by the Authority. This has resulted in the Authority being unable to pass such information to the relevant law enforcement agency. This is clearly an undesirable situation. Accordingly, the amendments proposed to subsections 59 (7) and (8) are designed to enable the Authority to disseminate unsolicited information relating to criminal activity in a proper and timely manner.

A similar defect in the present Act has been highlighted in respect of the receipt by the Authority of information relevant to security, as that word is defined in section 4 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979. At present the Act does not provide the Authority with the power to transfer such information to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). Clearly it is desirable that such information when it is received should be passed by the Authority to ASIO in accordance with ASIO's functions. The proposed new subsection 59 (11) is designed to overcome this difficulty. Similar provisions exist in the telephone interception and Customs legislation. The amendments will also enable the Authority to delegate, by signed instrument, to a member or acting member or to a member of the staff of the Authority, its powers to furnish information under subsections 59 (7), (8) and (11). At present section 59 of the Act requires the Authority to meet to determine when information should be provided to another agency. It is appropriate that such decisions be delegated to ensure that where information is to be transferred, that action occurs with a minimum of delay.

The Government is also proposing an amendment to the National Crime Authority (Status and Rights of Chairman) Act 1984. This amendment is consequential upon the Government's recent announcement of its intention to recommend to the Governor-General in Council that the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Justice Stewart, be reappointed for an additional year. The amendment is required to ensure that the provisions of the Status and Rights of Chairman Act will apply to Mr Justice Stewart for the period of his reappointment. Part VI of the Bill amends the Telecommunications Interception Act 1979 to enable a certified copy of a warrant authorising the interception of telecommunications to be received in certain proceedings as if it were the original warrant. This provision will help to reduce the cost and inconvenience arising at present in connection with the secure transmission of original warrants. The amendment does not alter any rule of evidence which may apply in relation to proof of the issue of a warrant, except that the original warrant will not be required to be produced. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMPANIES AND SECURITIES COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the National Companies and Security Commission Amendment Bill 1988 is to amend section 21 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act 1979 so as to clarify the power of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to give a general direction to a division established by the Commission. In addition, the Bill will retrospectively validate any past directions to a division under section 21 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act. The Bill will not, however, necessarily operate retrospectively where a past direction under section 21 is the subject of court proceedings that are in progress when the amendment commences operation.

Section 21 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act in its present form permits the NCSC, by resolution, to direct that its functions or powers in relation to `a matter' be performed or exercised by a division of the NCSC. The purpose of section 21 is to enable the NCSC to make the most efficient use of the limited number of its members by delegating certain of its functions or powers to a smaller division.

The present Bill is necessary to overcome the doubt now cast on the provision by comments made by some members of the Full Court of the Supreme Court of Victoria, in a recent as yet unreported case-NCSC v. Sim, 23 February 1988-on the power of the NCSC to give a general direction to divisions. In that case it was said by those members that the reference to `a matter' in section 21 of the Act appeared to contemplate specificity in the resolution, and would not enable a general bestowal by the Commission of all its functions and powers upon a division.

The section if construed in this way would mean that the Commission's method of operating through divisions would be fettered in that each individual matter would require a specific direction. It would not be possible for the Commission to give a general direction to a division that it exercise or perform the powers or functions of the Commission.

It was not the intention that the ambit of section 21 be confined in this way. Indeed, since the formation of the Commission in 1979 it has been accepted practice for its standing divisions-which now comprise the companies, takeovers, executive, securities industry and futures industry divisions-to perform most of the Commission's day to day decision making functions. In addition, the Commission has given a general direction that all matters arising under the legislation for which it is responsible are able to be exercised by a relevant division.

It is also desirable that the amendment preserve the validity of past actions by a division of the Commission to avoid possible administrative dislocation and public confusion which would result if previous decisions or acts were to be nullified. However, to protect the rights of those persons who may have already begun proceedings against the Commission, the amendment will not apply in those cases to retrospectively validate the Commission's direction in question, except where the court decides that it would be just and equitable for the direction to be treated as valid.

The Bill, therefore, aims to redress any misconceptions about the intended operation of section 21 and endeavours to ensure that the Commission can conduct its business through its divisions by virtue of either general or specific grants of power. In accordance with the Commonwealth's obligations under the formal agreement establishing the cooperative companies and securities scheme, this Bill was approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities on 17 March 1988. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr White) adjourned.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill makes provision for amendments to Commonwealth Government conservation legislation to clarify and strengthen the protection afforded under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, known as the World Heritage Act. The Bill amends the definition of `identified property', which is protected by the World Heritage Act, to follow more closely the format of the Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage-the World Heritage Convention. Protection against damage or destruction is extended to property which the Commonwealth Government believes may be of World Heritage value and which is subject to an inquiry to determine World Heritage status.

The Bill also makes provision for some other amendments to the World Heritage Act to rectify problems that have arisen with its operation since its enactment in 1983. These include the provision of a ministerial power to appoint inspectors under the Act for the purpose of obtaining information concerning the making of proclamations and regulations or of determining possible breaches of the Act. Additionally, it is proposed that sections of the Act held invalid by the High Court in the Tasmanian dam case be repealed. The provisions in the Act regarding compensation are also to be simplified. The Bill also makes it clear that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 does not apply to action taken under the World Heritage Act nor to any submission by Australia of a heritage property as suitable for inscription on the World Heritage List.

Before examining the provisions of the Bill in detail, let me first explain what it is that makes World Heritage so important and, secondly, discuss the circumstances which make these proposed amendments imperative. The World Heritage Convention is the most important international expression of the need to protect and conserve the natural and cultural heritage for the benefit of the whole world. This Convention was adopted by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation General Conference at its seventeenth session in Paris on 19 November 1972. The Convention came into force on 7 December 1975. It promotes cooperation among nations to protect areas and buildings which are of such outstanding universal value that their conservation is of concern to humanity generally. Australia was the seventh country to ratify the Convention in August 1974. Since then the number of parties to the Convention has steadily increased; 100 countries from all parts of the world are now parties. The Convention is the world's most successful instrument for the promotion of heritage conservation.

Parties to the Convention commit themselves to help in the identification, protection, conservation and presentation of World Heritage properties. In addition, the Convention provides an objective system for identifying those natural and cultural heritage properties within membercountries which are of outstanding universal value for all the world. The Convention also establishes a list of such properties. This list is known as the World Heritage List.
