The Convention is intended to ensure that, unlike most of the seven wonders of the ancient world, properties on the World Heritage List will be preserved for all time.

The conditions which have to be satisfied before any property is inscribed on the World Heritage List are extensive. First, the property must satisfy the definition of World Heritage specified in Articles 1 or 2 of the Convention. Secondly, nominations for listing must meet detailed criteria adopted by the World Heritage Committee, the policy and decision making body under the Convention, as part of its operational guidelines for the implementation of the Convention. In the case of natural heritage, nominations must also satisfy certain conditions of integrity. In assessing new nominations, the World Heritage Committee is assisted by professional organisations which provide impartial technical advice on the World Heritage nominations. The International Council for Monuments and Sites and the International Centre for Conservation in Rome are the advisory bodies for cultural sites, while the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) advises on natural properties. Normally, the expert advice provided by these bodies would be based not only on an analysis and evaluation of the written nomination against the criteria but also on an inspection and assessment of the nominated property itself. Often internationally acknowledged scientists are also invited to act as referees for a nomination related to the natural environment.

Not all nominations are successful. Of the 63 nominations scheduled for consideration by the Committee at its 1987 meeting only 41, or approximately 65 per cent, were accepted for inscription on the World Heritage List.

There are now 288 places on the World Heritage List. They include the Pyramids of Egypt, the Grand Canyon of the United States, the Taj Mahal of India, Chartres Cathedral in France and the Sagarmatha National Park, containing Mount Everest, in Nepal. Australian properties on the World Heritage List are the Great Barrier Reef, stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu National Park, the Willandra Lakes Region of Western New South Wales, the Lord Howe Island group off the coast of New South Wales, the Australian east coast temperate and sub-tropical rainforest parks-the New South Wales rainforests-the western Tasmania wilderness national parks and the Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park.

This Hawke Labor Government has a record second to none in its commitment to the environment and to heritage conservation. The Australian community increasingly looks to the Commonwealth Government to continue this role, in particular in relation to Australian properties which form part of the World Heritage. In most cases, this is being achieved in close collaboration with the States and Territories. It is an unfortunate fact, however, that this is not always the case. The area known as the wet tropical rainforest of north-east Australia, nominated by Australia in December 1987 for inclusion in the World Heritage List, has been identified for a number of years both nationally and internationally as being of World Heritage value. Despite this, the Queensland Government continues to oppose the nomination. In the Commonwealth Government's opinion, there is no doubt that this area, also known as the north Queensland rainforests, will be an appropriate and deserving addition to the World Heritage List. Independent studies indicate that the rainforests conform to the definition of natural heritage in article 2 of the Convention. Indeed, the best evidence suggests that they meet not only one but all four of the criteria set down for establishing outstanding universal value.

The north Queensland rainforests contain the highest concentration of primitive flowering plant families on earth, are home to a high diversity of animal life including a number of threatened species, and hold important clues to the origin, evolution and migration of flowering plants. The region also has many features of outstanding natural beauty, with waterfalls, deep gorges, fast flowing rivers and mountainous peaks. The Government believes that the wet tropical rainforests also qualify for the World Heritage List on cultural grounds. The only remaining recognised Australian Aboriginal rainforest culture is found in the wet tropics. The area has been recommended for World Heritage nomination by the Australian Heritage Commission and is included in the IUCN's list of the world's most outstanding natural areas. As long ago as November 1984 the General Assembly of IUCN called upon the Australian and Queensland governments to `overcome current difficulties' and nominate the wet tropical rainforests to the World Heritage List. The area has been acclaimed by internationally recognised scientists from all over the world.

Against this background the Queensland Government has consistently refused to consider World Heritage nomination and has maintained that rainforest logging should continue. The Commonwealth Government had no option, therefore, but to nominate the area and ban rainforest logging. This course was essential to fulfil Australia's obligations under the World Heritage Convention. Even after the formal nomination by Australia, the Queensland Government has publicly stated that it will strongly resist changing its normal forestry management practices in north Queensland. While forestry operations in the north Queensland rainforests have presently ceased because of the onset of the wet season, under normal practice operations would resume in April of this year. In the Government's view such forestry operations would clearly damage or destroy the integrity of the nominated World Heritage area as a whole or particularly valuable features of it.

The amended World Heritage Act will make it absolutely clear that the north Queensland rainforests are afforded interim protection under that Act pending a decision by the World Heritage Committee on whether to include them on the World Heritage List. The World Heritage Committee is the appropriate body to determine once and for all whether the north Queensland rainforests constitute natural heritage of outstanding universal value-for all the world. The Committee will make that determination at its next meeting in November 1988. It will do so with the advice of independent experts who will have inspected and assessed the area and who will have discussed the matter with both the Commonwealth and Queensland governments.

Prior to that determination by the World Heritage Committee it is essential that the area be afforded protection under the Act. It would be ridiculous if the World Heritage Committee decided later this year to inscribe the north Queensland rainforests on the World Heritage List and Australia had allowed those same rainforests to be irreparably damaged during the year of nomination. If, in the unlikely event that the Committee agreed with the Queensland Government and refused to inscribe either all or part of the area on the World Heritage List, then under the proposed amendments protection under the Act would cease.

I turn now to the Bill itself. As noted, the major consideration is the clarification and strengthening of the World Heritage Act. `Identified property', the property protected under the Act, is to be redefined to be more in line with the format of the Convention itself. Identified property would be property subject to any of the following: first, a Commonwealth inquiry to determine whether or not it is World Heritage; secondly, a World Heritage nomination by Australia; thirdly, World Heritage listing; or finally, if it is property which is World Heritage and which is declared by regulation to be identified property. In other words, the Act would follow the three stages of the World Heritage Convention: identification of property, nomination and listing. Interim protection would be afforded at each stage. This would cease, however, if the property ceased to be identified. The ultimate World Heritage test would be left to the appropriate and proper authority-the World Heritage Committee. The existing provision to identify property by regulation is to be retained, although in such cases protection will depend for its efficacy on the establishment, as a matter of fact, that an area is of outstanding universal value within the meaning of the Convention.

Another provision to strengthen the Act is a ministerial power to appoint inspectors. Inspectors' powers will relate to obtaining information relevant to making a proclamation or regulations under the Act, or determining whether an unlawful act has been, is being or is likely to be committed. The circumstances in which inspectors may enter places to exercise their powers are restricted under the Act. Inspectors may enter land or buildings only if they obtain the consent of the person in charge or a judge's warrant, or if there is an urgency requirement. An inspector has no authority in any circumstances to enter a person's home or dwelling. It is not the Government's intention to take away or diminish the rights of private citizens.

The proposed amendments also drastically simplify the procedure to be followed when the operation of the Act results in an acquisition of property within the meaning of paragraph 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution. There will be two stages only: negotiation on a reasonable amount of compensation; and, failing agreement, determination of the amount by the Federal Court of Australia. It is also proposed to repeal sections of the Act held invalid by the High Court in the Tasmanian dam case. These are paragraphs 9 (1) (a) to (g) and subsection 9 (2). Part III of the Bill relates to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. The Bill makes it clear that the Act does not apply, and is taken never to have applied, to action taken under the World Heritage Act or to any submission by Australia of a heritage property as suitable for inscription on the World Heritage List.

Finally, in part IV of the Bill, the existing proclamation and regulations under the Act relating to the north Queensland rainforests are taken never to have had effect. It is the Government's intention to seek a new proclamation and regulations in identical terms to be promulgated pursuant to the amended legislation. These provisions, along with clause 5, are designed to place the protection of the north Queensland rainforests during 1988 on a more appropriate footing in the light of their nomination in December 1987 for inscription on the World Heritage List. The amended legislation would enable the rainforests to be protected on the basis that the World Heritage Committee is considering the nomination. The repeal of the proclamation and regulations will not weaken the protection of the rainforests. It is also not intended to affect any accrued rights that there might be.

This Bill strengthens the protection afforded by the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act to follow more closely the format of the World Heritage Convention. It should also be seen as a measure of the Commonwealth Government's determination to protect World Heritage, particularly the wet tropical rainforests of north-east Australia. I present the explanatory memorandum and I commend the Bill to the House.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ironic that probably the most important Bill to come into this House for a long time-the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, which contravenes many of the old principles that governments in this place have applied-is supported by the presence in this chamber of only two Government members. One would have thought that the Government's determination to bring this into law would have commanded the support of all its members. I can only suggest that those members who are not here would be too embarrassed to come in here to hear this Government bringing forward this matter at any time, let alone at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition generally is appalled by the legislation, and I think this was demonstrated during the debate in the Senate. Today we are being asked to finalise this Bill, which was introduced on only 25 February without any consultation with the States and after very little consultation with the people. I understand that the Bill is to be passed into law by 1 April.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pure arrogance.

—Pure arrogance. We are appalled, and there is anger and resentment within the electorate in Queensland and, I think, throughout the rest of Australia. I think I can comfortably say that all Tasmanian members would like to take part in this debate, and that Western Australian members are greatly concerned about this legislation. I know that all Queensland Liberal Party and National Party members would give their eye teeth to have an opportunity to debate this legislation.
—The people made a comment on Saturday.

—Yes, that comment was made on Saturday during the New South Wales election. It was made through the power of the ballot box. The people of New South Wales understood that they had been left right out of it by the Labor factions. The people demonstrated how they felt about environmental and other matters. We have only limited time to debate this legislation properly and to give all members on both sides an opportunity to let us know what their feelings are and tell us whether they have been to the area in question. Government members are embarrassed, as their absence from this chamber at the moment indicates.

SPEECH.PARA: I describe this legislation as shotgun legislation, for this particular reason: the Government has embarked upon a course of stepping over the rights of States and individuals. In case the decisions it has had from the High Court of Australia do not subsequently stand up, this shotgun approach will pick up the people who might have missed out on the legal decisions made so far. Because it is shotgun legislation inspectors will be appointed. I say inspectors advisedly because they will be policemen for the Government. In the other House they were referred to as `Richardson's greenjackets'. I assume that was meant as a comparison with the jackets that were evident in Gestapo Germany. The inspectors will probably have the same powers as Gestapo officers.

This is shotgun legislation because it will take away from the courts of this country the power to make decisions on what is an Australian matter. It is shotgun legislation because it will not provide any real power to ensure that the Commonwealth will probably compensate people for the losses they incur. It is shotgun legislation because now more than ever the Government will not have to consult with people, to return to the grass roots. Least of all will it have to consult with the constituent States.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might after last Saturday.

—I should think that Government members would be thinking very deeply on that. When reflecting about what happened at last Saturday's New South Wales State election some members of the Government might be having second thoughts on this. I regard this legislation as shotgun legislation because it picks up what the Government missed out on with its jack boots diplomacy. The Government is ignoring the rights of individuals and making political decisions to win votes rather than for the good of the people. This legislation was guillotined in the Senate so that we could debate it in this House at this late stage. As a result, I fear that the members of the conservative parties in this House, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, who would wish to participate fully in the debate will not be given that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to remind honourable members of the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who said in this House that he wished to make it clear to all Australians that there would not be any capital gains tax. We all know what happened about that. I meant to make it clear to the Government that the coalition opposes this legislation and we will fight it to the end in the time that has been made available. It is my opinion-and it is my opinion only-that when the coalition returns to office it will repeal this ghastly legislation. The legislation is unnecessary and offensive.

As recently as 10 March the High Court of Australia delivered a decision in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests issue in which it indicated clearly that the powers that are being sought in this legislation are already available to the Commonwealth. I ask why Senator Richardson and the Government persist with this legislation, which is considered by legal experts to be unnecessary. The reason that the Government thinks the legislation is necessary is that it wants to get the last drop out of this. It wants to grind the ordinary people of Australia, those who populate this country, who derive a living from it, and who are proud to be called Australians, into the dust-never to reappear. The Government wants to appoint an inspectorial service so that the demands from Canberra can be carried out in the backblocks of Australia. It seeks to adopt a scattergun approach to remove all the doubt and the opposition it has faced to this time.

The Government will do all these things by invading people's privacy and rights. The Government may even contemplate the reintroduction of the ID card is connection. We need more Commonwealth inspectors like we need holes in our heads. I invite Government members to ask doctors and pharmacists in this country what they think of health inspectors. Health inspectors go about their policing duties in such a way that they believe people are guilty until they prove their innocence. I invite Government members to ask any doctor or pharmacist within their electorates and to tell us of their findings. In this regard I mention also the taxation inspectors that are going around this country. Not a week passes without a complaint being made by a taxpayer about the dictatorial powers of inspectors; of their telephoning taxpayers' premises at 8 o'clock in the morning, 8 o'clock at night, or indeed any time, bypassing the taxation agent and going direct to the individual without even giving him the courtesy of representation or a face to face confrontation.

As I have said, we need such inspectors like we need holes in our heads. This Government is notorious for the manner in which it appoints inspectors to police this Commonwealth. We avoided the ID card only by the skin of our teeth. This legislation is offensive to me as an individual, and I believe it is offensive to every Australian who claims to have some pride as an Australian. The freedoms of our Constitution, which were established in 1901, are being interpreted in a manner that was never envisaged at that time. The legislation is offensive to the legal practices that we have followed in the past and the powers that have been conferred on the Commonwealth Government by the States in the original Constitution. It is offensive because the Government is going beyond the realms of possibility and righteousness.

The legislation offends the basic rights of the States. I understand the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) will contribute to this debate. As a Queenslander I ask him where his feelings lie in this regard so far as his State, his electorate and this Government are concerned. It has always been the practice for States to have the right to nominate and receive support from the Commonwealth for whatever is done. I have always believed that all six States of the Commonwealth have always been responsible in the discharge of their powers. We all know that for many years this Government has been prepared to take away completely the rights of the Territories, without any opportunity to prepare submissions in defence of any action to legislate laws involving those Territories. The Kakadu National Park stage 2 declaration springs readily to mind. In that case there was no consultation. The Northern Territory had to fight in its own right before the world body.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I make mention of the fact that on the Government side of the House a member is speaking with an adviser. That action is offensive to the rules of the House. There is a stranger in the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable member for Calare to resume his seat.
—Get on with it.

—I am getting on with it. This is exactly the practice we have had in this Parliament for so many years-the normal forms are offended. What I have drawn attention to is just one small example, among many others, of matters that we are trying to correct at the moment. The honourable member for Leichhardt thinks this is a laughing matter. I suggest that after the next ballot he will not be laughing as he is at the moment. This legislation offends the basic rights of the States, just as this Government seeks to offend against everything. The legislation offends against cooperative federalism. I thought that this Government came in on the great notion of consensus. In this particular case there has been no consensus and no consultation, which has been usual in previous cases.
—Oh!

—The Minister for the Arts and Territories grunts and says, `Oh'. I have no doubt that correspondence is available that suggests that Queensland Premier Ahern was quite prepared to meet with the Government to discuss this matter, yet no consultation took place.
—What about the past four years?

—I am talking about an Act that will be introduced on 1 April. Mr Ahern has been the Premier of Queensland for four months and no consultation has taken place whatsoever. It seems strange that in that period the coalition has had no trouble whatsoever consulting with Premier Ahern. We have received a very good hearing. That type of consultative process is lacking in this matter. There is reliance on external powers and this extension of those powers, I believe, was not envisaged by our founding fathers in 1901. These powers have been used to the extreme-to enable the Government to use a jack boot approach in regard to the powers of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is offensive as it demonstrates the hard line on conservation attitudes for Federal and New South Wales election purposes that did not pay off. I suggest to those who think that this Government has any sort of mandate to implement conservation powers that they look at the results of Saturday's election in New South Wales. The legislation is offensive also because of the basic assumption that the Opposition parties should be embarrassed by their history on conservation. I deny that. If one examines the list of those areas that have been placed on the World Heritage List, one will see that many were so declared by successive conservative governments after consultation and agreement with the States involved.

I take up the point of the power of the green vote in Australia. There has been one report on this subject by Dr Peter Coaldrake for the Queensland Chamber of Mines. In assessing the last Federal election he said that the claim by the conservationists that there was a massive response to their attitudes on conservation had been disproved. That is also supported by Morgan gallup poll research which indicates that at the very most environmental matters affected the result of the last election by one per cent. Perhaps that one per cent is very important to the honourable member for Leichhardt, because that is probably the percentage to which his majority was reduced in that last election.

I think it is reasonable to refer to the Coaldrake report in this debate. On the basis of Dr Coaldrake's research it is reasonable to state that there is no conclusive evidence to support the contention made by the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) and some others that the environmental lobby was responsible for determining the results of the last election. While Senator Richardson continues to cultivate the environmental vote, that did not have the actual result that was contemplated. It must be said that Senator Richardson's position could be regarded as the basis of a personal political strategy as much as a party strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you like conservationists?

—That is a very good point. The honourable member in his ignorance suggests that there is a hatred-this is the offence that we find in the Bill-by us of conservationists. Every Australian today has a greater awareness of conservation issues than we had 30 years ago. Our Party platform, our Party strategy, is based on that concern. One of the members who will follow me in this debate, the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), has had a greater interest in the environment and in these matters than the honourable member for Leichhardt or any of the other Labor members who are present at the moment have indicated during their political lifetime. The involvement of the Australian Labor Party in environmental matters is as slim as its numbers present in the House at the moment.
—We include people in our policy.

—That is right. That is a very important difference. We include people in our environmental policy. To suggest, as did the Labor Party member who, in his ignorance, interjected, that we have no environmental concerns, that we hate environmentalists, is to overlook completely that in the heart and mind of every conservative on this side of the House is a fundamental concern for conservation and the future of Australia. I think that that matter should be placed on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: The other result of the Coaldrake report that is also worth mentioning is that a survey of the membership of the Australian Conservation Foundation revealed that 2 per cent of ACF members were blue-collar workers. One might call them the true Labor voters. Three per cent of members were tradesmen. One could say that half of that number were Labor voters and half were conservative voters. Less than 5 per cent of members were in managerial positions-maybe we are the ones who might confess to having the vote of those in managerial positions-and 76 per cent were academic or professional people. That is where the strength of the greenie vote comes from-the universities and such places around Australia-and that is where most of the comments have been made in recent times.

If the Government wants to know of the power of the green vote, I suggest to all honourable members from New South Wales-they would be quite knowledgeable on this fact by now; it is four or five days since the State election-that they ask anyone about the power of the green vote in the State election. They will find exactly where that power lies. There was the most stunning rebuff to right wing Labor politics yet experienced in State politics in this nation. That shows exactly what the power of the green vote would be. During that election Labor had to come clean with the fact that in the last Federal election it received donations from certain lobbies in connection with environmental issues-donations that were not revealed in the course of that election. When Labor members talk about hard line conservation matters, I suggest that they look very hard at their own platform, their own performance, and the donations they have received.

There is a glimmer of hope in this matter because some members are questioning the Government's policy. The Sydney Morning Herald of 17 February reported that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) had moved that the Caucus executive and relevant political committees take-and I quote:
. . . full account of the recommendations of the Forestry and Land Resources section of the Department of Primary Industry, when considering National Park and World Heritage Listings.
The article continued:
The Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Kerin, said there was a need for a `constructive' approach to the environment, particularly in the south-east.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) also expressed similar reservations. According to the Sydney Morning Herald of 22 March, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said that an advisory body would be set up to ensure that new proposals would not lock up natural resources from development. He also said that weight should be given to economics against other environmental matters. He said that the theory that conservation issues can be dealt with on the basis of deals for the delivery of votes had to be very carefully looked at. This legislation is all about policies for the delivery of votes. That is all it involves. The only opposition to those reports apparently was from Senator Richardson. We all know that this environmental matter was the subject of research by Rod Cameron, who picked up matters, and Senator Richardson ran with them. Kakadu was one such matter. The Prime Minister visited the area, then we had this sudden rush to declare the rainforest.

What is the cost of this legislation? I understand that $300,000 was spent by the Minister, Senator Richardson, to get certain studies done. Apparently these have not been tabled. One can only judge that they have not been tabled for a very obvious reason, that is, because there are conflicting results. Senator Richardson steps away from these studies and that expense, picks up some research of the Queensland organisation, the Northern Rainforest Management Agency, and deliberately misrepresents and misinterprets the findings of that report. That is one cost. But there is also a cost to industry-to forestry, primary industry and small business. More importantly, there is also a cost to the individuals-the farmers whose land values will be degraded. We had the opportunity to visit Ravenshoe. There is the threat of massive devaluation of houses in that area. People in businesses and hobby farmers are also affected. Somebody who was selling tourist-type goods made from wood suggested that they would be the last he would be able to make because of the threat of the environmental policy-the World Heritage listing-to his business.

Various figures have been put on the additional cost of the new Parliament House. What Australians feel about that is a matter of individual interpretation. We have had figures from the Minister ranging from $500,000 to $900,000 as being the additional cost of recontracting for timbers used in furniture because timber from the rainforests of north Queensland is now banned from that construction. I suggest that the figure is higher than that. Industry sources put that figure between $10m and $15m because of the additional cost in administration. Clerks will have to sweat over their books and vouchers and invoices, saying, `This is good timber, that is bad timber, we can have this, we can't have that', and all because of a date on a form.
There is also the loss of hope, not only of people in the immediate vicinity but elsewhere, their loss of pride in being Australians and their loss of faith about what is going on in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Strung up by their thumbs by the inspectors.

—The honourable member is entirely right. They will be the ones wearing the jackboots, making sure that the legislation is enforced. I refer to Kakadu National Park and particularly the listing of stage 2. I would imagine that what Minister Kerin was saying the other day applies particularly to Kakadu National Park. The boundaries of stage 2 were not related to any environmental survey or boundaries that were already drawn. The boundaries were declared on the basis of old cattle properties and leases. I have been through there, as have a lot of my colleagues. We were up there about two years ago as a party. There is no doubt that Kakadu has some of the loveliest country in Australia. Katherine Gorge is part of it. The escarpments and the wetlands are absolutely beautiful.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that the land in respect of which miners are now seeking approval to mine is no better or no worse than some of the land in the coal mining areas of my electorate. One could go over that land and not see anything unique or attractive about it, but it does hide some of the most valuable coal resources in the world. Because this land in Kakadu hides some of the most valuable uranium and mineral resources, the mining companies are being held to ransom, and so is Australia's economy, by the manner in which certain people approach national park declarations.

I repeat that this Bill represents a political experiment to gain votes. That conclusion was drawn not only by me. It is unnecessary and represents a waste of effort and time of this Parliament; it is a waste of resources, which Minister Kerin has referred to; it is economic vandalism as far as we are concerned; but, worse than anything else, it indicates a complete contempt for people from a government that, within the last four months, has lost Minister John Brown, seen the retirement of Senator Ryan and has also seen Mick Young go to greener and higher pastures. But, more importantly, the Government has lost not only those Ministers, because of various matters, but also touch with the people. That is basically what the people in New South Wales were saying about it recently.

The coalition's attitude on World Heritage listing is as follows: we would consult with the States; we would not override the States; in fact, we would consult with the Territories on anything they would want to put up on Territory matters. We would probably go further with the Territories and try to hand over to them the residual powers that have been denied for so long on matters which mean so much. We would consult with the States. As I said, Premier Ahern was quite prepared to consult with us. We would give support only if the States made a submission on and agreed to the World Heritage listing. Our record shows that we did consult with regard to the Great Barrier Reef. I think that was a good example of consultation. We do have a proposal where, in conjunction with the States, we would encourage a greater Daintree National Park, with proper boundaries drawn, and not the ad hoc boundaries that have presently been drawn. We would consult with all the bodies, such as the National Farmers Federation, the mining industry, other industries and the people who are concerned about the ramifications of this Bill and what it will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you move their amendments?
—We do not move their amendments because we are so offended by this Bill that we will oppose it totally.
—Order! The honourable member for Dawson will ignore the interjections. I ask members on my right to allow the honourable member to proceed with his speech uninterrupted.

—Our proposition would be consultation, not confrontation which has been the method of this Government. We would agree to sensible multiple use plans and management plans. Senator Puplick has visited the Daintree rainforest many times. The Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), has been up there at least twice. The Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), has been up there at least once. I know that Queenslander members of the Federal Parliament and other members of the Parliament have been there to make sure that they know what they are talking about. We are very impressed with the management plans of the Queensland Forestry Division. It has embarked upon a system of management and selective logging. It does not log near the streams or on the banks. It has embarked on every good environment practice that has been known. I suggest that it is in front of the Commonwealth in terms of its experience.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is about nominating World Heritage areas. The Minister read into Hansard exactly what was going to happen. Page 2 of the second reading speech indicates the areas that are to be nominated. It is nearly all land owned by the Queensland Government-State forests or leasehold and vacant land in Queensland-but there is some federally owned land and also some in private ownership. Page 3 refers to responsible administration. Page 6 mentions the agent responsible for preservation and conservation. In no way does the Government really get to the meaning or the purpose of the submission by indicating that Queensland is responsible for the administration. Nowhere is it mentioned that this Government does not have the support of the Queensland Government in this submission. By that admission alone, the submission is fraught with fault.

Quite apart from the Bill being about the matters that I have already mentioned, such as inspectors, who determine certain things and what the interpretation of the Bill is, it also determines that the States and the Australian courts will not list the World Heritage areas in the future; that the Australian judges are not capable of making a meaningful judgment of the areas suitable for World Heritage listing; that it will be put in the hands of an external body. I think Kakadu National Park is a great example of that. The World Heritage people did not make an inspection of stage 1 or stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park. In fact, they were quite embarrassed that they were not asked to make an inspection of stage 2. We completely oppose the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never in the years that I have been in this place have I heard such a savage attack on a piece of legislation and on the Government. The legislators would be vibrating with fear, having heard what the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), said. Not only have there been attacks on the legislation and the Government but the university students got a guernsey as well. All I can suggest to the previous speaker is that if he wants to close down the universities because there are too many greenie votes in them for the Australian Labor Party he should get out there onto the campuses and say so. In fact, I am so impressed by his speech that I am going to get a lot of copies of it and distribute it in my electorate. The honourable member has talked a lot of nonsense and has been wrong many times. I have never come across the likes of it before in my parliamentary experience.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get back to something which is relevant to the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill and which we have not heard in this debate. The Bill relates to two pieces of existing legislation-that is, the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. The latter Act is only brought into this debate in the sense that the legislation that we are now debating will not apply to the existing legislation. I mention that just to clarify the position.

The Bill makes provision for amendments to Commonwealth Government conservation legislation to clarify-this is the important part-and strengthen the protection afforded under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983-the World Heritage Act. The Bill amends the definition of identified property which is protected by the World Heritage Act to follow more closely the format of the convention concerning the protection of the world cultural and natural heritage. Protection against damage or destruction is extended to property which the Commonwealth Government believes may be of World Heritage value and which is subject to an inquiry to determine World Heritage status.

The Bill also makes provision for some other amendments to the World Heritage Act to rectify-once again it is a rectification-problems that have arisen in its operation since its enactment in 1983. These include the provision of a ministerial power to appoint inspectors under the Act for the purpose of obtaining information concerning the making of proclamations and regulations or of determining possible breaches of the Act. Additionally, it is proposed that the section of the Act held invalid by the High Court of Australia in the Tasmanian dam case be repealed. So there is a repealing of that section which the High Court has already held is invalid. The provisions in the Act regarding compensation are also to be simplified. The Bill makes it clear that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 does not apply, as I have said, to action taken under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act or to any submission by Australia of a heritage property as suitable for inscription on the World Heritage List.

Before examining the provisions of the Bill in detail, let me first explain what it is that makes World Heritage so important and, secondly, discuss the circumstances which make these proposed amendments imperative. The World Heritage Convention is the most important international expression of the need to protect and conserve the natural and cultural heritage for the benefit of the whole world. This Convention was adopted by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation General Conference in its seventeenth session in November 1972. It came into force on 7 December 1975. As the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) said, the Convention promotes cooperation among nations to protect areas and buildings which are of such outstanding universal value that their conservation is of concern to humanity generally. Parties to the Convention commit themselves to help in the identification, protection, conservation and presentation of World Heritage properties. In addition, the Convention provides an objective system for identifying those natural and cultural heritage properties within the member countries which are of outstanding universal value for all the world. The Convention also establishes a list of such properties, known as the World Heritage List. The Convention is intended to ensure that, unlike most of the seven wonders of the ancient world, properties on the World Heritage List will be preserved for all time.

It is important to point out, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the amendments do not remove the rights of the Queensland Government, or any individual, to challenge the legislation or a nomination in the Australian courts. It is not constitutionally possible for the Commonwealth to exclude the High Court from pronouncing on the constitutional validity of its laws. Consistent with the High Court judgment of 10 March, the Commonwealth is guaranteeing interim protection under the Act to areas which are the subject of either nomination or a duly constituted Federal inquiry, or to any area identified by regulation where World Heritage values will then have to be proven. The High Court found that the Commonwealth had the constitutional right and the international obligation to identify areas containing World Heritage values and to guarantee interim protection under the Act while these values were being assessed.

It is interesting to note that the honourable member for Dawson said that there was no necessity for putting this into legislation. Of course, he would prefer to turn a blind eye to the incursions by timber cutters into that particular area of the north-east Australian tropical rainforests after the pronouncement of the boundaries of that area. Those are the sorts of breaches of the legislation which must be carefully guarded against, especially when one comes from a State such as Queensland. It took several media announcements by me and protestations to the Department and the Queensland Government before anything was done to investigate the incursions by timber cutters, not only into a World Heritage area but into a Queensland national park. Those responsible for the incursions are now being prosecuted by the Queensland Government. The new, sounder basis for interim protection which the Bill provides, and the protection measures themselves, will be as open to legal challenge by Queensland as the old Act and measures. No powers of challenge to the High Court are eroded by this legislation.

The north Queensland logging season is due to recommence on 1 April. I ask the coalition parties whether they are trying to delay this legislation because they do not care about tropical rainforests. Would they prefer to hear the roar of chainsaws begin again on 1 April, destroying-probably irrevocably-rainforests which are of universal standard? Where is the commitment to saving an area which the Liberals know should be on the World Heritage List? I say that the Liberals know that because Senator Puplick has made that very statement. In August last year he issued a Press release in which he said:
The Queensland Wet Tropical Rainforests are worthy of inclusion on the World Heritage List.
He went on to say:

They are unique; they are of international significance; they contain one of the greatest and scientifically most significant concentrations of unique flora and fauna in the world. Australia is the only industrialised country with remaining tropical rainforests and we have a responsibility to protect them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he still saying that?

—Of course he is saying it. The only people who are saying there should not be World Heritage listing are his cronies in the National Party, not only in Queensland but unfortunately also in Canberra. For three years Queensland effectively vetoed the nomination of the State's rainforests to the World Heritage List. Anyone suggesting there should be consultation and not confrontation either does not know what he is talking about or is unaware of the facts about the period during which consultations were held. The irresponsible, inane, and at times insensible attitude of the former Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen-notwithstanding he was a little senile at the time-was, `How could there be any consultation?'. As far as he was concerned, he wanted confrontation. It was for that very reason that he told the people of north Queensland that they were at war and should take on the Federal Government. He whipped up hatred and fear in the minds of the people of north Queensland, to the extent that they saw fit to physically attack the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) when he visited the area.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no consultation while one has a government such as the Queensland National Party Government with its attitude to conservation and many other issues relating to public conduct. The Opposition believes Australia has a responsibility to protect rainforests but is not prepared to do anything about it. In Queensland we have seen procrastination, prevarication and corruption as the hallmarks of national park management and acquisition, despite the richest diversity of any Australian environment and hundreds of well-researched park proposals-many of them, unfortunately, more than a decade old. One of Premier Ahern's problems has been the poor advice his Government has received on the significance of the north Queensland rainforests and the future of the timber industry. Five years ago many people thought that saving tropical rainforests meant stopping a road at Cape Tribulation. We all remember the ridiculous statements made by the now Queensland Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Tenni. He thought that, if one stopped the road at Cape Tribulation, one would stop World Heritage listing. He is on the record as having said that.

The Australian Heritage Commission report, written by Dr Aila Keto and published in September 1984, shattered that illusion by identifying values which placed the rainforest region between Townsville and Cooktown alongside the top ten World Heritage sites in the world. Despite this evidence, the Queensland Government has persistently-and some would quite rightly say wilfully-argued that there is no scientific base to the World Heritage nomination.

Only last week in the Queensland Parliament, the Minister for the Environment, Conservation and Tourism, Mr Geoff Muntz-another extremely intelligent Minister from the Queensland Administration!-denigrated Dr Keto, who in February won the 1988 BHP Environment Award for excellence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he apologise?

—He would not know how to. Yet late last month the Queensland Government's key adviser on rainforests, Dr Ross Hynes, admitted to his few dozen listeners at a public meeting in Innisfail that, apart from some minor errors with the maps and the species listed, Dr Keto's report had established beyond doubt the World Heritage values of the region. The most recent embarrassing advice which the Queensland Government has chosen to distance itself from has come from the scientific subcommittee of the Northern Rainforest Management Agency (NORMA), chaired by Dr Hynes. The work of that committee is very welcome because, despite the hopes of its political masters, it has confirmed heritage values which the Commonwealth is committed to protecting.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite quite crude back-flips by Environment Minister Muntz, trying to downplay the significance of the report, it was not the work of one scientist, but rather the synthesis of input from about 14 scientists who have acknowledged expertise relating to rainforests. We should and will choose to ignore, for the moment, the important work of about another 10 scientists who were approached but either could not or would not participate in what was seen as a politically compromised piece of science. Mr Muntz's ranting about the report being `preliminary stolen', when it was publicly available in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation library, and about it containing computer errors has shattered whatever claims NORMA and its scientific committee ever had to political independence.

In February this year, the north Queensland Press carried advertisements for public meetings in Malanda and Innisfail where the public was advised to `come to hear the latest report on the vital work of NORMA's scientific committee opposed to World Heritage Listing of our rainforest'. This advertisement angered many of the scientists on the committee, who were wholly in favour of World Heritage. The committee demanded a public retraction and never got one. The mistake was explained away as a `clerical error'. Rather, it seems yet again that this political interference stems from the top. The advertisement was the work of a Mr Ken Crook-quite aptly named, I might say-Press secretary to former Premier, Sir Joh. Mr Crook has just taken up a position as Director of the National Party in Queensland.

There has been much loose and ill-informed talk about the impact of this legislation from various interest groups. The Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC) put out a Press release on 6 March claiming that the `rush to list endangers Australia's sovereignty and erodes the civil liberties of citizens'. This concern for civil liberties is very touching, but obviously AMIC was more concerned about access to resources. The reality is that, apart from national parks in some States, the mining industry has access to most lands, including freehold and leasehold properties. In Queensland, as I have pointed out, only 2 per cent of the State is national park. In Tasmania it is 13.4 per cent. Most of the rest of these States is already open to the miners.

In north Queensland, Senator Graham Richardson, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has stated on several occasions that mining operations are not prohibited provided they do not involve clearance of rainforest areas or other threats to World Heritage values. Twice the Government has been approached with specific mining proposals in north Queensland. Twice the Government has given the go-ahead.

In this week's Press, AMIC Director, Lachlan McIntosh, claimed `consultation has been negligible' and that no management plan had been produced. Mr McIntosh failed to mention that AMIC's cooperation has been sought in the development of management plans involving an appropriate mining regime for the area. AMIC's and the Queensland Government's concern for civil liberties and the rights of landholders is perhaps best characterised by a recent State Government proposal-albeit unsuccessful-to amend the State mining Act to allow holders of authorities to prospect to enter private land at any time, without notice, without the owner's permission, and without consulting the owner as to the works program. The Government's and, by implication, the mining industry's justification for this was the stated aim of the Government's Green Paper: `determination of the most appropriate land use at any given time should rest with the Government and not with the party owning or controlling the land in question'. So much for the police state!

The comments of my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) yesterday about the campaign by the National Farmers Federation (NFF) are also worthy of note. The Minister said that the Federation was `whipping up the issue'. He pointed out that there were only a handful of freehold properties in World Heritage areas-about 20 in north Queensland and eight in South West Tasmania-and that there is no way this Government is going to debase the currency of World Heritage by listing every bit of untouched bushland or threatened forest.

The NFF is concerned about the lack of legislated definition of procedures for consultation, compensation and management. All nominations are discussed with State governments, as they will be in this case. The Premier, Mr Ahern, mentioned only this week that he is now prepared to consult. Consultation, especially in the case of north Queensland, has been extensive and exhaustive over a period of years. Neither the NFF nor the AMIC has been able to produce one example-I challenge them to do so-of a property owner who has been disadvantaged unduly by Heritage listing. In fact, in Cairns a salesman for one of the major real estate companies in north Queensland said that he thought that World Heritage was the best thing that could have happened to property values in the area. Management arrangements are the responsibility of the Australian Government, not the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. Suitable management arrangements have been put in place for all Australian World Heritage areas. The decision to list the north-east Australian tropical rainforests on the World Heritage List will be seen in years to come as one of the great decisions of the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) that quite the contrary is the case: the decision to go ahead with the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 will be the very cause of the Government's demise. One would have thought that the Government, after seeing the State election results in New South Wales, would have learnt something. What do we read in the newspaper this morning? We read that the architect of this legislation, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, is now so arrogant he is telling the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he is not doing a good job. I agree with him, but is it not fanciful to see a Minister, only just into the Cabinet, now possessed of all integrity and wisdom, telling the Prime Minister in the national Press to lift his game?
—You got us all the environmental votes.

—I was going to refer to the speech made by the honourable member for Prospect in the adjournment debate last night. Perhaps he ought to send it to the honourable member for Leichhardt to read carefully. He can read about how the environment vote is not worth the chase. I see that the honourable member for Leichhardt is about to leave the chamber. He should stay in his seat and listen. I could not understand what he was saying. It was the rambling exercise we have become used to hearing from him.

SPEECH.PARA: The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 is totally opposed by the Opposition, as the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) so rightly pointed out. During the debate many speakers from the Opposition side will set out clearly the very important issues the Government has chosen to ignore. This Bill is the handiwork of Senator Richardson, the new Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It began in the Senate several days ago where it was debated for quite some time. There have been many speakers on it. Interestingly, the debate was guillotined earlier today to make sure that it got down to this place so that it could become law. It is being rushed through in the hope that people will not have the opportunity to look clearly and closely at some of its provisions. I wish to point them out this afternoon.

In its broadest sense, this Bill is an admission of the Minister's failure to make the federal system work and his inability to deal with the constituent States of our federation in proper consultative fashion-and this from the Party that told us it was going to make consensus and consultation an art form. What we are witnessing is a mockery of the federal compact. What does the Bill do? It amends two interesting Acts of this Parliament: the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act of 1983 and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act of 1974. The primary purpose of the Bill is to provide legislative backing for interim protection of the north-east Queensland rainforest and to deem that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 does not apply to World Heritage land since the commencement of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. In a word, it is retrospective legislation. The method by which Senator Richardson has gone about this can best be described as jackbooted, a resort to bully boy tactics which Senator Puplick, who led the debate in the Senate for the Opposition, so aptly described as `reminiscent of what goes on at the Enmore branch of the Australian Labor Party'. The Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch), who is at the table, would be well aware of that reference, I am sure, coming as he does from Sydney and being a member of the Sussex Street team, no doubt. He is smiling, anyway.

There are objections to this legislation. I am sure that the Minister at the table knows of them. They have been flooding into my office and to the offices of many other Opposition members. I am sure that honourable members on the other side of the House have been receiving similar objections. Concerns have been expressed by the National Farmers Federation, by the Australian Mining Industry Council, by an organisation in my own State, the Tasmanian Chamber of Mines, by the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties-from which I will quote at length later-by the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association and by many other organisations. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) in his speech referred to some of the concerns expressed by those people.

This Bill seeks a significant extension of the Commonwealth's power to areas which are, or are potentially, being considered for listing on the World Heritage List. Clause 3 of the Bill redefines the term `identified property' to include property which is subject to an inquiry established by a law of the Commonwealth whose purpose is to consider whether the property forms part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage of Australia. This whole amendment now really has a negative effect, given the decision of the High Court of Australia on 10 March in the Lemonthyme case. The editorial in the Australian the day after the decision encapsulates in fairly succinct terms, as editorial writers are wont to do, the significance of that decision. I quote from that editorial:

The decision strengthens the Commonwealth's legislative powers through its constitutional power to make laws about External Affairs, while further whittling away the power of the States and the people.
It goes on further to say:

. . . by upholding the Commonwealth's powers to protect the Lemonthyme and Southern forests area of Tasmania on Thursday, the High Court gave the Commonwealth power to protect areas it was merely thinking about having declared, at some later time, as part of the World Heritage.
It goes on to say:

By using this latest decision, the Federal Government could declare its interest in nominating an area for World Heritage listing and immediately gain total control over the area-ignoring the sovereign rights of the State government and the people-and then take no immediate action other than implementing a study or inquiry.
But of more concern than the environmental issue is the increasing concentration of power in the hands of the Federal Government.

The important point is that the High Court has said that the power which the Government claims it needs to put into legislation is a power which it already has. Why then proceed? Why was the Bill guillotined and rushed here to be put through tonight before we rise before Easter? Why is there such a rush? Use of this external affairs power to protect areas of forest came to the fore with the Tasmanian dams case. As a Tasmanian, of course I followed that case with extreme interest. The power was used to implement the World Heritage convention. The decision of the High Court in the Lemonthyme case on 10 March dealt with the validity of the Helsham Committee of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests.

When the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests (Commission of Inquiry) Bill was brought to this place, it was vigorously opposed by all of us on this side of the House. It in effect overturned a memorandum of understanding between Tasmanian and the Commonwealth and has put in jeopardy a $1 billion downstream value adding pulp mill in Tasmania. Representatives have been to the Prime Minister. They have explained to him: `We want to go ahead with this very large project which will be an economic boon to Tasmania. Tasmanians want it. Yet you have set up this inquiry. We need to know the situation so that we can make a decision'. The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), who is in the chamber today, earlier in the week asked the Prime Minister a question without notice at Question Time. He asked: `Are you going to follow the findings of this independent inquiry that you set up?'. The Prime Minister would not give an answer. He was very non-committal. All he would say was, `We will have a look at it'. And why? Because the Helsham Inquiry, as we have been watching it, is starting to see the validity of the arguments that the Tasmanian Government has been putting to it: that logging, done sensibly with environmental concerns, following the most stringent management plans of anywhere in Australia-no one in this place, regardless of where he sits, can deny that fact-perhaps ought to be going ahead.

By holding this inquiry we have taken out a section of time. We have stopped the industry in its tracks. Now we may find that a world leading pulp mill will be denied to Tasmania. That inquiry was a sop to extremist environmentalists. It has achieved nothing. It has cost thousands and thousands, both directly and indirectly, all because we have an environment Minister who is said to be born again. It is a piece of environmental cynicism.

The results in the New South Wales election were worse than those in 1975. Honourable members opposite cannot ignore this fact. At 25 minutes to six o'clock, all the people driving home in their cars all over Australia listening to the Parliament of Australia, ought to know that the New South Wales election saw the worst result for the Australian Labor Party since 1975. If that does not send a signal to the rest of Australia I do not know what will. But why is it that the people on the other side will not listen? Why go ahead with this piece of legislation? It has not done them any good at all. When Mr Unsworth said, `I have to resign for the good of the Party', poor old battling Barrie, he said one of the reasons--

TALK.START.PARA: —What does Barrie Unsworth have to do with the Queensland rainforests?

—We are going to talk about Kakadu so the honourable member can interrupt now if he wants to. He will get his chance. We will do him over later on. What Barrie Unsworth said was that one of the points--

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am intrigued as to the relevance of the honourable member's comments to the Bill that is before the House. I fail to see the relevance of his comments about the former Premier of New South Wales to this conservation Bill.
—There is a certain amount of substance to the point of order but there were a lot of interjections. I ask the honourable member for Bass to return to the Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, of course I was encouraged by those interjections to respond in kind but I will try to concern myself with the elements of the Bill because they provide the opportunity to refer to a story of monumental significance, the politics of which I am sure does not escape those who try to interject and to interrupt the flow of my speech. I was saying that in the Lemonthyme case the High Court voted in favour of the entire legislation. While two justices dissented, this was due to a lack of sufficient evidence to establish necessary facts and there was no disagreement with the general principles relied on by the majority. I quote the judgment of Mason, CJ, and Brennan, J:

SPEECH.PARA: The taking of action by way of interim protection pursuant to the external affairs power, for example, by the enactment of legislation prohibiting the destruction of, or damage to, particular property, pending a determination of its status as a property to be nominated for inclusion in the World Heritage List may be supported as action which can reasonably be considered appropriate and adapted to the attainment of the object of the Convention, namely the protection of the heritage.

So there we have it: the High Court gave it all away to the Commonwealth. We on this side of the House view that with some alarm. The legislation represents an undesirable and unnecessary escalation of the confrontationist approach of Senator Richardson. The hope of a return to any consultation and cooperation between the Commonwealth and States on a whole range of these issues is now lost by the stupidity of pursuing this legislation. Indeed, Mr McIntosh of the Australian Mining Industry Council points out graphically the undermining of investor confidence of this legislation. I quote from a letter I am sure all other members have received. Remember that the mining industry is the industry that provides Australia with its greatest wealth. Mr McIntosh said:

More than 23 per cent of Australia is difficult to access or completely closed to exploration and mining, and a further 20 per cent has been nominated by various groups for closure. The result would be to strangle the industry which earns more than 40 per cent of this nation's foreign earnings, and return Australia to the living standards of the 1800s.
He also said:
The Australian Mining Industry Council strongly supports the National Conservation Strategy. The industry is at the forefront of environmental management and conservation technology.

We are not dealing with an industry that is not sensitive to the environment; it is. Do Government members understand what is being said to them? They are putting in jeopardy major developments in this country by pursuing this piece of legislation. Senator Watson also sought details from Senator Richardson in the Senate about the two interdepartmental committee inquiries on land use and forestry that are being set up. He could not get very much information out of him but it is interesting that those committees have been set up. The material that he provided states:

One of the aims of the review is to improve existing arrangements and develop new principles and criteria to apply to Commonwealth land use decisions, taking into account the principles of sustainable development embodied in the national conservation strategy for Australia.

That is sensible. But who was it the other day who said, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, that we ought to be looking at these matters more carefully, given the New South Wales election result, and perhaps we ought to be looking at cost-benefit analyses before we go ahead and lock up natural resources from development?

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not Mr Kerin, was it?

—It was indeed the honourable member for Werriwa. He is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. We know, as do members on the other side of the House, that he stood up at the Caucus meeting and put his view. Senator Richardson, the born-again greenie, stood up and put his view. Now the Government is not sure where to go. If Senator Richardson can get away with telling the Prime Minister on the front page of the Australian that he is not doing a good enough job, he has all Labor members bluffed, has he not? What did Mr Kerin say? What he had to say was reasonably sensible. The Australian reports Mr Kerin as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The theory that conservation issues can be dealt with on the basis of deals for the delivery of votes is wrong.
This approach denigrates the dedication of the conservation movement and distorts the balanced way responsible Cabinet government should deal with conservation issues.
He went on further to say that there should be a scientific basis to making decisions. I could not agree more. Why will the Government not follow that? Why chase the votes?

The major item in this legislation to which we object most strongly is the matter of the inspectors. Those who are lawyers on the other side of the House surely have looked at the legislation. They have been described as Richardson's greenshirts by some honourable senators in the other place because they will be appointed by Senator Richardson and they have amazing powers. These inspectors may do just about anything. They may enter and search premises, they may take photographs, they may inspect, measure, and so on. They should do so with the consent of the property owner. But the let-out clause says:
. . . circumstances that are of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate entry without the consent of the person in charge or the authority of a warrant issued.

Notwithstanding Senator Richardson's assurances that it is not his intention to take away citizens' rights, the proposed provisions are of exceptional width. In the definition of `eligible purpose' a reference to unlawful acts `likely to be done' gives extraordinary scope to the powers of the inspectors. The Queensland Council for Civil Liberties wrote to me-I have the letter here-stating:
. . . it is exceedingly important that such a major extension of powers of the state into a new area be subject to the strictest safeguards to prevent misuse of such powers.

The Council made several suggestions. I am sure that honourable members have received the same letter. They say that the inspectors ought to have tape recorders to ensure that evidence is obtained properly so that it can be legitimately admissible in court. They also say that the warrant issuing process needs changing to avoid a misuse of powers. They also say that the penalties for obstruction of inspectors seem to be excessive in the circumstances. The Bill provides for a penalty of $1,000 or 12 months imprisonment for any obstruction to an inspector appointed by the Minister, Senator Richardson. They say that there is a need for any inspectors to be properly trained as to citizens' rights. At present, such inspectors will be appointed by the Minister.

The Tasmanian Council for Civil Liberties has been in touch with the Minister. Who is the Chairman of the Tasmanian Council for Civil Liberties? It is John White, Labor shadow Minister for the arts in Tasmania. He is the man who had the courage to stand up against the Australia Card Bill. Why do honourable members opposite not listen to these people? It is not the member for Bass expressing these concerns; it is people who are sympathetic to the Government's cause who are expressing them. Some honourable members opposite are lawyers. Why do they not listen? Are they going to respond to those concerns in the debate? Where are their amendments at least to meet those concerns? They are not here. They are just letting the legislation go straight through without any consideration at all. This legislation is disastrous, it is arrogant, and it smacks all over of Senator Richardson.

The whole process of World Heritage listing is under scrutiny. An interesting piece of paper came my way this afternoon. It is a telex from the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, Mr Mott, and it is a report he sent to Senator Richardson. It discloses that when the representative of the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, Mr Thorsell, came to Australia he was not taken to Kakadu. We might have an opportunity for this telex to be distributed widely. It shows that the Ambassador was very embarrassed about going back. What has happened, of course, is that the listing has been made on the basis that it was inspected by Mr Thorsell, and it was not. So how will the Minister explain that? The whole question of World Heritage listing is under scrutiny.

Another interesting document came my way earlier this week. It is a summary by Dr Croft, the Secretary to the Department of Law in the Northern Territory who attended the eleventh session in Geneva of the World Heritage Committee on assessment procedures. I would like to read this into the Hansard so that the people of Australia can see what are our concerns about this process, this lack of definition, this lack of commitment to basing decisions about World Heritage listing on true scientific evidence. That is the point. We are not saying that World Heritage listing is all bad; we are saying that the processes by which it is being put into place ought to be subject to more scrutiny. The document reads:

After sitting through the Eleventh Session Croft and Thomas gained the impression that the whole process lacked rigour of any kind. While the technical delegates regard World Heritage listing as very important and scientific the predominating the diplomatic influence views it more as a means of raising general environmental consciousness world-wide. It can be seen in some ways as a boutique tourist label more or less available on request to member countries.

The disparity of views of the varying factions of the committee and the weak assessments provided by IUCN at this Eleventh Session raise the very real issue as to whether any World Heritage nomination has ever been scientifically evaluated against the stringent requirements of the Convention. It is more than probable that there are properties around the world inscribed on the list that fall short of these requirements. It took the active lobbying of the Northern Territory Government in 1987 to even stir the Committee into critically evaluating the Kakadu nomination.
As far as extensions are concerned it would appear that experience to date has seen such areas gain inscription without having to satisfy the same criteria as would be applied to new nominations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very entertaining performance by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) but way off the mark as usual. I will be addressing some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite).
—You will be burying them.

—Perhaps the honourable member for Bass, who is leaving the chamber, would like to stay and listen. He might learn something about the Northern Territory Government and the way in which it has behaved in international forums, the way in which it has misrepresented Australia's interests, and the way in which it has discredited the people of this nation. They have performed in a similar fashion to the way in which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has performed recently. This matter was addressed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Question Time. It is the sort of activity we are seeing from the Opposition in this House. It is the sort of activity it supports in international forums. It is the sort of activity that is being carried out by the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 is to provide legislative backing for the interim protection of the north-east Queensland rainforests. I say interim because unfortunately the Queensland Government wants to continue to log the rainforests of north-east Queensland while the Australian nation waits to see whether this magnificent area is judged worthy of registry on the World Heritage Lists.

I think it appropriate, before I turn to the substantive provisions of the Bill, to put some historical perspective on environmental law. For the information of honourable members opposite, it was over 100 years ago, in 1870, that laws were introduced in this country to curb timber cutting in sensitive environmental areas, in that case in the Murray River and some parts of the coast of New South Wales. Since then there has been a variety of legislation passed to protect areas of significance, to prevent wholesale destruction of the nation's natural assets, to ensure a meshing of environmental values with responsible resource management.

In December 1982 the Fraser-Anthony Government nominated the western Tasmanian wilderness national parks and the Lord Howe Islands to the World Heritage Authority. Both these nominations were successful and registration took place in 1983. In regard to rainforests, since the white settlement of Australia we have managed to exploit and destroy 75 per cent of our rainforests. Queensland is now in the enviable position of having 55 per cent of this nation's remaining rainforests.

But Queensland has no regard for its rainforests. It wants to knock them over. I say enviable because I think that most other governments would give their left arm and their eye teeth to have within their State or territorial borders such a precious natural resource.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have chopped down all yours in the Northern Territory.

—Rainforests are home to well over half the species of flora and fauna on this planet. It is beyond the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) to comprehend what that means. Rainforests now cover only some 10 per cent of the land surface of the earth. In 1985 the World Bank launched an $11 billion plan. The honourable member might be able to understand what $11 billion means because that is what the Opposition was going to slash out of government spending if it had been elected last July. We would not have had any rainforests left in this nation-we would not have anything left-if the mob opposite were in government. I have carefully used the word `resource' in describing the rainforests of north-east Queensland because some honourable members opposite would have us believe that by protecting the rainforests somehow we have gone soft, that we are locking up vast tracts of the country in some kind of deal with the environmental movement to the detriment of the economy and the creation and maintenance of jobs.
