Nothing could be further from the truth, and well they know it. The coalition has backed down. We remember that after the last election the Leader of the Opposition made soothing noises about fixing up the coalition's environment policy. That has been thrown out the door, as has every other bit of policy the coalition parties have ever had, in the debate on this Bill. Their hypocrisy is plain for everyone to see. Let me quote Senator Puplick, the Liberal shadow Minister for the environment. In August last year Senator Puplick had this to say about the heritage listing of the Queensland wet tropical forests-honourable members opposite may not like it, but this is what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland wet tropical rainforests are worthy of inclusion on the World Heritage List; they are unique; they are of international significance; they contain one of the greatest and scientifically most significant concentrations of unique flora and fauna in the world. Australia is the only industrialised country with remaining tropical rainforests and we have a responsibility-
I repeat: a responsibility-
to protect them.

That was the shadow Minister for the environment. He is supporting the World Heritage listing of this area. Now this mob are denigrating the legislation. They do not know what day it is. My colleague Senator Richardson commented yesterday in the Senate:
That is the only thing Senator Puplick ever got right on the question of rainforests in north Queensland.
Even the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) had a bite of the cherry last October. He was quoted in the Cairns Post of 1 October last year as saying:
World Heritage listing might be appropriate for parts of the far north.

Mind you, he would not commit himself. We never expect him to commit himself about anything. He was trying to have it both ways, as usual-as the National Party of Australia does on most occasions. The forces of darkness in the coalition obviously have got their way once again. Now they are saying that a Liberal government would not nominate any areas for World Heritage listing if an individual State did not agree. What are they saying? Would they mind telling the people of Australia what their policies are and what they stand for? They do not have any, and they do not know. If the Queensland Government refuses to budge, they will drop the whole thing. They will support a scorched earth policy in areas that experts such as Dr James Thorsell, the executive officer of the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, have said on the public record are clearly of World Heritage calibre. What would members of the Opposition have done with that kind of irresponsible policy if Kakadu was coming up for listing? Would they have abrogated the responsibility of the Federal Government of Australia not only to the people of Australia but also to the international community and all the generations to come to ensure that areas worthy of World Heritage listing were preserved? Their short term parish pump politics in this issue are there for the whole nation to witness. They are a disgrace, and they know it. They do not know what day it is. They have no respect for the environment or the concerns of the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: how can the honourable member say that when we know it is only five days after the New South Wales election?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—What will the heritage listing of the north Queensland wet tropics mean to the people of Queensland? Honourable members opposite should ask themselves that. They should ask their fellow members of the National Party who have an interest in the tourism industry in that part of Queensland. What are they saying about the World Heritage listing? They are supporting it, and those opposite know it. The proposed listing of the Queensland wet tropics area on the World Heritage List--
—It is five days after we won the Cairns City Council elections.

—That is right, five days after we won the Cairns City Council elections and all local government elections north of Rockhampton, if I am not mistaken. The proposed listing of the Queensland wet tropics area on the World Heritage List, if successful-and I hope it is; I expect it to be-will mean that Queensland, like the Northern Territory, which boasts Kakadu and Uluru on the World Heritage List, will also be in the happy position of having two areas listed. Queenslanders not only will get to retain this precious remnant of the world's remaining rainforests but also will reap direct benefits through increases in the tourist industry that will surely follow the heritage listing of this region. Let me illustrate this point with an appropriate example drawn from my electorate of the Northern Territory. Stage 1 of Kakadu National Park was placed on the World Heritage List in October of 1981 and since that time visitor numbers to the park have risen dramatically. In 1982 the total number of visitors to Kakadu was a mere 48,500. By 1985 the annual number had topped 100,000 people and last year, in 1987, some 195,000 people went to Kakadu. Next year we expect a quarter of a million people. In other words, since stage 1 was listed, visitor numbers have increased by over 300 per cent. I fully expect that, following the recent heritage listing of Kakadu stage 2, the staggering growth rate for the tourist industry in the Top End will continue. I am sure that even my learned friend the honourable member for Maranoa-dare I used the word `learned'; I have some suspicion about how learned he is-can appreciate that tourism means dollars and cents. I know he understands bucks because that is where he comes from-the big bucks country. The tourism and hospitality trade means jobs. It means building motels and hotels, and the multiplier effect, for the economic illiterates on the other side of the House, of the tourism industry on local economies is not difficult to work out. Tourists need petrol, entertainment and food. They need a place to sleep or camp, although I have noticed that the honourable member for Maranoa is not too choosy where he camps on occasions. Tourists buy books and newspapers.
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory will cease speaking to the member for Maranoa and address himself to the question before the House.

—They go to banks and post offices; they buy souvenirs and T-shirts; and they take photographs and have them developed. If they have an enjoyable and memorable time-as I have previously noted that honourable members opposite often do-they will tell their friends and their friends will go back and spend a few bucks.

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism brings money into this country. We all know it. It injects large sums into the local economy. In saying this, I do not want to create the impression that I think the tourist industry in any region of this country should be allowed to grow like Topsy. Tourism, like any industry, needs careful planning and management. We need to know why people come to our country or travel from State to State or State to Territory. We need to understand the pressures that tourism creates-its social and economic impact on local communities. However, it is interesting to note that approximately 26 per cent of the 399,100 visitors who went to visit the north-eastern Queensland rainforest area in 1985 noted rainforests as a medium or high factor in their decision to visit the area. Approximately 50 per cent saw rainforests during their visit, while some 15 per cent, or almost a quarter of a million tourists, took part in activities which were classified as involving an environmental experience-something the honourable member for Maranoa would find difficult to understand.

Australian Tourism Commission surveys show that overseas tourists come to our country because they want to experience a back to nature holiday. The comparison of the activities of the Northern Territory Government and its hostility towards the World Heritage listing of stage 2 of Kakadu with the Queensland Government's opposition to the listing of its rainforests has not escaped me, just as it has not escaped members opposite. Unfortunately, they have got the bull by the tail, as usual, and have no real understanding of the issues. Both governments put up similar arguments to justify their waste of taxpayers' money. Both governments said they based their opposition on economic grounds. The Territory Government tried to say that stage 2 of Kakadu National Park was not worth listing. Well, what did it do? It employed Harry Butler, the conservationist's friend, and some clapped out academic from England to do a shonky video on Kakadu. They spent almost $870,000 or thereabouts on presenting a submission to the 1986 Paris United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation conference. As we would expect, they were laughed out of court.

Opposition members use hollow rhetoric. They talk repeatedly about jobs and economic growth but, I repeat, it is hollow rhetoric. What the Northern Territory Government managed to achieve, apart from running up a huge hotel bill in Paris both in 1986 and 1987, was to embarrass the Australian community just as the Queensland Government is doing at present and just as the Opposition is trying to do at the moment. The Territory Government managed to damage the tourist industry in the Northern Territory. We all know that the Northern Territory is a mineral rich region, with mining being one of the top money earners for the Territory economy. But so is tourism. Tourism is, of course, a renewable resource. In the meantime the Territory Government on the one hand promotes the Crocodile Dundee country to the hilt and, on the other, with typical hypocrisy it denigrates the very country that the tourists want to visit.

In the two years prior to the listing of stage 2 the Northern Territory Government tried to claim that stage 2 was not worthy of listing according to World Heritage List requirements. It claimed that the submission by the Australian Government was flawed and a fraud. We know who the fraud was. It was the Northern Territory Government. It spent endless dollars, hundreds of thousands of dollars, to make a stupid, banal political point-just as the Opposition is doing at the moment.

The Northern Territory Government also managed to waste scarce taxpayers' dollars. For the benefit of honourable members opposite, and especially for the benefit for the shadow Minister, I remind them that the Northern Territory gets almost 80 per cent of its revenue through Commonwealth coffers. The Northern Territory representatives went off to Paris in 1986 and took a QC with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?

—They took Tom Hughes, who is a very eminent QC. But what a waste of money. What a dead loss. That is the sort of activity that those blokes opposite support. It just goes to show what they think of this country. They have no respect for the taxpayer, the Treasury or the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: But the inconsistencies catch up with the coalition forces and they start fighting amongst themselves. Remember when the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) was the Opposition spokesman on the environment. Do we hear him? Where is he? I hope he will be speaking later in the debate. In July last year he made the mistake of putting out the olive branch on environment policy. He admitted that the Liberal Party's policy needed `substantial revision'. He is a revisionist. Honourable members would understand what that means as there are a few of them in the National Party. He was reported as saying:
Future Liberal governments should be prepared to use Commonwealth powers to override States' rights in a bid to win support from the conservation lobby.

There it is. Honourable members opposite should stop their bleating, whingeing and whining. If they want to talk about people who are aiming to win votes from the conservation lobby-let me repeat this, just in case those opposite have not heard it-the previous shadow Minister was reported as saying:
Future Liberal governments should be prepared to use Commonwealth powers to override States' rights in a bid to win support from the conservation lobby.

Predictably the responsible Minister in the Northern Territory swung into action and described our friend the ex-shadow Minister as `a silverspoon trendy from the Adelaide Hills'. Is that what honourable members think he is? The Northern Territory Minister responsible went on to say:
The last thing we need is wet statements from wimps like this.

The responsible Northern Territory Minister has described the former shadow Minister in the Opposition here as a wimp and a silverspoon trendy. It is obvious what has happened. Since Senator Puplick put out his policy option paper on the environment, the forces of reaction and darkness have got their act together and crushed any chance of the coalition having a responsible environment policy. I have here the Opposition's policy option paper entitled `Environmental Policy Option Discussion Paper' prepared by Senator Chris Puplick in December 1987. Let me tell honourable members that one of the options in this policy is to withdraw entirely from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation conventions. The boys want to take their bat and ball and go home; they want to get rid of it. They want this country to walk out and take no responsibility in the international community for looking after places such as the north-eastern rainforests through World Heritage listing. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill clearly indicates the intention of this Hawke Government to centralise further all power in Canberra and to provide the mechanism, through this legislation, for the Government ultimately to take unto itself the sole rights to dictate and control management of public and private property throughout this nation. I am very concerned, as is every member of the Parliament, that Australia's unique environment be protected, that it be managed and maintained for the benefit of present and future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: Many practices in the past in both urban and rural areas, either as a result of ignorance or in the quest for economic growth, or even in the quest for economic survival, have seen many parts of our environment damaged and many cases of enormous input being required from government to correct some of the damage that has been done. We could think of the inappropriate placement of chemical dumps or sewerage plants along our river systems in many of our States, serving both-should I mention this?-cities and rural townships. We could think of the enormous problem of salinity in the Murray Valley that is now extending to many of our dryland farming areas and our other river systems. We well remember the priority of the Hawke Government when it came to office and removed from the water resources program-a massive program-projects that would have corrected some of these problems that are so severely harming our environment. This nation is struggling to come to grips with the continual need to balance conservation with development. I was very interested in the comments made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) on this issue. I believe that he has brought this debate back into some sort of perspective.

No issue more clearly distinguishes the coalition from the Australian Labor Party, as it now moves relentlessly to extinguish private rights and civil liberties under the guise of a conservation Bill. The approach of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, in his approach to his portfolio, and his dictatorial attitude, which I remind the House may be the only way to stay at the top of the Australian Labor Party right wing pile, do not suit the people, as the recent elections throughout Australia have shown.

This Bill amends the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. It redefines `identified property' to bring it more into line with the actual workings of the Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. It allows any part of an identified property to be proclaimed and subjected to ministerial direction. It allows a property to be subject to the World Heritage listing protection before it is formally listed; for example, where a nomination is pending before the World Heritage Committee, or where the property is subject to an inquiry established by a law of the Commonwealth for the purposes of considering the potential World Heritage values of such property.

TALK.START.PARA: —More government from Switzerland.
—Why have a government at all?

—I can only agree with the interjections that have been made by my two colleagues, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) and the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb). Why have a government when we are going to accept some overseas authority over what should be our own responsibility?

SPEECH.PARA: The passing of this Bill will also establish a system of inspectors for World Heritage properties. Under the Bill the inspectors are supposed-and I emphasise the word `supposed'-to act with the consent of the property owner and on the basis of a judicial warrant, and in special or urgent circumstances. Fortunately, under this legislation entry to a dwelling house is prohibited. However, in relation to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, this is taken as not applying and never having applied to World Heritage properties. So while the rest of the community, such as mining companies, farmers and foresters, all have to abide by the environmental impact legislation, the Government's actions are to be exempt. I ask the Chairman of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, my colleague the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), to comment on this particular action that excludes the Government from responsibility for its actions whilst expecting everyone else in the community to follow the environmental impact legislation.

What then are the effects and the ramifications of this Bill? Firstly, and importantly, it intends to pass the final and sole responsibility for deciding World Heritage status in Australia to an external body. It abrogates Australia's sovereignty on these important conservation and environmental issues. Tragically, it ensures that the States cannot challenge any Federal Government decisions in respect of nominations of property for World Heritage status. The Government is saying to the people that they, as Australians, are not considered to be capable of making the informed decisions necessary on matters relating to their own heritage and in their own land, and that it is handing it over to an unelected, unrepresentative group overseas. I remind the House that some of the current membership of this overseas body, which includes of course Australia and about 100 other countries, includes such countries as Algeria, Malawi and Cuba, which are certainly not countries that are high on the list or known exclusively for the conservation and preservation of their lands.

Most disturbing of all is this system of inspectors who will be able to gather data on individuals and their activities for the Government. The Government assures us that these inspectors will be wearing photographic identity cards. It is claimed that these `Richardson's greencoats', as they have been called in this debate, will require a judicial warrant to enter private property. However, under the legislation there is an escape clause, which will allow inspectors to act even without such a warrant. I point out that these inspectors will need no special qualifications, yet they will have the right to enter, search, photograph and examine private property and vehicles at any time of the day or night-providing it is for, as they see it, an eligible purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful. It will allow this Government and the Australian Labor Party to further extend the jobs for the boys concept, which they have taken to an art form over recent months. One can well foresee a regime of World Heritage inspectors led by more and more failed Labor Party politicians as they find themselves incapable of finding work in the real world. We are entering a very sad stage of development in the evolution of Australia and Australian culture when we start adopting these sorts of attitudes and taking these sorts of actions towards ordinary Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The protection of the rights of individuals will be completely infringed by this legislation. There must occur invasions of privacy as we witness transgressions on the basic right to own land and to have a quiet and peaceful possession and occupation of that land. What about the penalties that may be imposed? Under this legislation if a property owner should seek in any way to restrict an inspector's right to enter his property, he may be fined $1,000 or be imprisoned for 12 months, or both. Even if the landowner seeks to question the inspector, he may still be imprisoned for 12 months or fined $1,000. An owner could be treated as having transgressed on his own land, and he faces penalties worse than many criminals receive for abuse against the property of a fellow citizen. In other words, under this legislation a private property owner could well be treated worse than any abuser of game laws in any State. As a result of this legislation he will be put in a more inferior and onerous position than one who trespasses on land.

A major aspect of this legislation relates to the action on the part of the Government in rejecting the jurisdiction of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. I referred to this issue earlier. That will mean that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act in this instance no longer need apply to World Heritage areas. It seems quite incredible to me that the Hawke Government is not willing to have its World Heritage areas, such as those proposed in north Queensland, stand up to the open scrutiny of environment impact procedures. The only conclusion that one can draw from this is that the area does not in the main have the intrinsic value that the Government claims it has. It is no wonder, therefore, that we have witnessed this untimely haste to push this proposal through in this legislation.

I am particularly concerned about the effect of this legislation in the short term on the listing proposal for Queensland rainforests. I shall spend some time on this subject as it is an important issue in the concept of this debate. The misrepresentations and misinformation of the Minister, Senator Richardson, should be corrected. For instance, he has never told the Australian people that effective forest management in Queensland has seen the Queensland Government, of its own volition, reduce the timber harvest from 195,000 cubic metres a year to 60,000 cubic metres a year to ensure that it can sustain the logging industry indefinitely and continue to employ between 2,000 and 3,000 people in the industry at an economic benefit of $33m a year to Queensland and Australia. Instead, the Minister has used this positive action of the Queensland Government to promote his argument that the industry is not viable.

The Minister claimed on 3 March that 45 per cent of the rainforests in this region has been logged. That statement is deceitful and wrong. The proposed World Heritage area is now clear for all to see. It shows that there is in excess of 900,000 hectares of land-in other words, land the size of the State of Victoria-included within the World Heritage listing. Of that 900,000 hectares, 143,000 hectares has been logged. The Minister said that 45 per cent has been logged. But he conveniently forgot the 61,000 hectares in the timber reserve, 120,000 hectares in national parks, 44,000 hectares in cattle grazing leases, and 5,000 hectares on freehold and freehold selections. Therefore, only 16 per cent of the total 900,000 hectares has been logged and only 23 per cent of the rainforest has been logged.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is deceitful.

—It is deceitful. As a Victorian I am concerned that these people in Queensland, to whom many of us have spoken-that is, foresters, timber mill operators and workers, and personal holders of private property-are being used as personal pawns and are being manipulated by the Hawke Government. The political conquests of this Government must not be permitted to bring about the abolition of private property. Nor should professional idealists and vote gathering politicians be permitted to manipulate this issue in such a way as to serve their own predatory and, in some cases, devious purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fitting in this debate to mention the coalition government's record on conservation and environment issues. The coalition's policy has been consistent and is one of compromise and consensus. I genuinely believe that the performance of the coalition government, at Federal government level, speaks for itself. Honourable members should remember that a coalition government established the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. A coalition government placed stage one of the Kakadu National Park on the World Heritage List and brought about the cessation of whaling in Australian waters. It was also a Liberal-National Party government that took the major initiative of developing and endorsing Australia's national conservation strategy. A coalition government also, of course, introduced the national tree program.

The National Party, probably more than any other political party, has a vital and vested interest in conserving Australia's environment. Most of our members live in rural areas. Many derive their income from the soil and the products of the soil. It is therefore in their best interests, if for no other purpose than to maintain a sustainable livelihood, to conserve our soil, water and wildlife. It is so important that there be continual and sustainable use of this country's resources, while at the same time ensuring that the natural heritage of this nation is approved.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, applying commonsense.

—That is so; applying commonsense and ensuring that policies fit in with an overall pattern for government, as I believe the coalition's policies do. The coalition's policy in this regard is balanced, affordable and workable and has regard for our national heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to sum up the effects of this legislation. There is not the slightest doubt that the powers of the Commonwealth are enhanced and further extended by having greater power over many parts of the World Heritage listed areas rather than more general areas. Environmental impact statements will not be required for actions or projects in World Heritage listed areas approved by the Minister, as they are for every other authority and individual. A new system of inspectors will permit greater gathering of data.

During consideration of a World Heritage nomination, avenues of appeal to the High Court of Australia have been effectively curtailed, as is apparent with the current Queensland appeal. There is absolutely no justification for an extension of these Commonwealth powers, nor for the exclusion of environmental impact statements provisions over ministerial approved projects. The Opposition finds the inspectorial system most objectionable also. It is virtually an openhanded invitation to abuse of private ownership and rights. The warrant provisions that exist in this legislation are farcical, given that such a warrant may be granted by any judge of a court created by the Parliament, who consents to serve for this purpose. In other words, even a Family Court of Australia judge could qualify to grant a warrant. The system of photographic identity cards for inspectors is an interesting attempt to bring the ID card issue back into public debate.

A number of Government members have said in this debate that following recent High Court rulings about Tasmania's southern forests it is inaccurate to suggest that the Federal Government can prescribe State land use. I disagree. Some judges in their conclusions suggested that the Commonwealth would have power over any area it may consider declaring as World Heritage in the future. It is clear also that if the control of buffer zones around World Heritage areas is necessary under World Heritage requirements, the power of the Federal Government could well be limitless. As Mr Justice Dawson said in his ruling, there appears to be no practical limit to the scope of the external affairs power.

This legislation removes the sensible course of consultation and agreement between State and Federal governments. It overrides the legislative role of the State in land use. It does not just affect environmental issues; it paves the way for massive expansion of Commonwealth powers across a broad spectrum of responsibility. This nation, of course, has quite clearly shown in the last week in elections held around the country that it is not prepared to tolerate government by factions.

I condemn the Federal Government for its unilateral approach to World Heritage listing without the support of various State governments, and particularly local government. Labor has been defeated not only in recent Federal and State by-elections and elections but also in council elections. In the Shire of Johnstone in the rainforest area, all Australian Labor Party councillors were defeated last Saturday. We praise the Forestry Department of Queensland-I have studied this very closely-for its effective forest management of the 18.7 per cent of the defined area in which logging is permitted. We also praise the Queensland Government for designating 75 per cent of the region either as national park or as forest reserve in which no logging is permitted.

I condemn the way in which boundaries have been determined in this exercise and for their irrational nature. Areas which are not tropical rainforests have been included, while others which are have been excluded. I refer honourable members to the original maps that were produced in regard to this listing. Not only could we not clearly define the reasons why the area had been so drawn, but also we were shocked to find that many areas had been excluded, areas which rightfully should have been included as World Heritage areas, particularly those on the fringing reef.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have looked after their mates.

—That is exactly what happened. Areas were excluded because they were owned by conservationists and environmentalists. In other words, the Government excluded areas that belonged to its mates. Fortunately, our promotion of this issue ensured that this position has been rectified.

SPEECH.PARA: I also express concern that the boundaries include some private land which is defined as corridors between recommended areas, but in regard to which normal rights of ownership are still prejudiced. I express concern that the Federal Government has ignored the social, economic and employment interests of those involved in the area, including those who utilise its timber and mineral resources. This House should note the irony of the proposal to close off a small area in which timber harvesting is effectively managed. This will necessitate imports from Third World countries where rainforest management is generally totally absent. I refer, of course, to what took place in relation to the building of the new Parliament House in Canberra. I believe that the World Heritage listing of the area, if it proceeds as proposed, will meet neither the objectives of those who live or work in the region nor those of the genuine conservationists. I oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with much pleasure to speak in support of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 which amends the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 by strengthening and clarifying the protection afforded under that Act. On 4 May 1983 I spoke in this House in support of the original World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill. On that occasion I referred to the unlawful and immoral acts which the Tasmanian Government had perpetrated in the south-west forests of Tasmania. It is pleasing to note that the World Heritage legislation has added strength to the protection afforded to the existing World Heritage sites of the Great Barrier Reef, Kakadu National Park, Willandra Lakes, Lord Howe Island and the western Tasmanian wilderness national parks. Since that time the Federal Labor Government has added to the World Heritage List stage 2 of Kakadu National Park, Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park, and also, with the strong support of the previous New South Wales Labor Government, the Australian east coast temperate and sub-tropical rainforest parks.

SPEECH.PARA: With last Saturday's election win by a conservative Liberal-National Party coalition Government in New South Wales, it is with much regret that I forewarn that we will not see much support for conservation of our national heritage in that State for the next four years. To those New South Wales conservationists who might have voted for the Liberal and National parties in that election, I can say only that they will find to their cost that conservative politicians, with few exceptions, will inevitably support development and so-called States rights even if it means sacrificing the protection of the built and natural environment. And so it is with the present Bill. In the Senate and the House of Representatives there is total opposition by senators and members from the Liberal and National parties on the grounds of so-called States rights. Nobody more vehemently puts that point of view than the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). One important aspect of the amendment Bill is that it will overcome the intransigence of the Queensland Government by providing interim protection to the wet tropical forests in Queensland pending a decision by the World Heritage Committee on the nomination by the Federal Government of the wet tropical rainforests of north-east Australia in December last year.

In my speech in 1983 I suggested some amendments which would strengthen the Bill. I am most pleased to note the new provisions of the amendment Bill which, in my view, will achieve that purpose. In particular, the amendments ensure that the Act will provide interim protection for all three stages of the nomination process for World Heritage listing, involving identification of the property, nomination of the property and, finally, listing. I also welcome the power to appoint inspectors, who will prevent unlawful acts being committed which could jeopardise the World Heritage status of the property, such as wilful damage or destructive development. The proposed amendments will ensure that attempts by the Queensland Government to sabotage the World Heritage nomination of the north Queensland rainforest will not be successful, as the amendments will provide official protection to prevent such acts of vandalism.

I was particularly surprised to read the remarks of Senator Puplick in the Senate last week. He described the legislation relating to the inspectors as an appalling, new intrusive system. Of course, we heard similar remarks from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) and other members of the Opposition. They choose to ignore the vandalism of the Queensland Government and its supporters in its attempts to destroy the Daintree Rainforest, in particular, which has necessitated the appointment of inspectors. I have witnessed scenes of vandalism on a number of occasions during visits to north Queensland. The honourable member for Mallee asked me why I supported the proposal for the appointment of inspectors. It is because I have seen this vandalism.

In August 1984 the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation presented a report in this House on the need for protection of the greater Daintree Rainforest and referred to the desecration of the rainforest presented by the construction of a coastal road north of Cape Tribulation. As Chairman of the Standing Committee I, together with other members of that Committee, visited the road construction site on several occasions. Our first inspection was in July 1984. It included a visit to the site of the Cape Tribulation-Bloomfield Road. We undertook an aerial inspection of most of the greater Daintree area. We also made a trip by boat along the coast between Cape Tribulation and the Bloomfield River. I wish I had time in this debate to describe the beauty of the area, which is really most spectacular. I have been asked not to be too long, so I will confine my remarks to the World Heritage values.

There are 30 major vegetation complexes in the area, including 15 distinct types of rainforest, eucalyptus forest, mangroves, coastal swamps and mountain moorland. The rainforest types contain a large number of species, including rare plants. There are many examples of plant communities and species which do not occur anywhere else in the world. After the dinner break I will quote from the report of the Committee, which confirms the importance of the greater Daintree.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was speaking in support of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill that is now before the House. I was pointing out why I am so very much in favour of this amendment Bill which will strengthen the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, particularly by the appointment of inspectors. Members of the Opposition were ranting and raving before dinner--
—You wait until after dinner.

—Yes, I am sure that there will be more, especially from the honourable member for Franklin who is sitting over there at the moment. The point is that they were ranting and raving about the appointment of these inspectors, saying that it was a great intrusion and so on. I want to point out the reasons why it is necessary to have these inspectors in place and able to prevent the sort of vandalism in which the Queensland State Government in particular has been involved.
—And Tasmania.

—And the Tasmanian Government also, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who is at the table, has just pointed out. I will quote from the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, of which I was Chairman. As I pointed out before dinner, we have been to the area of the Daintree Rainforest in particular, and I described what a beautiful and unique area it is. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The area contains examples of 8 of the 14 primitive plant species and is therefore considered to have some of the most important botanical sites in Australia. It has been suggested that there has been a continuous line of evolution from the earliest flowering plants with the vegetation developing relatively undisturbed by continental and climatic change over the last 150 million years. For this reason the area holds immense interest for botanists.

The forest near Cooktown was the first in Australia to be examined thoroughly by botanists and has remained relatively unchanged since the naturalists who accompanied Captain Cook explored the area in 1770. It therefore forms an important benchmark for ecological research.
Since that time both logging and development land subdivisions have caused desecration problems. I quote again from the Committee report:

Virgin rainforests with high conservation and scientific values are being sub-divided and cleared for rural housing in the Cow Bay area. Approval for this sub-division was given before the National Park was established and is occurring on privately owned land. The Committee inspected some sub-divisions and associated roads and were concerned that the developments might be causing serious environmental impacts and might not be an appropriate form of zoning for that area. The destruction of this rainforest may not be consistent with the proposals to preserve and protect the vegetation of the Greater Daintree region.

I point out that at that time there were advertisements in the Press in Victoria and New South Wales advertising this land for sale and saying, `Buy your own piece of rainforest-10 acres of rainforest'. Of course, many people were foolish enough to buy slices of this land before actually going up there and having a look at it. This area in the wet season is covered by several feet of water and has rocks and all sorts of vegetation over it. It is virtually an impossible place in which to build any sort of dwelling. Yet this is what was being done. It was complete desecration of rainforest.

A majority of the Committee made a number of recommendations in their August 1984 report of which the most important was that the Commonwealth Government consider applying the provisions of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act if it were found that the greater Daintree region was worthy of World Heritage nomination and that consultation with the Queensland State Government and offers of financial assistance were unsuccessful. Regretfully, the three Opposition members of the Committee dissented from the recommendations, basically on States' rights grounds which I have to say amounted to permitting the destruction of the rainforest which was being caused by the road construction and by subdivisions.

In preparing its November 1985 report which was on the protection of the Great Barrier Reef, the Committee visited the area again. Members were absolutely appalled at the desecration of the rainforest which had occurred as a result of the road workers. Mud had been washed down onto the reefs which were offshore from the beaches which extend from Cape Tribulation to the Bloomfield River. I point out to honourable members that the reefs are part of the Great Barrier Reef and are the most extensive fringing reefs adjacent to rainforest in the world. They have developed despite the high rainfall in the area because the watershed is drained by numerous small creeks. The action of the waves is also weakened by the extensive mangrove development. That allowed the reefs to grow also.

Scientists from the Australian Institute of Marine Science in their surveys of the coral on the reefs found that, whilst the corals were not as scenic as those on the deeper reefs of the outer reef where the water is clearer, the reefs were more diverse, with an unusually high number of coral types. The scientists' conclusion was that the corals were both significant and unique from a conservation and scientific view. Another quote from the 1985 report will indicate the concern which Committee members of all parties had at the effect of the road works. The scientists had observed these problems. We decided to put this in our report because we were concerned as well. The report states:

The scientists later observed that muddy water from the road was flowing into creeks and discharging over the reefs where some of the sediment was deposited. There are no relevant studies in Australia which would enable the effects of this increased sediment load on the reefs to be assessed but reports from Thailand and Japan suggest that the loss of coral and death of the reefs is possible. It is difficult to predict what the long term outcome will be but it appears that at best there will be an alteration of the species composition and possibly a reduction in the diversity of the reefs. At worst the reefs will be destroyed. The Committee views these possibilities with concern and considers that urgent action is required, not only to protect the reefs in the long term but also to prevent further erosion and damage to the rain forest. Extensive work will be required to stabilize the road and the surrounding earth works, regardless of whether the road remains open or is closed.

That is a fairly long quote, but I think it is very important for honourable members to appreciate what the scientists of the Australian Institute of Marine Science had said and what we Committee members were concerned about. I also want to quote from the Committee recommendation. It states:

the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment seek discussions on the importance of the fringing reefs with the Queensland Government and jointly sponsor an independent engineering study to determine ways of reducing the impact of runoff from the Cape Tribulation to Bloomfield Road on the fringing reefs north of Cape Tribulation.

At this stage I commend both the previous Minister, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), and the present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Graham Richardson) on their determined efforts to save the Daintree Rainforest. Despite many attempts by the honourable member for Robertson to have meaningful talks on the possibility of closing the road and providing some protection for the fringing reefs, the Queensland State Government refused to take part in any meaningful discussions. That situation still applies. Anybody who visits that road can see the terrible state that it is in. It was never contoured properly, the work was never done properly; in fact, there really was no need at all for that road to be constructed and for the rainforest to be destroyed in the way that it was.

It is for this reason that this amending legislation is put before the House. It is for this reason that we need inspectors in that area to ensure that these sorts of acts of vandalism do not continue. It is absolutely necessary that we protect these World Heritage areas, not only for Australians but for all the people of the world, because the areas have an important value for everyone. The main point I wish to make is that this amending legislation has been forced upon us because of the intransigence of the Queensland State Government, in particular, and also of the Tasmanian State Government. I am pleased to be here today to support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the House is to amend the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. It is impossible to consider this Bill without also considering the effect it will have on matters not directly related to it, such as States rights and civil liberties. One must also consider matters that might be broadly termed conservative issues. In my contribution to the debate tonight I wish to refer to those two matters, particularly the impact that this Bill, and other measures that are being taken, will have on civil liberties and the right to own private property. I also want to consider the impact of this Bill and other conservation measures on the balance of powers between the Commonwealth and the States.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind honourable members on the opposite side of the chamber of some of the provisions contained in the Bill. I shall quote directly from the Bill, without any elaboration. First, let us consider the definition of an identified property as contained in the Bill. An identified property is, firstly, property subject to an inquiry, such as the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests, or other inquiries that might be set up by the Commonwealth; and, secondly, property the subject of a World Heritage List nomination. It does not necessarily have to be on the World Heritage List; a nomination is sufficient. Thirdly, an identified property is property included on the World Heritage List or, fourthly, forming part of the cultural or the natural heritage and declared by the regulations to form part of the cultural or natural heritage. The fourth clause does not refer to World Heritage values or anything related to them. It simply says that some public servant, some member of a government at some time in the future, may in his opinion consider an area of land to be of such value that a regulation should be passed declaring it a cultural heritage area and therefore coming within the provisions of this Act. It does not draw a distinction between Crown land or private land; in fact, it does not draw any distinctions at all.

The Bill completely distorts the values which in the past we may have placed on the private ownership of land. I think we can probably obtain an assessment of the attitude of members of the Government towards the private ownership of property from a statement made by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in a debate in this House on the proposed introduction of the Australia Card. He said that civil liberties were akin to a bourgeois right to hold private property. That statement indicates the opinions of Government members towards the private ownership of land. Mr Deputy Speaker, let us consider what is happening right now in your State of Queensland. This Government is introducing legislation to say that an area of north Queensland is to be nominated for inclusion on the World Heritage List. Included in the area of listing are over 2,000 private properties, yet this Government draws no distinction between land held by private owners and land held by public owners. It is simply an area that this Government alone considers should be included in that listing.

What the Government is doing is placing not only Crown land but all private land in jeopardy. There will no longer be sanctity for anybody to own private land. The Government is not drawing a distinction between what might be contained in the Daintree area or in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests of Tasmania, or any other cultural area. Why would it not be within the capacity of any future Federal government under this legislation to declare Bondi Beach for World Heritage listing and exclude people from bathing there? I would like to point out to the House and to the people of Australia some of the measures which the Bill proposes. In the debate on this Bill in the other chamber, some of these measures were likened to jackboots and nazi-type tactics. I would not use expressions such as that; I do not think that is appropriate in parliamentary debate. But those remarks indicate the strength of feeling which members of parliament have about this Bill. If a person owns private property, it will be unlawful for him to do any act, if it comes within the provisions of this Bill, except with the consent in writing of the Minister. It does not matter that it is a person's private property. He must obtain approval in writing from the Minister to perform any act on that property.

In earlier contributions to the debate we heard about the so-called inspectors who are to be appointed under this Bill. What can the inspectors do? The Bill provides that the Minister may, in writing, appoint a person to be an inspector for the purposes of this Act. It also provides that an inspector may enter and search an eligible place; take photographs and record occurrences in an eligible place; and inspect, examine and take photographs and measurements of an eligible thing. For the purpose of exercising powers under paragraph 2 (c) of proposed section 17a, an inspector may stop, detain, enter and search any vehicle. What on earth is the Government doing? Has it no concern for civil liberties? In earlier debates I have heard the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) plead with great passion about the need to protect civil liberties, and I agree with him. But what the Government is doing in this legislation is destroying civil liberties. I acknowledge that the Minister believes passionately in the need to preserve the environment, but what he is saying is that, because he believes passionately about the environment, the Government will destroy all civil liberties if they threaten the environment. I am sorry, but I do not agree with that. I think that the maintenance of civil liberties is far more important than the maintenance of a few trees. One can grow more trees, but once civil liberties are destroyed they cannot be reimposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not reading it right.

—The Minister should study history. He will see that in nazi Germany the undermining of civil liberties began innocently and developed into a very nasty event. We should learn those lessons of history. What will happen if people owning private property dare to contravene the provisions of this Bill? They will be exposed to a penalty of $1,000 or imprisonment for 12 months. So, one would hardly lightly contravene the provisions of the Bill. In order to ensure that one does not do so, the Government will appoint a whole series of inspectors to go around and take photographs, enter property, and take any evidence they choose. This takes democracy in Australia into a whole new ball game. We should not head down that path very lightly.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard from the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) about the responses of the Council for Civil Liberties and people around this country-responsible people-who are concerned about the undermining of civil liberties which this measure threatens. That seems to mean nothing to honourable members opposite. They believe that the environment is far more important than civil liberties. I do not agree with them, but that is their response. There is no doubt that responsible civil liberties groups around Australia are extremely concerned about the effect this measure will have.

One should ask why the Government is prepared to take such an extreme measure. I guess that we can only speculate. It is my view that this Government, for electoral purposes, is trying to pander to conservation groups around this country. I urge my friends on the other side of the chamber to consider very carefully the conservation groups they are trying to appeal to. They will find that most of them are fanatics. They are fanatically interested and involved in the conservation movement and the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is good.

—That is okay. I do not disagree with that. They have every right to be fanatical about a single issue. Many other concerned people are fanatical about single issues, too. We might disagree with them, too. One cannot bow to fanatics. In governing one must make decisions that are balanced for the majority of people, not decisions that pander to a few fanatical people who might lobby for a particular issue. That is what this Government is doing-pandering to fanatics.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Government that it cannot appease fanatics. If one gives in and appeases them on one issue they simply move on to another area and ask one to appease them again. One cannot strike a balance. This is what has been happening, particularly in my State of Tasmania, with the conservation groups. It has been going on for a long time. We are well experienced in it in Tasmania. Conservationists say, `We want this area, which is a lovely area'-all of Tasmania is lovely, for that matter-`preserved for all time in the form of a national park'. The State Government says, `Right, it is a lovely area. We will declare it a national park'. Thirty per cent of Tasmania is now in the form of national parks. But the conservation movement says, `Thirty per cent of Tasmania is not enough. We want more'. It keeps on agitating for more. If one looks at the movement's agenda now, one finds that it still wants more. Even if the Government gets this legislation through and has the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests declared on the World Heritage List the conservation movement still has a list as long as your arm of other areas that it wants declared. One cannot appease them. One has to strike a balance based on commonsense. That is what this Government is not doing.

I put a proposition to the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests that what we should be doing in this country is declaring only one category that will protect an area for all time; that is, a national park. Once an area is declared a national park it should no longer be available for any form of development of its natural resources. Its timber resources, its mining resources and any other resources should be totally protected for all time. But if an area is not in a national park it should be available for development. Then the timber can be felled and regenerated; the area can be mined.

What we are seeing at the moment is the conservation movement expanding its territories by saying, `We consider that land to be a buffer zone'. That is the latest. It says, `We have that lovely national park. We have that area on the World Heritage List, but now we must have a buffer zone around that national park to protect it'. Once one has a buffer zone around a national park then one has to have a buffer zone around the buffer zone, and so on. That is what has been happening in Tasmania for years. I am sorry that my friends in Queensland are about to learn the same lesson.

Let us consider what this Bill does to States rights. Under section 51 of the Constitution, which has not been amended-it is still there-certain powers belong to the Commonwealth, and if certain powers are not listed it has always been assumed that any residual powers belong to the States. In the name of conservation the Constitution has been prostituted. The balance of powers between the Commonwealth and the States is changing dramatically. I do not mind if the Government wants to change the balance of powers between the Commonwealth and the States. I do not mind if it wants to be a centralist government. But it should not do it through the back door.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. As I understand it, under the Standing Orders of this House it is not permissible for a member to criticise the High Court of Australia. The High Court has made certain decisions on the Constitution which the honourable member calls `prostitution'.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—As I was pointing out, there is a change in the balance of powers between the Commonwealth and the States. I most certainly am not criticising the High Court. The High Court has upheld legislation that has been put through this Parliament by this Government. It is not the decisions of the High Court that are wrong; it is the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests legislation and the Franklin River legislation-the legislation the Government has put through the Parliament-which have changed the balance of powers.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government believes that it is appropriate and if it believes that it has the support of the people of Australia to change the balance of powers between the Commonwealth and the States, it should put up a referendum-take it to referendum and try to have the Constitution changed. It should change section 51 of the Constitution to give the Commonwealth more powers. But it should not go through the back door. It should act openly and honestly and give the people of Australia the opportunity to say whether they want the balance of powers changed. That is not happening. I challenge my friends on the other side of this chamber, if they believe that they have the support of the people in accumulating and centralising more power here in Canberra, to put up a referendum and take it to the people to see what they say. But the Government does not have the guts to do that. It is prostituting the Constitution by back door methods. I do not consider that to be legitimate in this day and age.

I consider this Bill to be the most draconian Bill I have seen in my 13 years in this Parliament because it completely undermines our Constitution. It drastically changes the balance of powers between the Commonwealth and the States without legitimate authority from the people of Australia. At the same time, it sets up a series of so-called inspectors, which, very markedly, will undermine the civil liberties of people throughout this country, changing the whole ethos that has always surrounded the ownership of private property. No longer will there be a sanctity about owning private property. Some of my friends opposite might say, `That is fair enough'. But I ask them to consider that it has always been the dream of every Australian-good, hard working Australians-to own a little piece of this country, to own a house and a block of land. What the Government is doing in this Bill is destroying the sanctity that has always surrounded the ownership of private property.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not serious.
—I wonder what would happen if somebody suddenly decided that it was the honourable member's backyard that should become part of a World Heritage area.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. Perhaps the honourable member for Lyons could tell us about the inspection powers of the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member should not engage in specious points of order.

—Even at this late stage, I urge my friends on the other side of the chamber to reconsider what they are doing to this country under this measure. Even at this late stage there may yet be a last opportunity for them to change their minds. I urge them to think very carefully before they vote here this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) that this country is under attack in the most grievous and injurious way, that our Constitution has been prostituted, that every Australian must stand aside because some unknown person is going to race out and snatch the land from under his very house, and the house will then collapse into a hole in the ground. If one has ever heard a speech of nonsense or a speech without foundation in law or fact that was it. The Opposition is so concerned about the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill that there is not one member of the Opposition in this chamber.
—Not even a shadow Minister.

—Not even a shadow Minister. Yet people from the Opposition have been stating in this Parliament the great concerns they allegedly have about this legislation. It is a pity there are not television cameras in the chamber so that all of Australia could see that not one member of the Opposition is sitting in this chamber now. This shows how concerned Opposition members are: they are so worried about the legislation before the House that they do not give a damn and they do not even bother to come into the chamber to listen to the debate. This proves the shallowness of everything they have said in the Senate today and everything they have said in this House tonight. They are the most shallow Opposition this country has had the misfortune to have in its history. That is without question. They stand condemned tonight for their total lack of concern for the Parliament and for this legislation. This is the first time in my nearly four years in this Parliament I have ever seen this happen. There is no Opposition member in the chamber, not even a shadow Minister. Here comes the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). He has left the Young Liberals meeting downstairs and has decided to come in to show that the Opposition does have some concern. He is the only member on his side of the House. Why does he not sit in the shadow Minister's seat? There is nobody there.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the nonsense the honourable member for Lyons raised. He suggested to this Parliament that the Constitution has been prostituted. He drew attention to the specific powers contained in section 51 of the Constitution. He forgot the rest of the powers. That is typical convenient Liberal memory. Liberal members mention only one part of the Constitution and forget the rest of it. I suppose that is because in most cases they do not bother reading it. The simple fact of the matter is that the High Court of Australia-mostly populated by people appointed by Liberal governments, not Labor government nominees-has determined as a principle and a fact of law that this Parliament, the Parliament of the Australian people, has the constitutional power to enact such legislation. It is an unarguable fact. So let the Opposition members stand here with their platitudes, their nonsense and their distortions of truth and fact; the judgment of the people will be upon them. We know how shallow they really are. As I said, what has happened tonight simply proves it.

The honourable member for Lyons raised the wonderful image that suddenly people would be created who would wander around the place pinching people's land. Again, this is an indication of the lack of legal knowledge he has. This is the Opposition that was so concerned about civil liberties that it denied the Australian people the right to have a Bill of Rights. We see that finally, 35 minutes after the House started sitting this evening, the first shadow Minister has walked into the chamber. Maybe he is slightly concerned. Why does he not go to sit at the table? He is the first one who has fronted so far. We would like to see someone from his side concerned about the running of the House and with the legislation. Apparently he does not want to sit at the table either.

I was referring to the wonderful notion that somehow one can take land away from people in the manner I referred to. The honourable member for Lyons does not have an iota of knowledge or understanding of the English legal system. The simple fact is that all land vests in the Crown, be it the Crown in right of a State or the Crown in right of the Commonwealth. The best that any individual owns at law is a fee simple title. At law, a title in fee simple means that subject to the rights of the Crown a person has the right of occupation but the right of resumption is a right of the Parliament acting as the Crown in this country to resume that land at any time, subject to the laws of the country. That has always been English law. It is the law of all of the States of this country and it is the law of this Parliament. So what the honourable member for Lyons was talking about is an absolute nonsense.

Is he suggesting that this Parliament should not have the power, in the interests of the nation, to resume land? That is the tenor of what he was saying. I guess one would draw the conclusion that as a member of the Opposition he is saying that if Australia were faced with an external threat of some magnitude and the Australian Parliament, representing the Australian people, saw fit in the defence of this country to resume land from private ownership, it should not have that power as the Australian Parliament. Is that what the honourable gentleman is suggesting? Or is he suggesting that if a local council in any of the States of Australia desires for public purposes to create a public facility, that local government body does not have the right at law to resume land for that purpose either voluntarily, by negotiation, or compulsorily? The simple legal fact of the matter is that every local government body in this country has that legal power. But the honourable member does not seem to understand that or he wants to neglect that very simple legal fact.

So on all matters raised by the honourable gentleman he is wrong in fact and wrong in law, but his remarks are typical of the misdirection the Liberal Party of Australia so often takes. That misdirection was very obvious tonight. I went to a function at an embassy in Canberra tonight. In leaving the side door of the House to drive there I saw that a car full of Young Liberals drove the wrong way in a one-way street. Young Liberals cannot even get their road directions right so what hope does the Liberal Party in this House have when future Liberal members of this House drive up one-way streets the wrong way in Canberra? It bodes no good future for the Liberal Party.

This is really a debate about conservation but one would not have known it from some of the rubbish spoken so far on the Opposition side of the House. The real issue and the real debate is very simply about the rights of the Australian people to preserve for the future and for all time very special and rare flora, fauna, vegetation, forests and timber in areas of this country. There is no question that at this stage of Australia's development if steps are not taken to put aside forever, to preserve forever as wilderness areas such as the Daintree, the South West of Tasmania, Kakadu and the Great Barrier Reef, if legislation is not put down now to ensure that forever unarguably these areas are set aside for the future of Australia, for the posterity of this country, we will never again have the chance.

That is what this debate is really all about. Forget the semantics that both sides go on with, ultimately it comes down to the view of the Australian Labor Party in government and the view of the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party in Opposition. They can say what they like about this legislation-scare tactics and scaremongering, which is their wont-but really what they have to answer in this Parliament is why they opposed the introduction of Kakadu National Park, why they opposed the Daintree World Heritage listing, why they opposed the preservation of South West Tasmania and why they opposed every major conservation initiative undertaken by this Government? That is the real, simple issue in this debate in this Parliament, despite what anybody in the Opposition says in this House.

Members of the Opposition sometimes say that this Government has no mandate to do that. Are they seriously saying that in the 1987 election, when the preservation of the Daintree forest was an issue in the electorate, the Australian public, who voted with their feet and increased the majority of members on this side of the House, did not support the Daintree forest preservation program? Are they seriously saying today, six or seven months after that election, that the Australian people did not give this Government a mandate to pass the necessary legislation to ensure the future preservation of areas such as the Daintree? Is that what they are now seriously saying? If they are they are misjudging the mood of the people. If they are they are mistaken and they are foolish. If they are I am looking forward to the next election because I know where I will be; I will be back here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly endorse the position taken by the Opposition in relation to the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill, not, as honourable members on both sides of the House will know only too well, because I am unconcerned about environmental issues-I have a very real personal concern about conservation-but because when we look at this legislation fairly carefully we see that it is a political gimmick. This legislation is not a real piece of legislation designed to improve the welfare of this country, as it should be. I suppose one could say in a sense that the legislation is really about increasing the power of the Federal Government over properties which fall within the auspices of World Heritage listings, and I will come back to World Heritage listings a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is also a concession by this Government that it has failed to deal constructively with Australia's federal system. In this particular instance the Federal Government has done nothing even to enter into negotiations with the States to try to achieve some sort of consensus. This Government, after all, came to power in 1983 on the slogan of consensus. `Bring Australians together', I think, was one of the other slogans that were used. Ironically, when it comes to the environment, when it comes to cheap calculations of votes instead of matters of principle and national concern, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) pointed out, the Government will quickly abandon consensus and move on towards a policy of confrontation, which is precisely what this is. That is an argument that is simply incontestable.

I accept very well that environment and conservation issues should be an important part of national debate, and we on this side of the House want to do everything we can to ensure that there is a national approach to that important national issue. That is why we initiated, when we were in government, a national conservation strategy for Australia. Yes, it was the Liberal-National Party Government that initiated the national conservation strategy, which brought together conservationists, developers and politicians of different varieties. We know that in this country there is a broad measure of agreement about the need to conserve much of the beauty and the scientifically important parts of our natural environment. We know that there is a national consensus but, unfortunately, the Government is turning its back on that and using the issue simply as a political football.

I think we exercised in government very responsibly our commitment to conservation. We created stage 1 of the Kakadu National Park, which was an historic decision and initiative by the Fraser Government. We are very proud of the fact that we proclaimed the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority as well. I have mentioned already the national conservation strategy for Australia. We also, surprisingly to people on the other side of the House, regard the preservation of Australia's remaining rain- forests as a very important issue. We sincerely recognise the beauty, the scientific importance and the ecological significance of, for example, the Queensland wet tropics. It does not matter who one speaks to on this side of the House; there is a recognition of that, and there is no desire by anyone on this side of the House to see the Queensland wet tropics destroyed, nor is there any desire by the Queensland Government to see the Queensland wet tropics destroyed. Anybody who sits down and looks at the facts instead of listening to empty rhetoric will realise that that is a self-evident truth.

I must admit that it has always made me slightly angry to listen to the politically motivated and anti-Liberal-National Party rhetoric we get from some people in the Australian Labor Party-since they are our political opponents we cannot blame them for making political points-and from some people amongst the leadership, but not the ordinary members, of the Australian Conservation Foundation who say that if there were a Liberal-National Party government in Canberra or a National-Liberal Party government in Queensland, or whatever, the Queensland wet tropics would face extinction. If we sit down and look at the way the Queensland Government manages the wet tropics, whilst we may quibble about some of the exercises that take place-and I have sympathy and respect for people who quibble about the way logging takes place in the wet tropics-that is not the same as saying that the Queensland Government is hell bent on the destruction of the whole of the Queensland wet tropics. That simply is not the case. I plead with people, if they are serious about conservation issues, to try to put forward their own case with some intelligence and take that into account.

Everybody knows that in reality, if we set aside the cheap political rhetoric, the Tasmanian Government is not hell bent on turning the whole of the State into a desert and destroying the forests. It is clearly not true and I do not think any intellectual assessment would ever come to that conclusion. It is just rhetoric. However, it is regrettable that some of that hysterical and extravagant rhetoric, which is politically motivated, as we know too well, has been bought by the media, none of whom is here tonight to hear this debate; they only ever report Question Time. The fact is that members of the media will not investigate the details of the case. They simply pick up the loudest, most extravagant, most hysterical Press releases from all kinds of groups around the country, regardless of how representative or unrepresentative they might be, and give them all kinds of prominence. It does not do the country much good in terms of intelligent debate. I plead not only with members of this House, but with the three or four people around Australia who are perhaps listening to this broadcast, to try to ensure that we have a proper debate about conservation issues and not let it be reduced to sloganism and political rhetoric.

I think it is true to say that many honourable members on this side of the House recognise that there is a role for the Federal Government in ensuring that we conserve, intelligently and responsibly, our great national environmental resources. After all, we would not have sponsored the national conservation strategy for Australia if that were not our view. I do not oppose World Heritage listing per se. As I said throughout the last election campaign, I hope World Heritage listing can be achieved with the agreement of State governments and with a genuine attempt to reach agreement with State governments, instead of doing what this Government has done, which is simply to ride roughshod-obviously for political purposes-over the relevant State governments, not being Labor governments.

When we talk about World Heritage listing we have to be a little cautious not to take the rhetoric and the slogans on face value but to look into what World Heritage listing really means. I will look into it tonight in a slightly different way by referring this House to the telex which the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), Mr Charles Mott-he is a friend of mine and I think a very professional diplomat-sent to Senator Graham Richardson. As Senator Puplick said in his Press release recently, it blows the whistle on the Federal Labor Government. In the telex that Charles Mott sent in December 1987 he admitted:
The IUCN in fact has never visited Kakadu officially, not even in 1981 when Stage 1 was listed-
that was by the Federal Liberal-National Party Government, of course-
and certainly not for Stage 2.

Goodness me, that really is a revelation. I wonder how many people in Australia who are interested in conservation issues-and there are a lot of such people-knew that the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) did not actually visit Kakadu stage 1 and stage 2 in this particular context?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there something wrong with that?

—Somebody on the other side of the House asks whether there is something wrong. The answer is that there is something wrong because under the rules of UNESCO, which as we know is responsible for the World Heritage Committee and World Heritage listings, it is a requirement that either the IUCN, in the case of natural sites, or the International Council on Monuments and Sites, where nomination involves things that have been built, must visit the particular site before the nomination is accepted. So it is a little surprising that we learn from Ambassador Mott that this did not happen in the case of stage 1 and stage 2 of Kakadu. It is really quite a revelation. If we read on through Ambassador Mott's telex we learn more and more.
