I have said already that the normal, formal procedure, which was to follow the guidelines for the implementation for the World Heritage Convention, as they are called, was not followed in relation to Kakadu stage 1. Mott's telex goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: There was . . . no IUCN report on Kakadu, a fact which the Americans, the only delegation on the Committee unhelpful to our cause, pursued at length in questioning . . .

They may have been unhelpful but the fact that the guidelines were not followed is not a bad point, is it? Funnily enough, apparently nobody in Australia actually knew this, until now. What is going to happen in the case of the World Heritage listing of the Queensland wet tropics? I turn again to Ambassador Mott's historic, I think, telex to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, (Senator Graham Richardson), who, as we all know, has nothing to do with the environment but lots to do with trying to ensure that the greenie vote is delivered to the Australian Labor Party. Everyone knows that; I do not know why I bother to mention it. Ambassador Mott's telex advises Richardson:
For Queensland it is desirable that Thorsell-
that is, James Thorsell of Canada, a very well respected gentleman who is expected to lead an IUCN team to Australia later this year-
visit and he be well looked after.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will be well looked after? What does he mean by that?
—The honourable member for Dawson raises a very good question: What does he mean by that? Let us look at Mott's telex. He goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It would also help if Canberra Ambassadors of WHC member states could be taken to the forests and shown around.

So we are going to look after the key man and we are going to show around the ambassadors from the countries that might be involved in making decisions. It is not exactly a government calling for an objective assessment; it is a government running a political campaign. That is what I would do if I were running a political campaign. As a politician, I have a few ideas about political campaigns. That is not the way to get an objective assessment, and unfortunately Ambassador Mott's telex reveals the game being played. This UNESCO Ambassador, Charles Mott, reports in relation to the World Heritage Committee secretariat:
Secretariat would like to use Australia as `a motor' (their words) to promote World Heritage Work in Asia, a region that is below par in the field . . .

That may be so; but to use Australia as a motor? Again that is not an objective assessment; it is using Australia as a motor-a vehicle if you like; a motor being a bit smaller than a vehicle-to try to achieve some sort of political end. Frankly, I think that revelation from the telex of Charles Mott raises enormous questions, unfortunately, about the whole issue of World Heritage listing that need to be very carefully considered when these issues are debated.

I urge all members of this House to try to look at the facts and not just be swept along by a lot of empty, excited rhetoric. I mention these points as a person who has a lot of sympathy for the idea of World Heritage listing. I am not in principle opposed to it but I would like to feel that the system is a genuine system and not one which is being promoted and abused for simple political purposes. We on this side of the House want a co-ordinated national approach to these issues, not just legislation which is confrontationist-which is what this is. The Minister for the Arts, Sport the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, has apparently in the case of the Queensland wet tropics refused to negotiate with Mr Ahern, the Premier of Queensland, and the Queensland Government. That contrasts with the position taken by the Opposition spokesman, Senator Puplick, and by others. The Opposition has literally sat down with Mr Ahern to discuss ways in which the Commonwealth and the State could work together to ensure that the Queensland wet tropics are properly conserved and that a minimal amount of logging can go ahead in areas where it will not do fundamental, long-lasting environmental damage but will, on the contrary, conserve the jobs of people who work in those industries.

This legislation is the antithesis of that approach that the Opposition has been able to establish-and we are only an Opposition; it is an approach that the Government has refused to countenance because, let us face it, the Queensland Government is a National Party government and the Federal Government is a Labor Government. It is great politics for the Labor Party to go around and the kick the Nats. It gets all the greenies to think that the Queensland Government is a government of environmental vandals. The Government tries to create that impression while, on the other side of the debate, it tries to project itself as a government that is serious about conservation. Admittedly, fewer and fewer people now believe that the Labor Government is serious about those issues. Those honourable members who read conservation literature will be only too well aware of that. Perhaps some of them do not read it, but they would be aware of that if they did. Still, that is the name of the game certainly as far as Senator Richardson is concerned.

Here we have legislation that significantly increases the Commonwealth's power without any consultation with the States. It increases the Commonwealth's power in a whole variety of ways. It increases its power over parts of World Heritage listed or proposed World Heritage listed areas so that now the Commonwealth's power apparently extends to areas subject to an inquiry whose purpose or one of whose purposes is to establish whether the property is part of the cultural or natural heritage of this country. That gives the Commonwealth Government gigantic power. As somebody who is, at least from the point of view of this side of the House, quite strongly on the side of the Commonwealth having an involvement in the conservation of our greatest national environmental assets, I do think this oversteps the mark in an extraordinarily extravagant way.

This legislation also increases the Commonwealth's power very significantly by establishing this notorious system of inspectors-inspectors, who, by the way, go around with identity cards. I liked Senator Puplick's expression that these people should be described as Richardson's greenshirts. They certainly will be that. These inspectors can go anywhere on private property without the consent of the owner of that property. They can just march in. This reminds me of the famous comment by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) about private property being a bourgeois concept and nothing that should be taken too seriously by a socialist party such as the Labor Party, or words to that effect. Really and truly, we have it here again. Investigators and inspectors can march through private property. They can go anywhere, except, by the way, inside a dwelling house. They can stop, detain and examine any vehicle. The Government, by enabling the bureaucracy to do that sort of thing, is giving it an enormous amount of power.

Also in terms of the accretion in Commonwealth power, we have this quite extraordinary situation where environmental impact statements are required for any actions or projects in World Heritage areas but under this legislation, apparently for some reason-it is unclear to me why, in my ignorance-Commonwealth action is immune from those environmental impact statements. If honourable members on the other side of the House are sincere about conservation-I know that some of them, though not a lot, are sincere about it-why do they support that particular provision of this legislation? Why would honourable members support the proposal that the Commonwealth could build the monorail that it wanted to build at one stage from Ayers Rock out to the Olgas without an environmental impact statement? It is completely irrational. Either one is strongly in favour of conservation and wants environmental impact statements, or one is not. One cannot have it both ways. The Labor Government is trying to have it both ways with this legislation. I find that quite extraordinary. If the private sector wants to build a hotel, a convention centre or something else in a World Heritage area, there first has to be an environmental impact statement, and we on this side of the House have always supported that. But if the Commonwealth Government wants to build a monorail in such an area, there is no mention of an environmental impact statement.

Here we have legislation which is not genuine; it is a political stunt. No effort has been made to consult and to reach agreement with the Queensland Government, which we found easy enough to do in a few weeks. No effort has been made to reach an intelligent, cooperative solution. The rhetoric of consensus was just a political stunt and this legislation, unfortunately, is the same. I look forward to subsequent speeches from the other side of the House and hearing what the Government's responses are to Ambassador Mott's telexes from UNESCO in Paris revealing so much of the background of how Australia and the World Heritage Committee have actually worked in practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Towards the middle of his speech the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) tried to suggest that a lot of the debate on this legislation could be described as empty, excited rhetoric. If one is fairly objective in analysing his contribution, one would certainly apply that phrase, particularly after some of the scaremongering campaigns that the Opposition has once again tried to get going through the Australian community. I am sure that Peter Sawyer, with some of the nonsense he has been putting out of late, would be very proud indeed of some of the members of the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia-who have at times condemned some of the nonsense that he has put abroad-because the Opposition's contribution goes along the same sort of track.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take the powers of search and entry that are mentioned in the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill. There were a couple of special contributions to this debate, but I must say that the prize tonight goes to the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr). He told us of all of the horrific powers of search that would be involved under the Bill. But he failed to tell us that in his own State officers of the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service have far greater powers than those proposed for these Federal inspectors. For example, the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service Act 1970 gives authorised officers, as they are termed under section 41 of the Act, the power to seize anything on reasonable grounds suspected of being taken contrary to the provisions of the Act. Under section 42 of the same Act they have the power to search any premises, including private homes and vehicles. Under section 43 they have the power of arrest without warrant, even for failure to give one's full name and address.

In a report called Privacy and Statutory Powers of Intrusion that was produced in 1981 by the Law Reform Commission of Western Australia some significant points were made regarding so-called concerns about civil liberties that we have heard about in this debate from the honourable member for Lyons and the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). One should be aware that in Western Australia, under the Poultry Industry Trust Fund Act 1948-1969, inspectors checking the chooks must make entry `at a reasonably time', with the lights kept on day and night. So we obviously assume that the privacy and civil liberties of the chooks were eroded years ago when that Act was introduced.

This legislation is hardly a precursor to some sort of new environmental police state, which was suggested to us tonight by the honourable member for Mayo. During the debate in the Senate, Senator Walters expressed concern about being in a dark and lonely spot after midnight with a man trying to get into her car flashing something-a badge, it turned out. If the Opposition is really serious about looking for some sort of Big Brother or badge flasher in the bottom paddock, he is already there. He is not wearing a green shirt; he is wearing a brown shirt and he is probably a friendly officer from one of the dozens of boards, authorities or departments that deal with such important civil liberties concerns as public health, forestry, national parks and primary production.

I think it is important to make those comments because once again the Opposition has no reasonable grounds for attacking this legislation. It has no amendments of any great substance to move, and it certainly did not move any in the other chamber. All it can resort to is the politics of fear. We have seen it time and time again, and once more it has wheeled out the old fearmongering wheelbarrow to try to scare everyone in the community about this legislation, about what it purports to do and what it will do to people's civil liberties. But I do not want to concentrate on that.

In the time remaining to me I want to mention a deputation that I led last Friday to the National Farmers Federation. The country task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which I am honoured to chair, had some discussions with the National Farmers Federation (NFF) about a whole range of issues. One of the issues brought to our attention was the Federation's concern about World Heritage legislation, part of which is the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill before the House tonight. The National Farmers Federation made a number of comments to us. It mentioned that it had a number of serious concerns about what it saw as deficiencies in the Act.

It mentioned that it saw no procedures in the legislation for the selection of land to be considered for nomination, not even a requirement that there be an inquiry. It also pointed out that property can be identified when it is subject to an inquiry, but that the processes are not spelt out. When it is listed it is quite clear that it can be declared by regulation, but again the processes are not spelt out. It pointed out that it felt there had been a lack of consultation, although I understand from subsequent discussions with the office of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) that it has met the Minister over the last couple of days. It also pointed out that there were no provisions for management once nomination had been accepted by the World Heritage Committee.

I was concerned to learn of some of the points that were made by the National Farmers Federation. It is an important peak body representing the interests of the farming community in Australia. Upon hearing of these concerns, I and a number of other people who were present in that delegation decided to follow things up with the Minister's office. I am pleased to report to the House that the proposed amendments that were put forward by the Federation have been examined by the Government, but they have not really been accepted simply because they show a great misunderstanding of some of Australia's legal obligations under the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage as well as a misunderstanding about the process of nomination, the types of sites listed and the management of World Heritage sites. I should point out to the National Farmers Federation that the conduct of a resource study would be quite inappropriate. The issue to be settled is really whether a site is of outstanding universal value. The Convention contains extremely stringent criteria against which a site is assessed.

The NFF amendments presuppose that there can be properties of proven World Heritage value which are not desirable for nomination because of their resource value. This is certainly not the case. Properties are either of outstanding universal value or clearly they are not. I should point out that we should put into context the sorts of numbers we are talking about in this debate. I am informed by the Minister's office that we are dealing with some 20 private properties in the area of north Queensland and about eight in South West Tasmania. Yet after the contributions tonight by the honourable member for Lyons and the honourable member for Mayo, one could be excused for thinking that the Commonwealth was suddenly going to move into far north Queensland and Tasmania and assume total control over every piece of private property or that that had already happened.

The proposal that was put forward, to hold an inquiry in all cases, ignores the great deal of public consultation that has already taken place and is still taking place. While an inquiry may be appropriate in some cases, it is ludicrous to establish an inquiry for all proposed nominations; for example, the nomination of an archaeological site or restricted area within a national park.

The NFF assumes that World Heritage listing locks up an area and that activities such as grazing and mining are prohibited by that listing. Honourable members should understand that listing does not prohibit any of those sorts of activities. Management plans determine the future operations of World Heritage listed areas. Grazing occurs, for example, in the Willandra Lakes area in western New South Wales, and a wide range of activities are permitted on Lord Howe Island. Of course, there is also the tourist activity that is exploited on the Great Barrier Reef. Activities that do not affect World Heritage values will quite obviously be permitted under this particular proposal.

It is not appropriate, necessary, or required by the World Heritage Convention for management plans to accompany a nomination. The role of the World Heritage Committee is not to consider management plans but the value of particular regions. It is for the nominating country to decide how an area will be protected and managed. I am not talking about some outside group determining what type of management plan will be adopted in our own country. Quite clearly, that would be a decision for the Australian Government to make. The development of management plans often proceeds in parallel with a nomination. In some cases, proclamation and development of detailed management plans actually follows the listing. For example, on the Great Barrier Reef and Lord Howe Island, long, complex processes are required through a pro- cess of public consultation. Management plans also change and evolve in time. Therefore, the proposal of the NFF, if accepted, would quite clearly be a retrograde step.

Finally I wish to refer to the NFF's comments on compensation. The Bill provides for simplified provisions for the payment of compensation where the operation of the Act results in the acquisition of property within section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution. It is not appropriate for compensation for other effects of the Act to be covered by the legislation. This, quite clearly, is a matter of Government policy and is not a legal requirement. The NFF has said that it is not opposed, as a general principle, to conservation issues. Indeed, it has been very supportive of some of the efforts of this Government in relation to land degradation and the Government's conservation policy in that regard. However I should point out to the NFF that in this case it has been somewhat misguided in its representations to the Government and with some of the proposals it has put forward. I am sure the NFF put the proposals forward in good faith and I am sure it has sought to protect the interests of its members; but I am satisfied, following the consultation the Government had with the NFF last Friday, and advice provided to me by the Minister, that the concerns the NFF has for some of the elements embodied in the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill are unjustified. I am sure that the NFF can be satisfied that the interests of its members will not be affected in any negative way.

I totally support the sentiments of other members who have contributed to this debate in relation to the Government's point of view. I urge all thinking people who are concerned about genuine conservation issues to dismiss some of the rhetoric and nonsense we have heard in this House tonight. Quite clearly that type of rhetoric and emotional debate is no substitute at all for logical analysis of an important Bill such as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This so-called Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill is, in reality, just another illustration of this Government's willingness to sacrifice the long-term best interests of Australia and Australians on the altar of political expediency. The challenges we face in regard to sensitive and significant conservation issues cannot be solved by adopting such ill-founded and potentially dangerous legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition's opposition to this latest attempt by the Government to substitute confrontation for consultation will, no doubt, be deliberately misinterpreted by misinformed people as an indication that all coalition members, together with all mining companies and those involved in forestry industries, have no commitment to the protection and preservation of our environment and or the sensible and responsible management of our natural resources. This is demonstrably false and totally incorrect. We are opposing this legislation because it not only is unnecessary, but also sets dangerous precedents in regard to retrospectivity, the redistribution of power, and the rights of ordinary law-abiding Australians. It is yet another indication of this Government's preference for confrontation rather than consultation.

This Government claims to be concerned about the environment, but the provisions of this legislation include the removal of the requirement for environmental impact studies and, instead, substitute the approval of the Minister. In other words, the Minister can make up his own mind as to what is, and what is not, acceptable in regard to any activities in World Heritage listed areas. This has an obvious and inherent danger. But even more dangerous and objectionable is the proposal to introduce an environmental hit squad of inspectors appointed by the Minister. I am well aware that my coalition colleagues have already mentioned these appalling provisions. But their warnings cannot be overemphasised and bear repeating again and again. An inspector may, for an eligible purpose-and I quote the wording of the explanatory memorandum:

enter, search, photograph in and record occurrences in an `eligible place', . . . and inspect, examine, photograph and measure an `eligible thing' (with specific power to stop, detain, enter and search a vehicle for the latter purpose).

When one sees the wording, the officialese, of the parliamentary draftsman the mind actually boggles. There are few limitations on the powers bestowed on these inspectors. A token gesture restricts their power to enter an eligible place other than a public place or, in some circumstances, a vehicle, unless the consent of the person in charge of the eligible place or vehicle is obtained.

This provision is immediately watered down by another, which allows an eligible judge-who is satisfied by information on oath from an inspector that it is reasonably necessary that the inspector should, for an eligible purpose, enter an eligible place or vehicle to inspect, examine, photograph or measure an eligible thing-to issue a warrant authorising the inspector with such assistance, and by such force as is necessary and reasonable, to enter the eligible place or vehicle and exercise the not inconsiderable powers bestowed upon him or her.

As if this is not enough, there is yet another provision that allows the inspector to enter an eligible place if he or she believes, on reasonable grounds, that entry is necessary to prevent the concealment, loss or destruction of any thing and the circumstances are of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate entry without the consent of the person in charge or the authority of a warrant. This is an unreasonable, unjustifiable and unwarranted negation of civil liberties. It is a clear and frightening demonstration of just how far this Government is prepared to go in its attempts to subvert the rights of ordinary Australian citizens. We saw it with the identity card legislation and we are seeing it again here today.

My commitment to the protection and preservation of our natural heritage is very sincere and very real but it does not and cannot extend to supporting this draconian, insidious and demonstrably unnecessary legislation. There is no valid reason for this proposed extension of Commonwealth ministerial powers; no justification for setting up a special environmental police force with such unrestrained powers; no reason to substitute ministerial whims for environmental impact studies; and no reason to believe that conservation challenges will be better solved by the coercive measures and tactics contained in this Bill rather than by consultation and cooperation with and between all concerned parties, be they State governments, companies involved in the mining or forest industries, or any other appropriate groups, organisations and individuals. This is the wise, reasonable and acceptable alternative. It is the alternative the coalition is committed to and the alternative the present Government should adopt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. It is interesting for one who has listened closely to the debate so far and taken the trouble to peruse the report of the debate in the other place over the last week or so. It is unfortunate, as in current discussions of the matters of importance, that members of the coalition parties have chosen to misuse the facts. It is inherent in every debate they wish to enter that they choose to distort and to conduct fear campaigns. Let us look at some of the often repeated concerns about this legislation. One is the effects of part III of this legislation-an amendment proposed to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. It has been suggested that the amendments in the legislation before us will mean that in all cases the application of the impact of proposals Act will be null and void. That is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, if the Opposition bothered to study and digest the legislation it would see that it concerns only the action proposed under this legislation, which is merely listing under World Heritage and nothing else. The often repeated example that has been used by Opposition spokespersons-the monorail from Ayers Rock to the Olgas-clearly under the Act would be subjected to an environmental impact statement. There is nothing in this legislation that suggests otherwise. It is one of a number of furphies that have been raised in the debate in this chamber and in the other place. As I have said, it is unfortunate that this type of tactic is adopted day in and day out on a whole range of matters that come before us in public debate.

I do not intend to touch upon the notion of Richardson's greenshirts-the inspectors who will inspect properties-because my colleague the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), in indicating the powers of a range of inspectors under different Commonwealth and State legislation, debunked that argument. It is sheer nonsense. It is part of a continuing fear campaign that has little to do with the facts but a lot to do with mounting hysteria and sheer political gain. One of the main concerns-it is a genuine concern-people have when we talk about World Heritage listings that might be contemplated or enacted under this legislation is that in some way they might lead to job losses. It is unfortunate that there is a notion abroad that in any way protection of the environment per se has something to do with loss of employment. If we look at a whole range of examples we find that that is not the case.

My colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), in his contribution to this debate, clearly showed the situation concerning listings of Uluru and Kakadu and the increasing tourism in those areas. In those cases the World Heritage listings have been of great benefit in a range of employment opportunities. It is a nonsense to presume that environmental protection is in some way counter to the restoration of other forms of employment.

If we look at the particular listing that is the main topic of this debate, that is, the wet tropical rainforests of north-east Australia, and at the great concern amongst those in the logging industry, we find that that is something the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) has taken into account. People have been given the impression that there has been no consultation, but that is not true. Honourable members would have to acknowledge the number of visits made by the Minister and the most open way in which he has tried to conduct discussions. He has been subjected to all sorts of abuse but continues to try to work out ways in which those people most affected in the areas in question can be given other prospects.

It should not be forgotten by those who raise questions about the loss of jobs in the forestry industry in far north Queensland that the logging operations were winding down. There had been great difficulties which in some cases had not been confronted. It is unfortunate that, whether or not the listing went ahead, those problems would have had to be faced. There is very little evidence to show that the Queensland Government had addressed that problem. So there was already a problem that was not being addressed in an appropriate manner. The action which is now being undertaken gives us an opportunity to look at these matters. Senator Richardson has gone out of his way to try to provide alternatives, and I think it is a disgrace that as yet there has not been proper cooperation.

I return to the Federal Government's sovereignty in regard to putting up nominations for World Heritage listing. I listened with interest to some of the points made by honourable members opposite and the discussion of some of the decisions of the High Court of Australia and its interpretation of the Constitution. My colleagues the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) and the honourable member for Calare, who preceded me, have commented on the remarks made by the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) about the prostitution of the Constitution by legislation such as this. That is just a nonsense. The Constitution is not able to be tampered with by legislation. The High Court has made several decisions over a number of years about the Federal Government's rights in this regard. The relevant section of the Constitution, section 51(xxix), says that the Commonwealth has the power to make laws for peace, order and good government with respect to external affairs which govern conduct in and outside Australia. That is the relevant portion of the Constitution upon which a number of our international treaties and the Federal Government's ability to act under those treaties hinge. For the honourable member for Lyons to suggest that because of the way that this part of the Constitution has been interpreted-he does not particularly like the way it has been interpreted-it should be subjected to referenda is flying in the face of the manner in which Australia has continually developed since Federation in 1901.

Let us just quickly go over the history of environmental legislation. My colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory referred to legislation in the 1870s that was to do with the control of the forestry industry along the Murray-Darling Basin. Unfortunately from that time on there was very limited legislation on the environment. This will probably raise the hair on the back of the necks of those opposite: it was not until the Whitlam years that we saw further major advances in the protection of the environment. In May 1973 Australia joined the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources which had been established in 1948; so it was not as if it was something that we just merely jumped into. In 1975 we joined the International Centre for the Study of the Preservation and Restoration of Cultural Property which had been founded in 1959. In 1975 the Whitlam Government established the Australian Heritage Commission and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Again, during the Whitlam years Australia became the seventh signatory to the World Heritage Convention. By 1986, 89 national governments had accepted the Convention. Today there are 100. Honourable members should be interested to know, as has been indicated earlier in the debate, that there are now some 288 listings throughout the world.

I want to touch on one aspect of a telex that has been bandied about in this debate. It is a telex from our representative to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO). It is unfortunate that it has been selectively quoted on a number of occasions. A number of suggestions are made in that telex that are of importance and should not be sneezed at. One suggestion was sneezed at by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). It was suggested that the World Heritage Committee was conducting its future development to widen the scope of the World Heritage listing that `Australia be used as a motor to promote World Heritage work in the Asian region'. We hear a lot of talk from those opposite of the need for Australia to widen its horizons on the international front. In matters such as environmental protection there is no harm in Australia being seen as a motor to promote World Heritage.

If we look at the 288 listings we see that there are few other countries that have listings in our region. There are a couple of listings in New Zealand and that is about it in regard to our near neighbours. We should look upon Australia with pride because it has had some motivating influence in trying to get other countries in our region involved. One absence in the signatories to the Convention is, notably, Japan. I think that people in this House would recognise and understand that there are a number of both cultural and natural properties in Japan that would be most suitable for World Heritage listing. I think it is a nonsense to pooh-pooh the notion that we should be seen as being some example in our region.

There was another selective quoting about the need for us to take action to ensure that the representatives of the 21 nations on the World Heritage Committee-it should be noted that Australia has been one of those nations since the inception-fully understand our proposal. Tonight that has also been taken out of context. The suggestions from our representative to UNESCO were that the States and the Territories-the Northern Territory and Tasmania in particular-in the most recent of the World Heritage listings have taken large contingents across to Paris when the Committee met for its annual meeting. As my colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory indicated, they have spent a lot of money on promoting and lobbying for their case.

It was in that context that suggestions were made that we should be more diligent and careful in the way that we conducted ourselves in the promotion of our listing. I am sure that all Australians would be proud that we have such a significant area. Many people overseas are looking forward to having it placed on the World Heritage listing.

The honourable member for Lyons suggested that we were doing things for a small minority. I would like to think that when we are putting forward the tropical rainforests of Australia we are acting on behalf of the majority of Australians. When we talk to young people in Australia we find that they have a clear perception and understanding of the environment. I have discussed these matters with the school children in my electorate. They have a clear appreciation of what is involved. But the tragedy is that because of a number of factors they will be unable to share the beauty and the importance of those areas; they may not be able to visit those areas. But that does not make it less important that we continue with the action we are taking. It is important that we act on behalf of future generations of Australians, because that is what we are really on about.

This year some thought is being given to where Australia is going. That is important. We should at least have some maturity and be able to look at matters such as environmental protection on the basis that it is something for all Australians. As a signatory to the World Heritage Convention we have an international obligation. I think that that is important. I do not think that it is something that we should sneeze at. I note in the debate in the other place some suggestion that because the 21 countries on the World Heritage Committee of UNESCO are not the most friendly nations we should ignore what they are doing. Let us get the nonsense out of the way that because something is listed under the World Heritage Convention we lose some power over that listing. We should recognise that Australia is one of the few nations that have legislation on this matter. It is important legislation.

I will conclude by quoting some very important words that were part of the late Justice Lionel Murphy's statement in the Franklin Dam case. It is important that honourable members opposite listen to these words because I think that they sum up the position that we, as Australians, should be taking. We should see this as an obligation. Justice Murphy stated:

The cooperation of Australia with other nation States to preserve the world cultural and natural heritage falls easily within the external affairs power. It is part of Australia's external affairs to participate with other nations bodies and persons in this process of declaring that world renowned monuments, scenic and architectural sites belong to the world and not merely the nation or the province where they are situated. It is also part of Australia's external affairs to cooperate with others, each nation doing what it can to preserve the sites within its area, as part of a web of internal regulation and supervision of such sites. Even if there were no treaty the preservation of world heritage is part of Australia's external affairs and federal laws directed to preservation of any part of that heritage in Australia would be within the legislative powers of the Parliament.
He went on to say:

The preservation of the World's heritage must not be looked at in isolation but as part of the cooperation between nations which is calculated to achieve intellectual and moral solidarity of mankind and so reinforce the bonds between people which promote peace and displace those of narrow nationalism and alienation which promote war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to enter this debate. It is good to see my colleagues from Tasmania present in the House-people such as the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles)-and other members of whom I ask forgiveness if I have not mentioned them. It is good to have support from the Tasmanians. I listened tonight to the speeches of two Tasmanian members and I was proud of them, as the elder statesman of the Tasmanian delegation. I thought their speeches were marvellous. If the greenies are listening tonight, they had better switch off because I am not going to give them any cheer at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard Government members tonight talking about the philosophical point of view of the Australian Labor Party, the conservation movement, et cetera. What about the poor old workers in the timber industry and the truck drivers who take the timber to the mills, the people who are heavily involved in the industry in Tasmania? They must be saying, `What is the Federal Parliament doing?'. They hear about this legislation and they must be very confused.

This Government does not care about those ordinary, average working people. The Labor Party has sold its soul. I said that Bob Hawke was like Dorian Gray-he had sold his soul to the devil, meaning the conservation movement. He thinks that will get him votes. It did not get him many votes in New South Wales. He lost votes in that State and he will lose them in Tasmania, and also at the next Federal election. The poor average working man, whom the Labor Party claims to support and assist, has been forgotten in this debate. I am referring to the blue-collar workers, the sort of people who really make Australia. The poor fellows down at the Lemonthyme and in the Southern Forests who are listening tonight must be wondering what is going on. I am not going to run down judges, but some of them have never been through the mill in the true sense of the word. Their hands are clean. I know we are not allowed to talk about judges in this House, but I will talk about anyone who I believe is going to jeopardise an industry in Tasmania and cause even more unemployment. All Tasmanians would agree with that. The ordinary people are forgotten in this debate.

Let me just go through this very slowly. First of all, we began with Lake Pedder. The Bob Browns and the Norm Sanderses of this world, and others I could name, came out of the woodwork. They opposed the damming of Lake Pedder. They said, `No, don't touch Lake Pedder. You can't do that'. Everyone in Tasmania was up in arms; people marched through the streets, including, surprisingly, a few we know. They said, `We are going to stop the damming of Lake Pedder'. That was the first shot they fired. People looked me straight in the eye-they were somewhat taller than I am but I stood up to them-and said, `Bruce, it is a cause. You must get behind it'. I said, `Look, some of the people I represent can ill afford a motor car, let alone go and see Lake Pedder. They cannot put haversacks on their backs and march around Lake Pedder or fly there and come down in a parachute. We need development in that area. I would like the people of Tasmania to see Lake Pedder. They have never seen it. The only way they can go there is by a road'. So the Hydro Electric Commission developed Lake Pedder and the conservationists lost that particular case.

That was the beginning. I thought, `Where do these Browns and Sanderses come from? Where are all these other greenies coming from?'. They had never done anything for Tasmania before but they came out of the woodwork and decided to get involved in Lake Pedder. After we won the case, I said, `We will have trouble from here on'. I was right. We came into Federal Parliament and what did we find? The fight for the construction of the Franklin Dam. Suddenly that was taken completely out of context. Everyone was saying, `Save the Franklin. Don't let the dam be constructed'. Before we knew where we were, the greenies were there. Bellamy came from England-that silly looking coot. I could call him a few names. He came to Tasmania to celebrate his birthday in gaol. He should not have been given a passport. He was the first one. Then we had Yehudi Menuhin-he should have stuck to his fiddle. He said, `You have got to stop the dam'. We even had Prince Charles saying a few things about stopping the dam. All these conservationists jumped on the band wagon and the ordinary people were forgotten. Then thousands of conservationists went to Warners Landing. Most of them were unemployed. They put good people out of work in Tasmania. We fought and fought, but we allowed the Franklin River to be taken over by those so-called educated people who seem to know everything but have never got their hands dirty with a bit of hard work.

Let us go back in history. Brown, Sanders and the others, and a few members of this chamber, said, `We will have development down at the south-west. We will have hotels'. What has happened? Nothing. People are talking about building a hotel at Warners Landing but the conservationists will not even give permission for that. I will tell honourable members what the conservationists want. They already have 30 per cent of Tasmania locked up but they want it completely locked up to be their own little playground. They want to put their haversacks on their backs and walk down there and say, `Gosh, we have travelled around Tasmania'. It does not matter about the poor workers, the ordinary average people. The greenies are continually attacking Tasmania, wanting it for their own purposes and forgetting about ordinary Tasmanians who have given their lifeblood to that State, made it such a good place to live in, educated their children, and worked hard. They are being taken to the cleaners.

We lost the issue of damming the Franklin River and we said, `It's over. They have won. Let them have it. Don't get too agitated about it. That is the end of it'. But it was not the end. The greenies started again at Farmhouse Creek in my electorate. I looked at the 25 people arrested at Farmhouse Creek; 20 of them were unemployed and came from another State. They got all the publicity under the sun. They wonder why Bruce Goodluck goes crook at the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the media. The greenies were given all that publicity, but the good people were forgotten. The poor people at Geeveston were battling to pay their hire purchase agreements and to feed and care for their children, but these silly coots were sitting up in trees putting on a great show for the Australian people and saying that this and that should be saved. That was the beginning of what we are now involved in. We all knew it but we could not stop it. The greenies thought, `We have stopped them on the dam; we did not stop them on Lake Pedder but we will stop them in the forests'. That is where they started, down at Farmhouse Creek.

Regrettably, my friend the Tasmanian Minister responsible for forests and the environment-a very nice fellow for whom I have the highest regard-has been quoted in the media as saying, `Bruce, we don't want any bitterness in this debate. Let them go on and don't be bitter as on the dams issue'. I regret that it is a bitter debate because the people of Tasmania are being taken to the cleaners by these conservationists, who are hell-bent on a single issue. If we give way to them-and we are tonight, because we do not have the numbers in this House-they will win. This legislation will give Senator Richardson more power. He is a self-confessed turnabout greenie. He is saying that he realised at the last Federal election that there were votes to be gained from the conservation movement. If he gets those greenies on side, the Government can win elections. I say to the Minister that that will not be the case because the ordinary average people in Australia are starting to wake up. This Bill will give the Minister more power. It will override State governments. As things are going at the moment, we may as well not have a State government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what they want.

—That is what those opposite want. They want the power centralised in Canberra so that they can dictate the terms. The Tasmanian Forestry Commission is doing a magnificent job trying to preserve our forests in a constructive way. The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) laughs. He laughs because he loves the birds and the bees. He thinks that the birds and the bees and the bushes supply Tasmanians with work, but they do not. We know that they do not.

SPEECH.PARA: The environmentalists may want Tasmania as their own playground, but the people I represent do not want it as a playground. They want to conserve our forests but still be able to work them sensibly-to cut down trees to make wood for the new Parliament House, for instance. Even the dining room in the new Parliament House is lined with Tasmanian blackwood. But the Government is going to stop that. All the things that are said about there being no more timber here and no more timber there in Tasmania are a lot of rot. The Forestry Commission in Tasmania is well organised. It is trying to do the best possible job by looking after conservation but not forgetting development. That is what it is all about-a balance.

I do not want to hear any more from those in that little group in my own Party. They do not have my support. They should not believe that Bruce John Goodluck will support them just because they are in his Party. One cannot walk on the barbed wire fence in this game. One is on either one side or the other. I am on the side of looking after the ordinary, average working people in Tasmania who depend on us Tasmanians to bring forward their point of view. Some of them are not very well educated. Some of them have been taken to the cleaners by the educated, the university people, in Tasmania who continually say, `You have to save this and save that'. What about their wages? What about their groups.

This legislation will go through. The Australian Labor Party is on a path of disaster because it has forsaken its support base, that is, the ordinary, average working person and his family. The Bob Browns and Norm Sanderses of the world and other conservationists are listening tonight. They are single issue people. They believe in only one thing-what they want. They get bitter if we have an opposing point of view. My colleagues and I on this side of the House look after every aspect of the person. We try to look after all his problems. All the crowd opposite are interested in is what they want, and what they want is to save the forests at any cost. They say, `Don't cut down one tree in Tasmania. We want it for ourselves'. Where is the development that was promised after the dams issue? There was no development at all. They have refuted their promise and left Tasmania in disarray because of what they are trying to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is extremely difficult, even impossible, to follow the contribution of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) to the debate on the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill. His contribution, with respect, did nothing to advance the cause of the Opposition. Regrettably, prejudice piled upon prejudice does nothing to advance the totality of human knowledge and rational debate in this Parliament. But I say to the honourable member for Franklin that he is always good for a laugh and brings some entertainment to what otherwise might become an overly serious debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I should address a couple of matters that the honourable member for Franklin at least implicitly raised in his contribution. What he was really advancing was the view that environmental protection was somehow inconsistent with full employment. That is an extremely short-sighted and Tasmanian view of the world, one which is clearly at odds with the rest of Australia and certainly at odds with this Government's view of environmental protection.

I stand here as someone committed to the principle of full employment. I am proud to call myself an environmentalist for full employment. Let us consider Tasmania as an example of what rape and pillaging of the environment over the entire course of a government does for the economic development of a State. Tasmania's economy is in decline. It has a government that is, according to the public opinion polls, increasingly unpopular and unable to deliver the jobs, a government that, had the Federal Government not intervened, would have been responsible for the destruction of a unique World Heritage area. It is not surprising that the honourable member for Franklin now leaves the chamber. I have not yet finished dealing with some of the remarks he made. He might not care to hear some of the other things I have to say.

I was interested to hear that the honourable member's contribution to this debate involved an attack on his own Party. He referred to differences of opinion. Of course there are differences of opinion in the Liberal Party on environmental protection. I acknowledge that there are some decent people in the Liberal Party, people we think of as small `1' Liberals, or wets, as they are on occasions called, people who have a genuine commitment to preserving these unique, natural areas, irrespective of what the rednecks in the National Party might think about the issue.

One has to remember that what we are talking about when we talk about World Heritage areas are not small, local environmental issues but sites of, not just national, but international significance. We are talking about South West Tasmania. We are talking about Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park, known to many people as Ayers Rock. We are talking about the Great Barrier Reef and Kakadu National Park, places that are truly of international significance. That is not the responsibility of a State government that is prepared to turn its back on these issues. This Government, at the national level, should ensure protection of these areas in the event of State governments refusing to look after them.

This Bill amends the Commonwealth conservation legislation to clarify and strengthen the protection afforded under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, commonly called the World Heritage Act. It is important to remember that Opposition members are not speaking in support of amendments to this Bill. They are not proposing any small changes or substantial changes. They are opposing the very nature of the legislation. They are on record as taking the view that the Federal Government should have no role in ensuring protection for a World Heritage area in the event that a State government fails to live up to its responsibilities.

The Government's powers and responsibilities in this area are based on the World Heritage Convention, which was a reflection of the desire of humankind throughout the world to protect the natural environment. The Convention is formally called the International Convention Concerning the Protection of World Cultural and Natural Heritage. It was adopted by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation General Conference at its seventeenth session in Paris in 1972 and came into force in 1975. It promotes cooperation among nations to protect areas and buildings which are of such universal value that their conservation is of concern to humanity generally.

I repeat: these are sites of global significance. We ought to take pride when Australia's natural features are listed as World Heritage areas. It is a matter of enormous pride to this Government when we are able to secure new listings on the World Heritage List because our listings join the pyramids of Egypt, the Grand Canyon of the United States and the Taj Mahal of India. Such is the calibre and importance of our natural resources.

I have said many times before-and I am sure that my close colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), the fighter from Tasmania, agrees with my sentiments-that this Government is committed to cooperation, to trying to achieve social reform and social progress by working with State governments, local authorities and people from all walks of life in a cooperative way to ensure that we can achieve reform by consensus. That is the best way to achieve social progress. It is not our view that we should seek or promote division for some short term political end, to grab a headline. It is not our view that we should promote divisions between private and public school sectors, between major employer and union bodies. It is not our view that we should have barricades between conservationists and foresters.

Those are the results of the policies of confrontation which the ideologues on the other side continually promote. That does not mean that there are not serious questions that have to be resolved. On occasions a Federal government has to take a stand to protect the national interest. But the approach that we adopt is initially one of compromise to seek to mediate where there are conflicting views. Of course, in relation to the tropical forests of northern Queensland that is the approach that we have adopted, not just for a matter of weeks or months but for years. For years we have tried to get some advance in Queensland. Of course, initially it was the former Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who provided the obstacle and the hardline opposition but now we find with a change of government the same trenchant opposition, the same provocation, the same encouragement of division and refusal to protect these World Heritage areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Head in the sand stuff.

—As the honourable member for Denison said, this is a head in the sand approach. It is even more than that because it is a deliberate attempt to cause division, a deliberate attempt to engage in political confrontation for some short-term gain. It is in that context that when our Government is confronted with the obstinate, redneck National Party Government in Queensland we are determined to ensure that the north Queensland tropical rainforests are preserved for all time for Australians and indeed for the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I want people to think back to the approach of the Opposition during the period of the Fraser Government. Tonight we have heard people from the Liberal Party and the National Party saying that environmental protection is a matter for the States and that land use matters are not a Federal responsibility. But I ask the Opposition to tell us which government used its export powers to stop sandmining on Fraser Island. Was it a policy that was implemented by the Whitlam Government? Was it a policy of the Hawke Labor Government? No, it was a policy implemented by Malcolm Fraser. Even Malcolm Fraser knew that Australians were not prepared to accept this blinkered view, this warped and distorted view of the Australian Constitution which suggests that the interpretation of the Australian Constitution should be fixed for all time as it was originally interpreted in 1900. The High Court of Australia has ruled that it is a perfectly valid exercise of Commonwealth power to intervene using those powers to protect the natural environment. Malcolm Fraser did it; now the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and everybody on the Opposition benches repudiate what the Fraser Government did in that area.

I want to turn my attention particularly, directly and specifically to the policies of the Opposition on the environment right now as they stand in 1988. In the document that Senator Puplick, the Opposition spokesman on the environment, has put out he makes a very frank acknowledgment: that the current policies of the Liberal Party-can you believe this, Mr Deputy Speaker?-are the same policies as the coalition had in 1977. And where did the policies come from in 1977? They came from the then spokesman for the environment, the north Queensland National Party senator, Stan Collard. They were the policies and they remain the policies. I have absolutely no doubt that those who determine policy in the Liberal and National parties in this area will not be the, with respect, token inclusion in the shadow Cabinet, the wet Senator Puplick. They will be the likes of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and Senator John Stone, the ideologues. Mr Deputy Speaker, I bet you and my other colleagues that they will not budge an inch. They will not give even a little bit to Senator Puplick to try to establish some credibility with the environmental movement. As I said, the policies were and remain those promoted by Senator Stan Collard in 1977. I do not say that; Senator Puplick says that. They are the policies of the Opposition now. Senator Stone will have his way and the Opposition will be stuck with those policies.

My time is running out and I must conclude but I want to make a couple of brief remarks in conclusion. I believe very strongly-I make these views known on most occasions when I speak in this Parliament-that as much as possible there should be a bipartisan approach to important items on the national political agenda. I do not seek to promote confrontation. For the sake of my children, in the future if there is a change of government I do not want to see the Kakadu National Park and the Great Barrier Reef at risk because of hardline, extremist and unacceptable policies. So I give the Liberal Party a message: its environmental policy, its States rights, hands off policy on environmental issues, is unacceptable to workers, to middle class Australians and to people from all walks of life. Environmental protection is not a middle class issue; it is an issue for workers and an issue for all Australians. The majority will not accept the Opposition's extremist and unacceptable fringe policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise to speak on the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill, which relates to the environment, because I personally have a concern about the environment. Unlike the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), the previous speaker, I live in an area which has a natural environment which still exists in a very real way. I am sure that people in Tasmania realise the great need to maintain the natural environment. I repudiate some of the things the previous speaker mentioned about the coalition's policies. The Opposition is concerned about the environment but at the same time it is concerned about families and jobs and opportunities for families. It is also concerned that businesses have the opportunities to get on and develop jobs for Australians. At the moment the really big question which we are faced with as a nation is: what is the balance to be struck? Many people listening tonight would be asking that question. Where do we strike a balance between opening up new opportunities for jobs which will go on for hundreds of years and locking up areas forever so that future generations do not have the flexibility of making that choice for themselves? The Opposition is very much about allowing flexibility in the future for those people who come after us to have the opportunity to make decisions as to whether various businesses start up or whether new mines open up in certain areas. Tasmania is at the front of this area of operations and so much of our land, so much of our forests is being locked up that future generations will not be able to exploit, use, get the benefits of it-it does not matter what words are used-to provide jobs for future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: As one of the previous speakers from Tasmania, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), told the House, 30 per cent of Tasmania is locked up. I want to try to impress upon people that this is the equivalent, in mainland terms of all Queensland being blotted out with no mines and no forest activities of any kind, all of New South Wales being blotted off the mainland, with no mines and no forest activities, and the same for Victoria-one-third of the mainland not being allowed to be used. That is what has happened in Tasmania. That the Government did not allow that part of Tasmania to be made available for logging operations seriously restricts the opportunities for young people who will have to build businesses in the future and help develop mines. I put it to the House that it should consider the ramifications of this type of legislation.

The coalition is concerned about the environment. It is concerned that we should live in a healthy, natural environment. Might I point out to the House that we talk about the environment as though there were only the natural environment. What is the Australian Labor Party doing about the urban environment? It is doing very little. It is good to see a new government in New South Wales that has policies not just for the natural environment but also for the urban environment. It was elected because in its policies there was a balance between the natural and the urban environment. It is interested in combating crime and corruption-part of our environment.

Let me return to the natural environment. This legislation indicates that the Government wants to go over the top in environmental areas. The legislation is obviously for political expediency; there is no doubt about that. On the matter of inspectors, I was absolutely bemused by a Press statement released by Senator Aulich in Tasmania last week. The headline read: `New conservation legislation-inspectors will not enter people's homes'. Is that not a great headline for this sort of legislation? The Press statement did not say anything about people's farms. It did not say anything about people's businesses. The idea was, `Don't be afraid, at least you can be guaranteed that these inspectors will not enter your homes'. How far from the truth that sort of headline is. The honourable senator was grabbing headlines for political expediency. If he spent more time in Tasmania and less in other places he would not have to try to get those headlines.

I refer now to the external affairs power. I was interested that the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) said that the legislation came under the external affairs powers in section 52 of the Constitution. Let me read that again. Section 52 states:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have exclusive power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth. . .
I wonder what our forests have to do with peace, order and good government. Obviously, nothing. It was well put by Barry Prismall in the Hobart Mercury:
The reforms are the most far reaching in Australia's environmental history.
Decisions about an area's World Heritage values-which was the basis for the Tasmanian High Court challenge over logging-will be put squarely in the province of the World Heritage Committee. . . .

Where did this Committee meet? It did not meet in Hobart, or in Canberra, or even within Australia. It met in Paris. Are we as a nation prepared to allow decisions to be made about our backyard by countries overseas? People say that the High Court of Australia has made decisions on this matter, and I agree that that is certainly true, but I suggest, as the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) did earlier, that if the decisions that have been made by the High Court of Australia over the last five years which moved power from the States to the Commonwealth were put to the Australian people, they would not be passed. Average Australians know that the more power that is given to the central government the less control they have over their lives. There is no doubt that the Australian people would reject those decisions which have been made, quite correctly, by the High Court. I put it to the House that there is a great concern in Australia that the external affairs powers should be limited.

Another point I should like to make relates to land use. Under the Constitution, land use is a matter for the States and it is one which we should jealously protect for the States. If it is provided under the Constitution that the States have power over land then it should be the State governments which decide on nominating any areas for World Heritage listing.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would not nominate any in Tasmania.

—I am interested in what the honourable member for Dunkley suggests. Of course, the assumption is that people who enter the Commonwealth Parliament somehow have a higher set of moral values than anybody who enters a State parliament. That is absolute nonsense.
—I am talking about different parties.

—Of course I will respond to that comment because I would like to go on. The honourable member likes it because he will have his name in the record. Tasmania has the best record on forest practices of any Australian State. I want to illustrate the detail to which the Tasmanian Government has gone in putting together a forest practices code to ensure that the environment is handled sensitively and carefully, that various fauna and flora in the forests are protected. I do not want to dwell on that aspect; I want to talk about other areas such as soil erosion. The Forest Practices Code, which is covered by an Act of Parliament in Tasmania, requires the operators in our forests to be very careful. This is the detail which this Government, in bringing in the legislation, totally ignored. Code B.6. relates to the construction of bridges, causeways and fords. I hope the people of Australia are listening to this information because the Liberal Party, particularly in Tasmania, has made enormous strides in regard to the environment and is a long way ahead of the Labor Government. The Labor Party had 35 years, yet it did not do one tap in regard to the environment in Tasmania. The State Liberal Party has moved further down the track than any Labor State government on the mainland. Those governments do not have a code of practice. The code sets out the sort of things that loggers have to do when constructing bridges, causeways or fords. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Permanent bridges on major watercourses should be designed to withstand the fifty (50) year flood level.
This is the case even though some of the watercourses are quite small streams. The code further states:

Where causeways or fords are planned for stream crossings they will be constructed on stable substrate with solid rocky surfaces immediately downstream and an adequate length of properly rendered or gravelled dry approach will be provided on both sides.
Tractors and other equipment will operate in a manner that will cause the least disturbance to the stream bed and stream banks. Do not push fill into running streams.
These are the guidelines which the people who go into the forests have to abide by. The code continues:
Plan activities in streams to coincide with low water flows, unless advice indicates problems for fresh water fish in sensitive localities.
So where streams are very low the loggers are given instructions on how to handle that situation. The code continues:
Stream bed and bank areas will be restored as nearly as practicable to their original condition upon completion of the operation.
It is not just how they go about it, but what happens when the operations actually finish. The code goes on:
Wooden bridges and components will need to be secured properly where they will be subjected to high water flows or maybe submerged.
Lastly, it states:
Protect bridge embankments to minimise erosion by use of suitable concrete, timber logs, vegetation or rip rap.

I continue on to another section which deals with snig tracks. Some people might ask what snig tracks are. Snig tracks, of course, are the small tracks used in the operations to get logs out of the forest. This is what the code says about them:
Snig tracks will not cross a Class 1 watercourse.
In other words, there can be no logging anywhere near particular watercourses. Further, it states:
The number of crossings of other watercourses will be restricted to clearly marked crossing points. Temporary culverts or log crossings will be provided in any such crossing.
Tractor damage to stream banks will be minimised.
No watercourse bed will be used for snigging.
Where practicable snigging should be carried out in an uphill direction on soils in the high erosion class.
Cording of snig tracks--

I guess most of those who have spoken on the environment and have talked about our forests would not even know what cording is, because they are out of touch with what our timber operations are all about. It is incredible that so many people from the Government side really do not have much idea about going about operations in a forest in a sensitive way. Cording, of course, is putting bark and that sort of thing over the ground to prevent erosion. The paragraph states:
Cording of snig tracks in wet areas and use of temporary culverts should be considered to reduce severe soil compaction.
Cording is used particularly around areas where the logs are pulled in and loaded onto trucks. Lastly, the code states:
Outsloping of snig tracks should be considered to reduce scouring. The outslope should be about 2 per cent and not more than 6 per cent as logs slide off slopes greater than 6 per cent.
I could go on, but time does not permit. There is a lot more detail in this Forest Practices Code, which is the best forest practices code in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the world.

—As the honourable member from the Blue Mountains would certainly know, coming from such a beautiful area of Australia, this is the best code for operations in our forests. It was brought in by a Liberal government. It is wrong of Government members to say that the coalition is not sensitive to the environment.
—Did you know the honourable member for Denison is not speaking?

—I am interested to hear that, as the honourable member for Bass says-and he gave a very good speech earlier in the day-the only member from Tasmania not listed to speak is the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr). It is interesting that a person like that, who is a greenie, is not speaking on this legislation. Of course we are the members who really are concerned for the ordinary, average person in Tasmania who wants to have a job and support his family. We are interested in the future of the young people in our colleges; we want them to be able to go out and get jobs and get apprenticeships. We are concerned about them, and that is why we are speaking on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issue I am interested in is the issue of private property, referred to by Government members including, I think, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons). He said: `Of course, only 20 private properties in Queensland and only eight in Tasmania will be affected by this legislation'. That is an absolute, outright--

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrage.

—It is an outrage that any private property should be listed by somebody else in this manner when the owners do not get any say in whether it is listed. That is something which, as a parliament, we should object to very strenuously. People buy their private property, and some people in some areas of Tasmania have owned it for 100 years, and yet somebody else is able to go along and say, `This has got World Heritage status' and they have no say over it whatsoever. It is an outrage, as the honourable member for Lyons has said. The Opposition is totally opposed to this draconian legislation, which has really come at the zenith of the environmental debate. It has really gone over the top.
—Richardson's greenshirts.

—Yes; the honourable member for Bass refers to Richardson's greenshirts-inspectors who can go into the farms and business operations of people interested in forest operations. This Bill should never see the light of day as an Act of Parliament. The Opposition is totally opposed to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) will have an opportunity to speak this evening on the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill. The reason he could not get on the list is that so many people on this side want to speak on the Bill. There are so many that I could hardly get a guernsey, and I have been on the environment committee since I have been a member of this Parliament. So it is very hard to get on to speak. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) mentioned the urban environment. Let me tell him that we have done a lot in connection with the urban environment. If he was aware of what was happening next week he would know that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) is coming down to the beautiful electorate of Dunkley to have a look at the urban environment, and we will be taking steps to protect that environment down there. These people who knock us environmentalists think we are at the zenith of our power, at the zenith of our influence, but we have not started.

SPEECH.PARA: The environment movement in Australia began in the late 1960s and early 1970s with the destruction by the Tasmanian Government of Lake Pedder. That was sort of covered over. One has only to look at the beautiful photographs of Lake Pedder to see what we have lost. We have lost forever a magnificent lake. Some day maybe someone with a bit of nous will knock down that dam and Lake Pedder will be rejuvenated. I suggest that is not a bad idea.

It has been stated quite often that Tasmania still has these huge stands of trees because the forests there have been managed in a sympathetic manner. The only reason those trees have been left is that these areas are so isolated from the mainland. The market did not exist to sell off all these trees. Now the markets do exist and there is the opportunity to sell this timber, and that is what the companies are trying to do. However, we will not let them.

It has also been said that there was 35 years of Labor government in Tasmania and nothing was done. Environment was not an issue when the Australian Labor Party was in power in Tasmania. Surely honourable members opposite know that. The environment has come from nowhere, 15 years ago, to being an issue which now has a high profile-and it will continue to get a higher profile in the future.

I have always claimed that we should save as much as possible of what is left of our natural environment throughout Australia. It is my policy to try to do this-to grab it now while we have the opportunity. We can fight over whether it has minerals or whether some development should go ahead in the future. However, if we get it now while Australia is in the unique position in the world of being a fairly wealthy nation which does not need some of the resources in world heritage or national park areas, and put this land aside, maybe at some time in the future we will be able to mine it. I have always said that national parks could possibly be mined in another 20 years with some sort of robot or equipment that digs underneath the ground and does not disturb the environment on the top. Maybe we could manage it a lot better than we do at the moment. These areas should be set aside for our children, such as the young girls from Queensland in the gallery at the moment. We are looking after their future. We are leaving them something-something that, only through luck, has been left to us. It is important that we actually keep as much as we can for the future residents of Australia.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Beazley-I require that the question be put forthwith without debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr CHYNOWETH

TALK.START.PARA: —There was some discussion by the honourable member for Braddon about the best forest practices in the world that he claims the Tasmanian Government has put into operation. But Tasmania put those forest practices in place only because it was forced to do so by the environmentalists. To say that everyone adheres to that code is incorrect. I was in Tasmania last year and the year before, and I can assure honourable members that everyone does not follow that code.
