I think 10 metres either side of creeks and rivers was supposed to be left, but the trees were knocked over and into the water. The snig tracks were well compacted and no steps had been taken to rejuvenate them after logging had finished.

INTERJECT.PARA: There was also some logging going on. Cranes were placed on top of mountains and the logs were drawn up to the top. A couple of years ago the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation was holding an inquiry into the crown of thorns starfish on the Great Barrier Reef. From the air, this area in Tasmania where all the logs had been pulled up to the crown of the mountain looked as though it had been attacked by crown of thorns starfish eating their way slowly along the mountain top and destroying it all. That is something symbolic that has stuck in my mind and I will never forget it. As I have said before, we must try to save as much of Australia as we can.

I could speak for my full 20 minutes, telling the people of Australia about the great things that the Australian Labor Party has done in relation to the environment. We have made certain that woodchipping is carried out on a controlled basis. There is a lot of pressure on the New South Wales and Victorian governments at the moment to increase woodchipping, but I trust that does not happen. Why should we chop down beautiful gum trees and other trees and turn them into cardboard that gets wrapped around some plastic toy from Japan or Korea? We should look at the work practices that are followed in these forests. A lot of logs are not suitable for pulp as they are sawlogs, and to say otherwise is incorrect. Last year a small exhibition was staged in front of Parliament House by the woodchippers from Eden. They brought up all these dirty old logs with cracks and holes in them and made it look as though they were the logs that they would send to the pulp mill. That is not the case. I have seen rumbling along back roads in Tasmania plenty of excellent logs which should have been classified as sawlogs, but which were being turned into pulp and paper.

The Australian Labor Party has also done a lot in the area of rainforests. We have taken steps to preserve them for future generations. Why have we had to do this? We have had to bring in this legislation to make certain that conservative Liberal-National Party governments do not destroy the environment. We should not need this sort of legislation, but it is necessary to protect the natural heritage for future generations.

I believe that this Bill should have been in force some time ago. If it had been, we may not have had the problems we have had with certain governments. I commend Senator Richardson for his far-sightedness and I commend those in his Department who have worked hard to make certain that this legislation was in a proper form. I hope the Bill passes through this House and the Senate and is enacted in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill is nothing more nor less than typical socialist legislation designed to hoodwink the people of Australia. The Government is going to jackboot this legislation through the House so that it can build some sort of monument to Senator Richardson. He has just messed up things in New South Wales, and what he is doing here is no better. It is just another step to transfer power from State governments to the Federal Government via such mechanisms as international treaties and to centralise the power. That is what those on the other side seem to want.

SPEECH.PARA: Under this legislation the Government will set up a system of inspectors, it will abolish the environmental impact statement considerations and it will take away any say or right of appeal that State governments have-and we are talking about Queensland in this case. It is worth dwelling for a minute on the history of this matter. The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), that discredited offshoot of the United Nations, set up the Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage in Paris on 19 November 1972. That came into force on 7 December 1975, but Australia ratified it before that, in August 1974, and was the seventh country to do so. About 100 other countries have done so since. We now have a World Heritage Committee which lists monuments and sites, and also natural sites. The group that is responsible for giving advice to the World Heritage Committee on natural sites is the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN).

About 288 places around the world have been listed. We all know the famous ones. They include the pyramids of Egypt, the Taj Mahal in India, Yellowstone National Park and so on. Australia has already listed the Great Barrier Reef, the Kakadu National Park, the Willandra Lakes in New South Wales, Lord Howe Island, the New South Wales rainforests, the Uluru National Park, which contains Ayers Rock, and some of the Western Tasmanian Wilderness National Parks. This sounds all very well but in practice it is not working out too well in this country. We only have to go to Lord Howe Island to see the little ways in which that beautiful island is being messed up. To do some work on the side of the road which had recently been washed away, the authorities had to bring stones from the mainland. This is the sort of nonsense that goes on.
I have a copy of a telex here from Ambassador Mott of UNESCO, who telexed Senator Richardson in December 1987 and said:
IUCN in fact has never visited Kakadu officially, not even in 1981 when Stage I was listed, and certainly not for Stage II . . .

So IUCN has not even followed its own guidelines before some of these places have been listed. It makes me wonder whether the Kakadu listing should be declared invalid, because the guidelines have not been adhered to. Mr James Thorsell of Canada will lead an IUCN team to Australia later this year to evaluate the north Queensland rainforests. He is a respected figure, but Ambassador Mott, in telexing Senator Richardson, said:
For Queensland it is desirable that Thorsell visit and he be well looked after.
He went on to say:
It would also help if Canberra Ambassadors of WHC member states could be taken to the forests and shown around.

In other words, he was saying, `Junket this whole group around, look after its members well, pour a few whiskies and ports into them and then we might get listing. We will try to follow the guidelines on this case'. This is the sort of thing that has been going on. But the area of Queensland rainforests proposed for listing extends roughly from Townsville in the south to Cooktown in the north, a stretch of country extending over about 500 kilometres and in places up to 100 kilometres wide. It encompasses about 857,000 hectares, or in excess of two million acres. A decision on this matter is expected by November 1988. We should not forget that the Queensland State Government has managed this area very well over the past 100 years. Some 76 per cent of the area has been set aside and has never been logged, and only about 18.7 per cent is logged now.

The Government believes that logging is incompatible with listing because logging will destroy the area for World Heritage listing. As I have said, some areas have been logged two, three and four times over the past 100 years. One can enter such areas and have difficulty determining whether they have been logged or they are virgin forest. Yet logging is supposed to be so harmful. Why does the Government want to stop the logging; why does it want to list the area? To do so will have the effect of destroying an industry which earned $33m last year. There are 13 mills operating in the area which will no doubt close down. The Government is not even concerned about them; it is so out of touch with people in this country. There will be $50m worth of investment wasted in this industry. By my calculations 765 people are employed directly in the industry who will be put out of work. A further 378, who are indirectly involved, will be out of work also. The Government is so out of touch. That was demonstrated recently in the results of the New South Wales State election, and it will happen again in Queensland. Not only will people be out of work but towns will go under.

TALK.START.PARA: —And families.

—And families. Beautiful little hamlets such as Ravenshoe will be lost. What will that do for tourism? Tourism will actually drop. We have 106,000 people involved in forestry and in wood manufacturing industries in the country and this Government is doing the best it can to take away their jobs. The industry is a $8,000m industry when it is followed right through, and this Government is trying to destroy it.
—What about the human tragedy?

—The Government has not considered the human tragedy; it has not even considered the alternatives. Let us examine the alternatives if the hardwood industry in this country is shut down. The Government says that softwoods can be used. Softwood may be suitable to manufacture some things, but it is not suitable for everything. The Government apparently wants to build every table, desk and chair out of plastic. Some things can be built from plastic, but I, for one, do not want to see everything made out of plastic, aluminium or steel. The alternative is that we import hardwood from countries such as Malaysia or Brazil. It seems that it is immoral to chop down a tree in Australia but is all right to chop a tree down overseas. If the Government were genuinely interested in conserving rainforests, it surely would cut down those trees that have to be cut down in areas that are managed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government wants to shift the problem overseas to a Third World country, where the problem will be out of sight. This is the type of hypocrisy the Government indulges in. A further alternative proposed by the Government is that hardwoods be grown in plantations. Where will the Government get the land from? Where will the money come from to buy the properties to grow the hardwood? Even if it were possible to grow the hardwood in 40 years, by my calculations it would realise only a 5 per cent gross return-a very poor investment indeed. It should not be forgotten that many trees that are cut down, such as cedars, do grow to an acceptable height in 40 years but the wood has not matured and does not have an acceptable colour. Such wood would be suitable only for pulp return. In any event, after a period of 40 years there will be no sawmills because they will be closed. The industry would have to be started again. In plantations, I am sure all honourable members are aware, only one species is grown, which I find very unattractive. So I do not think the alternatives are at all suitable.

Senator Cook in his Senate speech said that in the Government's view such forestry operations-he was referring to logging-would clearly damage or destroy the integrity of the nominated World Heritage area as a whole or the partly valuable features of the area. As I said earlier, we have been logging for 100 years and the Government considers that the land is still suitable for listing. The Government is correct when it says it is beautiful land, which means that logging has not done so much damage to it after all.

The Government is desperately out of touch not only on this issue but in chasing the greenie vote in the way it has. That was proved at the recent New South Wales State election. The Australian Labor Party lost many of its country seats, Monaro being one of them, and it was hurled out of office. The Australian Conservation Foundation has 1,100-odd members and a survey conducted some time ago revealed that 548 of that membership answered positively that the ACF should support a political party. The findings of that survey opens one's eyes. They reveal that 361 members said that they would support the Australian Democrats or the Nuclear Disarmament Party. Only 46 members said that they would support the Australian Labor Party; only three said that they would support the Liberal Party; and not one said that he would support the National Party of Australia.

The ACF membership is totally unrepresentative. There is no balance in its membership whatsoever. It has no representative from the Labor Party, for heaven's sake. In excess of 76 per cent of its membership are either academics or professionals. Less than 2 per cent are blue-collar members, from which the Australian Labor Party base is supposed to come; less than 3 per cent are tradesmen; less than 5 per cent come from managerial areas; and 63 per cent of the membership have no children in their families. That is a revealing statistic. The majority of the leadership of the ACF are university academics. The leadership and the membership are overwhelmingly urban. It is a completely out of touch lobby group. It received $1.3m in government grants in 1986. It has fooled the Labor Party completely.

This legislation also is out of touch. Let us look at it in some detail. It gives the Commonwealth greater power over specific parts of World Heritage listed areas. In the past the power was more general. This legislation represents a grab for more power. Further, an environmental impact statement is not now required in World Heritage listed areas. This aspect was referred to by other members in this debate. If one seeks to do anything to anywhere else in the country, one has to have an environmental impact statement; but not in this case. If the former Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), who now sits on the back benches, wished to erect a monorail in Uluru National Park, he would not have had to have an environmental impact statement. He could have gone ahead without one. It makes one realise the sheer hypocrisy of this legislation. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is out there playing golf with Kerry Packer and smoking cigars with Peter Abeles while legislation of this sort is going through the House. I have never seen a Government so out of touch.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jobs are being lost.

—Jobs are being lost everywhere. Let us look at the proposed system of inspectors-who have been called `Graham's green-shirts' or `Richardson's raiders', or whatever. It is completely anti-Australian that inspectors with plastic ID cards should be running around gathering information, if they feel there is a serious and urgent need to do so, and reporting back to the Minister. They are supplied with warrants for this purpose, which are granted by any judge of a court created by the Parliament. Does that include a judge of the Family Court of Australia, for example? None of these matters has been spelt out. In addition, the Commonwealth will be able to shut down activities in an area before listing is even granted simply because an area is being considered for World Heritage listing. If a nomination is pending, all activities will be ordered to cease by the Minister. As well, the avenues of appeal to the High Court of Australia will be, in effect, curtailed, which means that the current Queensland Government appeal will fall into this category.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been no consultation as such at all. What has happened to the famous consensus? The Prime Minister has lost interest in it. His chief minder, who is pushing this legislation through, has lost interest in it. The cigar smoking golfer seems to have forgotten the common people of Australia who are creating this country's wealth. The Prime Minister's minder, his henchman, the Minister responsible for this legislation, is riding roughshod over Queenslanders to push the legislation through. At the next election the Government will lose the electorate of Leichhardt, and the National Party majority in the electorate of Kennedy will increase. Australia cannot afford this nonsense. Our import-export ratio of timber is running at five to one against us and this Government will exacerbate that problem with this legislation.

Does the Government know what has been going on with logging? On average, only eight trees per hectare are cut down every forty years. There is no clear-felling. Only the mature trees are cut down, many of which are defective and would fall down anyway. The best trees are left for seed production. The Forestry Commission identifies these trees and indicates in which direction they should fall. Only 0.5 per cent of the forest is logged each year. The average person who visits the forest would be hard pressed to say where logging had taken place.

When a tree is felled it opens up the canopy and lets in a bit of sunlight. Such an area is the most exciting part of the forest because of the fauna and flora that are concentrated there. The canopy filters about 98 per cent of the sunlight. When a tree is taken out, the filtering is reduced to about 84 per cent, but after 10 years the normal canopy returns. One has only to look at the damage caused by Cyclone Winifred to the canopy 15 or 18 months ago. It stripped virtually every leaf from every tree. A person who returned there now would not be able to tell that there had been a cyclone in the area. The rainforest is very vigorous and robust. There are about 1,000 trees per hectare with a breast-height diameter of greater than 10 centimetres. The rainforest has a tremendous capacity to regenerate. No logging occurs near streams or in special areas.

The timber workers have done a magnificent job. They love these areas and they have looked after them for the last hundred years-before these latter-day conservationists heard of the areas and started to take an interest in them. I congratulate the Forestry Commission and the workers for the magnificent job they have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —The salt of the earth.

—They are the salt of the earth, as the honourable member for Riverina-Darling says. Originally, it was proposed that about 1,200 to 3,000 private properties would be listed. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) did not even know that that was the case. He said that only 120 to 200 were to be listed. I was interested to see the number of private properties that had been excluded in the Cape Tribulation and Cape Kimberley areas. Some cleared properties had been included while virtually virgin areas had been left out. It seemed that there was quite a correlation between the greenies' mates' properties, which had been left out, and normal decent people's properties, which had been left in. That was quite a scandal. When we examined the original maps of the Cape Tribulation-Cape Kimberley area that became very obvious.

SPEECH.PARA: It is totally illogical to stop logging. Apparently, quarry mining can continue, building can continue, the power generation that now goes on can continue, but logging can be stopped. The Minister makes much of tourism by saying that World Heritage listing will increase tourism. But when the Great Barrier Reef was listed, domestic tourism actually fell off in the years following the listing. It was only the heavy advertising in this area which turned around the figures. There was no change in the number of international tourists who flocked to the area after the listing. At the same time, while tourism to the Great Barrier Reef was falling, tourism to the Queensland State forests actually increased very sharply from half a million tourists to 1.2 million tourists. The State forests had been managed very well because of the setting up of recreation zones, scientific area zones and catchment area protection zones. This was all done when conservation was unfashionable.

The World Heritage listing is very suspect. More and more people in this country are starting to realise that what seemed to be a good idea at the time is actually of little value. If Queensland wants it, it can have it and the Opposition will support it, but it is up to the Queensland Government to decide. If it is so good, why is it not asking for it?

TALK.START.PARA: —If they did, they would be fools.
—I wish the honourable member would return to his seat and stop interjecting.
— Order! If the honourable member for Kalgoorlie wishes to interject he should return to his own seat.

—What a good idea. A wider agenda is at work here. This Bill is overriding States rights. It is centralising more power in Canberra. It is shutting up the productive areas of Australia. It is the first step in passing power to overseas bodies. It is destroying the jobs of private enterprise workers. It is repugnant to everything we on this side of the House stand for. We totally oppose it. The Minister should come to his senses and have this legislation withdrawn.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is the practice in this House for honourable members not to be interrupted when they are speaking by those who sit beside them. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie has sat there for the last 10 minutes making a fool of himself by deliberately interrupting and whispering something to the speaker. It is a discourtesy to speakers. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to speak appropriately to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, who is again rising whilst not in his place.
—Order! The Chair has advised the honourable member for Kalgoorlie of that. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in this debate I heard a poignant remark from the honourable for Braddon (Mr Miles) with which I agreed entirely-that is, that this debate needs balance. The fundamentals are that we are dealing with the need to accommodate two very important elements of national policy, namely to provide jobs and to protect the environment. Both of these elements need to be preserved. Behind the mask of the honourable member for Braddon, we then heard the authentic voice of Australian conservatism-the speaker who has just sat down, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb)-the voice of hatred, the voice that cannot accommodate any view other than his own very narrow perceptions. I hope that those who are still listening to the broadcast at this late hour listened to the honourable member for Parkes and make their own judgment about his contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, there is no room in this House for a view which is tainted by hatred or misunderstanding. The other day my colleague from Tasmania, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), addressed us on the subject of conservation. For 10 minutes he explained why he hated those whom he called the greenies. There is no room for that in this place. In our form of democracy we need to accommodate those people who need work, whose jobs are at stake, and those people who see value in our natural environment and the need to make sure that we as a nation preserve aspects of our heritage for future generations. It is a complete distortion of the focus of this debate to say that it is an issue upon which one can take the crude and simplistic analysis that has been put before this House by the honourable member for Parkes.

Let me address some very fundamental issues. Without national heritage legislation by now we would have seen the destruction of that natural heritage area, the Gordon River. This is an area which has been saved because of the courage of the Australian Labor Party in bringing before this Parliament the necessary legislation to ensure that the heritage of Australia is saved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did Whitlam flood Pedder?

—The honourable member demonstrates the depth of his ignorance in mentioning Lake Pedder. The Whitlam Government made a very generous offer to the people of Tasmania to provide all the funding necessary to ensure that that project did not go ahead. The honourable member displayed the fact that he has no comprehension of the history of the matters under discussion. In Tasmania it is vital that we address these important elements concerning the environment and the creation of jobs. I have the most serious contempt for those who put before us the record of the Tasmanian Government as a protector of jobs. The destruction of jobs in the forestry industry saddens me the most in this debate. There have been so many jobs lost as our industry has moved from a small industry based on small sawmillers and a pulp industry to woodchipping. That process has led to the loss of jobs in the timber industry. Over the many years that this has been occurring, employment in the timber industry has declined by more than half. We now have a situation where the industry is not sustaining the numbers that it did before, when it was using much less resource. We have a situation where we are not using our product most efficiently, where we have not used value added products and where we are not moving into areas of high employment but, instead, at least at the Gray Government level, are still clinging to outdated and simplistic notions of what it is to exploit forests. That is just not good enough.

SPEECH.PARA: My friend the honourable member for Braddon spoke about the forest code. That is a real step forward. I would be the last to begrudge the credit that the Tasmanian Government deserved last year in bringing forward for the first time a sensible code for forest practice management. That code is a large advance. It has problems in terms of making sure that it is enforced and that valuable timber that should be sawlog is not chipped. It has many difficulties, but at least it is a step forward. However, it is a step forward which has been brought about only in the last year and only in the face of the success of the Labor Party in raising these issues and making certain that the people of Tasmania recognise the necessity for such intelligent and creative responses to the issues that are now before this House for debate.

I am deeply saddened by the tone of dislike for the commonsense of the Australian people that is evidenced from the Opposition. In this debate we have heard the most gross distortions of the policies of this Government and we have heard, unfortunately, from those who share with me the pleasure of representing Tasmania some of the saddest statements about their motivation and what advantage they seek to take in a debate which really should be one where we are joining to ensure that national priorities are maintained, namely, protecting both jobs and the environment. In Australia in the future no government that ignores either of those two fundamentals will be returned. If the crude redneck statements that have been made by some speakers on the Opposition side in this debate reflect the tone that they will be bringing to future election campaigns, they will certainly consign themselves to a significant lack of electoral success in future elections because both the fundamentals-employment for Australians and the environment-need to be preserved.

In conclusion, I say that we need to be moving now to make sure that the resources we do hold and can use for timber production are used most wisely, that we draw back from crude use of those resources for simple woodchipping, and that we move down into value added production, pulp use, high quality timber, sawlog timber, furniture making and the like, veneer production and paper production. We should move down that track and get away from simple analyses, hatred and fraudulent hypocrisy and deal with the issue that should be before us, which is-I think that this is the bottom line-the need to protect both of these very important fundamentals for our future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a representative of one of the most important timber industries in Australia, in East Gippsland in particular, I cannot allow the mealy-mouthed, sanctimonious performance by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) to go unchallenged. It is a long time since I have heard such a string of meaningless platitudes imposed upon members of this chamber, as well as those listening to the broadcast.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Denison sought to portray himself as the personification of reasonableness and balance. Instead, he simply again portrayed more graphically than any member on this side of the House could hope to demonstrate the utter imbalance in this debate. Let the honourable member for Denison and any other of those urban-based members of the Australian Labor Party visit areas such as east Gippsland and meet with the workers and their families who are being driven out of their industry and their local communities. Those opposite should not pretend that it does not occur. When is the Labor Party going to put a human face on the drafting of its policies, particularly in regard to conservation? Those members of the Labor Party who try to portray themselves as the arbitrators of all wisdom in this debate are doing a great many Australians a grave disservice. Anyone who does not believe that the environmental debate is hopelessly imbalanced towards radical conservationists is totally out of touch. That is a characteristic one so easily associates with the Australian Labor Party in today's climate. It is an attitude that is costing the Labor Party dearly, as the New South Wales election so vividly demonstrated. I refer to the case of the honourable member for Denison, an urban lawyer from Sydney before he was drafted by the greeny movement to Denison specifically for the task of turfing out the then sitting member, the Honourable Michael Hodgman.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did a good job.
—He did it, all right. He did it because of the combined strength and force of a totally outrageous, totally unrepresentative conservation movement.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland might address himself to the matters before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, in addressing this debate about balance in the conservation argument I will set out for you the case of the East Gippsland Coalition in my electorate which has extraordinary and totally undue influence over the Cain Government in the drafting of the timber strategy which affects East Gippsland and, to a certain extent, West Gippsland. No member of the East Gippsland Coalition of whom I know, or of whom anybody else knows, lives in East Gippsland. That coalition is made up of people from different walks of life-as far as we can tell, centred on academia-who have no connection with East Gippsland. We have a State government that responds to this unrepresentative group, in total disregard of the desires of the local community.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to take up the time of the House much longer, except to point out that the honourable member for Denison spoke of being deeply saddened by the divisiveness of this debate. The divisiveness originates because of the imbalance and narrow-mindedness of the Federal Government. As long as a centralist, socialist government imposes on State governments and, by extension, regions, its own unrepresentative, totally illogical, ideological idiosyncrasies we will have such divisiveness. Members on this side of the House introduce balance to the areas we represent. We want conservation balanced by the opportunity for industry to grow and flourish so that blue collar workers, whom honourable members say they represent but who are turning to us in droves, can live in those areas. We want balance. Nobody sets out to raze the forests-certainly not those who work in them. Let us have none of this hypocrisy from members of the Labor Party who are indebted to the conservation movement for their very presence in this chamber and who, therefore, are merely paying back debts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-To say the least, tonight the debate on the Conservation Legislation Bill 1988 has been a most interesting one. Supposedly we were to see the new Liberals. These are the Liberals who dumped the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) after the last election. Nonetheless, putting that aside, these are the Liberals who are going to be, supposedly, responsible and even-handed in regard to the environment. However, tonight when they had the opportunity to show whether they had changed their spots about the environment-given all the talk from their ranks after the last election-they again opposed any legislative security for the environment at each and every point and turn.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the House tonight that in this debate we have returned to the fundamentals in regard to the environment. It is a case of us against honourable members opposite. It is a case of pro against anti. Honourable members opposite have returned to their fundamental beliefs. It is in their blood. Once again Opposition members are out and about to get the best chance-a bit of rock, a bit of minerals, a slice of timber, live for today only. The Opposition still cannot see the long term benefits and the long term necessity of protecting and enhancing the environment for anything other than the perceived short term gain which clouds their vision. After tonight one would truly have to be a mug to believe that the Liberal Party or the National Party is anything other than anti-environment, as we on this side of the House have always known. Tonight the Opposition's real views are again exposed for the world to see. The concept of a Liberal Party or National Party Minister for the environment is something akin to having a wolf standing guard on a flock of lambs.

Let me deal now, Mr Deputy Speaker, with a number of specific points raised by the Opposition in this debate tonight. First, the amendments proposed by the National Farmers Federation (NFF), as my colleague the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) so adequately explained earlier, were carefully examined by the Government and rejected as being inappropriate. However, the NFF's views on compensation and the procedures for nominations will be further considered by the Government in the development of the World Heritage policy.

Let me turn now to the contribution made to the debate by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb). In terms of the World Heritage Bill which we are talking about tonight, there are about 20 privately owned properties included. The reduction from the numbers which the honourable member was talking about a few moments ago is a direct result of the extensive consultation process undertaken by this Government. It is a great pity that the honourable member conveniently forgot to mention that.

Let us talk now about the subject of negotiations and put this in perspective. In September 1984 the Australian Heritage Commission recommended that the wet tropical rainforests of north Queensland should be nominated to the World Heritage List. For the next three years the Commonwealth tried to talk to the Queensland Government about rainforest conservation, but the State of Queensland, which has 54 per cent of Australia's rainforests, refused to alter its destructive logging schedule. And Opposition members talk to us about negotiations! Despite these obstacles, the House should be reminded, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the former Minister responsible for the Environment, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), and the present Minister responsible for the environment, Senator Richardson, persisted in attempts to negotiate with the Queenslanders. Let me say to this House loud and clear once and for all that we on this side of the House have never refused an offer to negotiate.

Earlier this evening an Opposition member raised the prospect of negotiating with the Queensland Premier. The Prime Minister wrote to the Queensland Premier on 11 December 1987 suggesting talks between the two governments. Less than two weeks later Premier Ahern said that his State would `fight to the end'. On numerous occasions the Minister responsible for the environment, Senator Richardson, has requested talks with the Queensland Government. On 20 January he telexed Premier Ahern requesting talks on the future of the Queensland rainforests. All this has been done by a Federal government which will not negotiate! I am relieved to learn from the Minister that talks have now been agreed to and that the Minister will be reporting to the Parliament once the talks have been completed. Despite the Hawke Government's attempts to secure the rainforests of north Queensland, despite the fact that this Government has a mandate secured from the people of Australia on 11 July 1987, the Opposition parties have sought to frustrate and thwart the will of the people at every turn.

Let me say loud and clear once again in this House tonight that there is no hidden agenda in this, as Opposition members paranoiacally go on about. There is no plan to list all of Australia and there is certainly no plan to lock up large areas of Australia forever for no purpose. Our proposals for World Heritage listing will not cheapen or belittle the meaning of the listing in any way, as intended by Opposition members. The Government is not interested in nominating every piece of pretty landscape or threatened bushland, as Opposition members seek to imply.

Let us talk about the issue of inspections and civil rights, as raised by the Opposition. A desperate Opposition, despite defeat on these issues by the will of the people in July 1987, now seeks to delay the legislation with some wild accusations that it is unconstitutional and somehow a threat to civil liberties. Let me say loud and clear once again that the rights of private citizens will not be diminished under this Bill. Even if there is some red cedar rather than reds under the bed for the Opposition to be paranoid about now, inspectors have no power under any circumstances to enter a private dwelling. There will be no power of seizure or arrest. The inspectors' powers are not draconian. They are only sufficient to obtain information relating to the protection and identification of World Heritage values. Inspectors can only enter property--

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's go home.

—It would do the honourable member a lot of good to listen to this. I know that it will upset the Opposition's pamphlets and Press releases, but it will do it the world of good to listen to this. Inspectors can enter property without permission or a judge's warrant only in serious and urgent circumstances.
—Such as?
—Such as?

—Honourable members ask, `Such as?'. I thank them for that. Those urgent circumstances as outlined in the proposed Act, relate to the concealment, loss or destruction of anything related to illegal activities that requires urgent collection of information. That is pretty specific. I know that nothing like that will appease honourable members opposite because they do not want to be appeased. They are looking for excuses. I hate to put the facts in the road of a good story, but that is the truth. Let us consider the Tasmanian State Government. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who is sitting out of his place, raised that earlier.
—This is my correct position.

—We think that he would do a better job as Deputy Leader also. The lack of cooperation from the Tasmanian Government in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests has demonstrated the need for independent Commonwealth inspectors-the inspectors he so queries. However, officers of Tasmania's National Parks and Wildlife Service, as the honourable member for Franklin should know, have far greater powers than those proposed for these Federal inspectors. For example, section 41 of the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Act 1970 gives authorised officers the power to seize anything on reasonable grounds. Section 42 gives them the power to search any premises, including private homes and vehicles. I would like to hear what the honourable member for Franklin intends to say to the Tasmanian Premier about that. Section 43 gives the power of arrest without warrant, even for failing to give the full name and address.

SPEECH.PARA: Not wishing to promote shock horror headlines, it is, however, my duty to inform the house of the powers of the various banana, chook, seamen and other inspectors right across the Commonwealth, in State jurisdictions, which contrast with those under this legislation which the Opposition is seeking to misrepresent tonight. This legislation is hardly the forerunner of a new environmental police state. If the Opposition is really looking for Big Brother in the bottom paddock, he is already there. The person the Opposition really fears is not a greenshirt but a brownshirt. He is the friendly, ordinary every day officer from the dozens of boards, authorities and departments dealing with production across the Commonwealth. Most of those regulatory bodies are set up under State legislation, often giving those various inspectors far more powers, particularly in the area of arrest and seizure, which inspectors under this legislation do not have. Once again, I am sorry, for the sake of those opposite, to spoil a good story and a good Press release, but those are the facts.

Let us consider the constitutional question which was also raised. This Bill does not remove the right of the Queensland Government, or any individual, to challenge the legislation or a nomination in the Australian courts. Honourable members should remember that it is not constitutionally possible for the Commonwealth to exclude the High Court of Australia from pronouncing on the constitutional validity of this Bill. In interpreting the external affairs powers, the High Court has been aware of the federal backdrop against which the Australian Constitution was originally created. There is nothing in this Bill that has not already been endorsed as constitutionally valid by the High Court in the Tasmanian dams case and the Lemonthyme case. The legislation and the protective measures will be as open to legal challenge as the old Act and measures. However, I would have thought-and this is particularly relevant to Queensland and Tasmanian taxpayers-that the Commonwealth's success in all four of the challenges to its external affairs powers should be enough to convince those States in particular of the legality of the Commonwealth's commitment. Furthermore, contrary to many claims made in the other place and elsewhere, part III of the Bill does not mean that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act no longer applies to World Heritage areas.

The effect of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill is to make it clear that any World Heritage nomination by Australia or any other action under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act to protect and conserve property would not be subject to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Given the conservation objectives of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, it should be obvious that the Federal Government has never intended the EP (IP) Act, as it is known, to apply to such activities. All other actions and decisions of the Government in World Heritage areas are still subject to the EP (IP) Act. No double standards, such as those proposed by honourable members opposite, are being applied.

It is a pity that the same cannot be said for the attitude of the conservative parties which we have seen in this chamber today. Why, for example, do both the National Party and the Liberal Party sanction the continued logging of the north Queensland rainforest without any form of environmental impact statement having been prepared? On this issue and on other environment and heritage issues the coalition parties might make all the comforting noises in the world about conservation and heritage. However, we on this side of the House and the vast majority of the Australian public will not be misled by their words. They tolerate a charade which allows the bulldozers to roll in the dead of night, demolishing hotels, the chainsaws to howl until the last of the Queensland rainforests is ravaged and the tiptrucks to fill with concrete until the last of the wild rivers is no more. This Government is committed to the environment and sensible, rational environmental policies. That is what we have done tonight.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Narrogin Senior High School-Merredin Senior High-Christ the King School

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Punch) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I have two students from my electorate of O'Connor in the Speaker's gallery who are visiting Canberra as part of my student scholarship program. I understand that a Government member has a similar group here, which I welcome. I congratulate that member for doing something I have been doing for quite some time. The two are Sonia Walsh from Corrigin, a country town in Western Australia situated approximately 240 kilometres east-south-east of Perth, and Penelope Duncan from Doodlakine, a town approximately 200 kilometres east of Perth on the Great Eastern Highway.

SPEECH.PARA: Corrigin, a friendly and community conscious town of 1,600 people, is an important centre for a farming community, which has as its main produce wheat, barley, lupins and sheep. A seed cleaning business, several stock agents and an engineering firm are amongst the many small businesses located in the town. The locals publish a biweekly newspaper focusing on community issues, and another recent project has been the formation of Central Ag Care, which provides a counselling service for rural people in hardship.

Doodlakine, a smaller town but no less important to the local farming community, is a friendly centre situated on the main rail link between Perth and Kalgoorlie, this link being important for the transport of farming produce to the port of Fremantle for export. Neither Corrigin nor Doodlakine is large enough to have senior high schools and both Sonia and Penelope are year 12 students at the nearby centres of Narrogin and Merredin.

Sonia and Penelope will complete their tertiary entrance examinations at the end of this year, Sonia at Narrogin Senior High School where there are 850 students from years 8 to 12, and Penelope at Merredin Senior High School, which was officially opened in August 1957, where there are 400 students-somewhat less than in previous years due to the economic downturn in the rural sector. Sonia boards at the Narrogin Hostel, which provides accommodation for approximately 250 fellow students from surrounding districts, whilst Penelope travels 100 kilometres a day to attend school.

Both schools have an elected student council which organises various functions on behalf of the students and acts as a liaison body between the teachers and students. Narrogin is a larger version of Sonia's home town of Corrigin. The town is farming orientated and has friendly people. Narrogin is a main shopping and medical centre for nearby districts. It has a large, modern, well-equipped hospital and also has a number of doctors, dentists and physiotherapists. Narrogin is also a major regional centre for the lower central wheat-belt of Western Australia and is located approximately 180 kilometres south-east of Perth on the main rail line between Perth and Albany, a port on the south coast of Western Australia. Narrogin is also located close to the town of Wickepin where Albert Facey of A Fortunate Life fame originated.

Merredin, which was opened up as a farming centre after the Kalgoorlie and Coolgardie gold rushes of the 1890s, has a large railway junction, a growing industrial area and many regional government offices. It is also a large service centre for the farming needs of the district, where wheat, wool and pig raising are the main industries. The town services an area of some 3,372 square kilometres. Merredin Senior High School also provides for students as far afield as Southern Cross, Mukinbudin, Kellerberrin, Narembeen and Bruce Rock and has a fine record of producing students outstanding in both academic and sporting achievements. The motto of Merredin School is `Advance' and Penelope believes the staff and students endeavour to uphold this tradition. Other activities with which students are associated are the annual dance eisteddfod at the University of Western Australia in which Merredin did extremely well last year, and a school based youth leadership option which includes the Duke of Edinburgh Award.

Sonia and Penelope are the eleventh pair of year 12 students that I have brought to the nation's capital, Canberra, under this scholarship scheme. I would also like to take this opportunity of thanking Ansett Airlines for its assistance. The teachers and students are proud of their high schools and both Sonia and Penelope are honoured to represent students from the Narrogin and Merredin Senior High Schools here today.

I thank the Parliament, the Speaker and Deputy Speaker again for the opportunity of bringing to the Parliament the speech written by these young people and finally prepared in my office today. I think it is to their credit and it is a very worthwhile exercise. I thank the Parliament for the attention it has given me.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the House, I welcome the young people from both the O'Connor and Forde electorates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to the fine calibre of the youth from my electorate of Forde who are seated in the gallery tonight. I am somewhat concerned that I have won the accolades of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) but it has been said that people who like children cannot be all bad. I wish to mention in particular four students who come from Christ the King School in Graceville. This is part of my electorate and is in the parish and district in which I live. These young ladies are Emma Forrester, Rebecca Handy, Philippa Creagh and Caroline Dunworth. I particularly wish to welcome them and say that I am sure they have found the parliamentary processes both interesting and informative. I know that they will take back home to their families, parents and friends many stories of what eventuated here.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to thank the Speaker, Ministers and colleagues who made the girls so welcome. While I am thanking people, I also wish to thank two members of my staff, Lyn Rowe and Colleen Forrester, for their long-suffering and generous spirit. It is important when we look to the youth of today to acknowledge their very real strengths and the value of their contribution to our community. They make that contribution within a family environment as the result of the support that families give to them. These four girls are very lucky in that they have family support and extended family support which of course makes for a much more stable environment in which to grow up, learn values and support the kind of hopes and aspirations which they have.

A visit to Parliament also enables them to participate in a real life learning process. A visit to this Parliament House in this year is of particular importance because, after all, this is part of our history and heritage. The girls have been very fortunate in being able to see Question Time in this House, to see the old Speaker's Chair and to sit in this chamber in the last session here.

It is important to recognise that youth is the future of Australia. In this our bicentenary year it is important to look not only at our past but also to our future. Of course it is the youth of our country-and in particular these four girls-who will contribute very much to the future of Australia. Their talents, hopes and aspirations will be part of Australia's own vision. They will take us into the twenty-first century. This visit is therefore particularly important for them.

To Emma, Rebecca, Philippa and Caroline I say: remember, girls can do anything. I think that they have seen many real role models here today. They have recognised that women do have a vital role to play in the political processes of this country. It is important to acknowledge that women comprise 54 per cent of the voters in the electorate. We, as women, have made and will continue to make a lasting contribution to the political processes of this country. I say to the youth in my electorate of Forde, and in particular to the four representatives who are present here tonight, that we look forward to their taking to us into the twenty-first century. I thank everybody who has been concerned with their visit.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 10 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What will be the cost of Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek.
(2) Will the Federal Airports Corporation have the responsibility for the airport; if so, (a) at what cost, (b) on what basis and (c) when will its responsibility commence.
(3) How will the terminal buildings and other operational facilities be funded.
(4) Will the financing of Badgerys Creek Airport be subject to public sector borrowing requirements; if not, why not.

(5) What is the state of progress of the Government's acquisition of properties for the new airport, including (a) how many properties have been bought at what individual and total cost, (b) how many remain to be bought and (c) what sum will they cost at current real estate values.
(6) When will the Government commence construction of the new airport.
(7) What arrangements has the Government made with the New South Wales Government for the provision of infrastructure, including transport systems supporting the new airport.
(8) What is the estimated cost of providing this infrastructure.

(9) Will landing charges be used to meet the cost or partial cost of the new airport; if so (a) on what basis will they be levied, (b) at what levels will they initially be set, (c) what percentage of the total cost of the new airport will be recovered from the aviation industry and over what time scale and (d) from where will the remainder of the cost of the airport be raised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) At this stage the Government has made no decision on the timing, funding or future management of the proposed second Sydney airport (SSA) at Badgerys Creek.

In February 1986 the decision to acquire the airport site stated, inter alia ``The decision does not mean that work will start immediately on the second Sydney airport. Rather, it sets aside land so that when the time comes for the airport to be built-and the timetable for that will depend on what the needs are-then at least the land will be available''.

I am ensuring that close liaison is maintained between officers of the Department of Transport and Communications, the Federal Airports Corporation, the New South Wales Government and the aviation industry. This will enable recommendations to be made to the Government at the appropriate time to facilitate the continued efficient operation of Sydney's airports.
It is expected that the SSA will be developed in stages with the ultimate extent outlined in the Master Plan being required only after several decades.

(5) As the acquisition of the SSA site falls within the portfolio responsibilities of the Hon. Stewart West MP Minister for Administrative Services, it will be necessary to direct any questions on this matter to him.
(6) As for questions (1) to (4)

(7) and (8) Close consultation and coordination took place with the NSW Government in the planning for the site. As indicated above no action is taking place to develop the airport or its access at this time.
(9) As for questions (1) to (4)
